summary: Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was brought on in the 83rd minute during a 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, but Townsend proved him wrong by scoring a stunning equalizer against Italy. Merson admitted his mistake and acknowledged being wrong. However, any apparent reconciliation seemed short-lived as Merson took another jab at Townsend following the Burnley match.

Chelsea have made a formal offer to acquire 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, according to the Japanese club's president Naoki Ogane. If the deal goes through, Muto will join Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. The young Japanese international, who graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and has earned 11 caps for Japan, scoring once. Muto expressed his honor at receiving the offer from Chelsea but has not decided on the move yet. The proposed transfer fee is around £4million and is not related to Chelsea's recent £200million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The study, published in Pediatrics, compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with records of antibiotic prescriptions. The results showed that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by age two, and children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight. The study did not prove that antibiotics were causing weight gain, but suggested that they may kill off gut bugs that would normally feed on some of the food eaten, freeing up more food for the body. The lead author warned that antibiotic exposure before six months of age, or repeatedly during infancy, was associated with increased body mass in healthy children and could contribute to the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic. The study also noted that previous research has found that babies given antibiotics are at higher risk of eczema and digestive problems.

During the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, a Queen's Guard accidentally slipped on a manhole cover, causing him to lose his footing, knock his bearskin on the sentry box, and drop his rifle. The incident was captured on camera by a tourist, David Meadwell. The guard quickly got up and continued as if nothing had happened, but appeared embarrassed as he noticed the crowd watching. The guard's slip is believed to have been caused by the metal protectors on his boots. The Changing of the Guard ceremony attracts thousands of tourists daily in the summer and every other day in the winter. The Queen's Guard is a fully operational unit, not purely ceremonial. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The iconic TV miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and attracted over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E networks for a 2016 release. The new version will be a contemporary take on the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in America, and will draw more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake, which will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History. The remake aims to reach both fans of the original and a new generation of viewers, and will consult scholars for historical accuracy. The remade "Roots" will encounter a modern audience that has seen significant racial events, such as Barack Obama's presidency and the Oscar win for "12 Years a Slave," but also widespread racial unrest in U.S. cities.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has accused Clarence House aides of attempting to force him into an orgy in the 1970s. He claims he was groped and pinned to a chair by a male member of staff on his first day at work. Lawler, now 64, says the incident occurred in January 1978 when he was 27 and working at the Queen Mother's London residence. He reported the incident to Clarence House officials but was ignored for months before the police were notified. Lawler, who was haunted by the incident for years, wrote to the Palace last year after hearing about the probe into historical cases of child abuse. His complaint was eventually passed to Scotland Yard, and a retired royal aide was reportedly interviewed but denied involvement. The Royal Household has stated it will work exhaustively and cooperatively with any police probe.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube, shows the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood. The video ends with a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple revealed that the video was made for loved ones living far away and they were surprised by its viral success. Jesse Meek is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. Another video is a possibility after finding out the child's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind was sold for $137,000 at an auction in Beverly Hills, California. The dress, a jacket and full skirt ensemble, was worn in several key scenes and was originally slate blue-gray but has faded to light gray over time. The dress was part of a private collection of over 150 items from the film, owned by James Tumblin, who began collecting memorabilia from the film in the 1960s. Other top-selling items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh, a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland as Melanie Wilkes. Gone With the Wind was based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 best-selling book and marked the first time an African-American actor, Hattie McDaniel, was nominated for and won an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. He suffered minor injuries and was rescued by his parents before paramedics arrived. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A non-functional speed camera, previously used to enforce a 30mph speed limit in a residential road in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been repositioned to face a house's front door. The camera, along with around 300 others in the West Midlands, has been out of operation since 2013 due to obsolete technology. The camera's unexpected repositioning has caused mystery, and a spokesman for Birmingham City Council stated that an engineer will visit the site and the camera may be removed. The house owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medalist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt expressed his excitement and readiness to participate, emphasizing Jamaica's successful tradition in relays and his commitment to making his country proud. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) is pleased with Bolt's availability and expects "sprint magic" at the event. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates at Barcelona, demonstrated their commitment to the club by attending the basketball El Clasico. They were accompanied by Neymar's sister, Rafaella. Barcelona won the Euro League match against Real Madrid with a score of 85-80. Despite this victory, Real Madrid remains at the top of their Euro League division due to points difference. Prior to the international break, Barcelona had won their El Clasico match in La Liga, moving four points clear at the top. Neymar, who captained Brazil, led his team to a 1-0 win over Chile in a tense match. Neymar and his Barcelona teammates will resume their La Liga campaign against Celta Vigo, aiming for a treble of trophies.

Italy is currently dealing with an influx of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. Over a four-day period, 8,480 migrants were rescued, with 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. There are fears that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people capsized off the Libyan coast, according to Save the Children. However, the Italian coast guard has not found evidence to confirm this incident. There has been a recent increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy, with the Italian Coast Guard performing more rescues. In the first three months of 2015, Italy registered over 10,000 migrants, with most coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean this year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Chilean forward Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal instead of Liverpool, although he is unsure of the exact reason for Sanchez's decision. Sanchez, who was pursued by several elite clubs last summer, has made an immediate impact in English football, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been used as leverage during negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Wenger praises Sanchez's qualities, work-rate, and fighting spirit, stating that he is one of the best around. Ahead of the Premier League clash between Arsenal and Liverpool, Wenger downplays any potential summer transfer move for Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling and commends Brendan Rodgers for developing his team following the sale of Suarez and injury to striker Daniel Sturridge.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record of 52.491km was set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, who is also a three-time Olympic gold medalist on the track, is expected to set a mark that will last for some time. He will hope for a capacity crowd of 6,000 to spur on his attempt, with tickets going on sale from April 19. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins is targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics in the four-man, four-kilometre team pursuit.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion, found her match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup to be a significant 'eye-opener' as the claycourt season begins. Despite winning 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3, Williams expressed dissatisfaction with her performance. The US team, including Williams and Alison Riske, were defeated 3-2 by Italy, with Errani and Flavia Pennetta winning the doubles rubber 6-0 6-3. This loss relegated the US to World Group II. Williams, who won her 19th singles grand slam at the Australian Open, acknowledged her lack of readiness for the claycourt season. The French Open has been her least successful major, despite winning it in 2002 and 2013. The doubles defeat marred her otherwise perfect Fed Cup record and left the US needing to work harder to return to the elite nations next year.

River Plate are interested in signing their former striker Radamel Falcao, who currently plays for Manchester United on loan from Monaco. Falcao has struggled at United, scoring only four Premier League goals this season. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the club's desire to bring Falcao back, stating "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open." Falcao, who is 29 years old, has recently shown good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games and equaling the country's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. Falcao previously played for River Plate from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Ella Henderson, a former X Factor finalist and pop star known for her vocals, has been announced as the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This marks Henderson's first brand collaboration at the age of 19. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles against a vibrant city background. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, Mirror Man. Henderson has expressed her excitement about working with the brand, which she regularly uses. The campaign is also the first endorsement for Henderson, as commented by Mark Hargreaves, the CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group who manages her.

In Kenosha, Wisconsin, a billboard featuring officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot 26-year-old Aaron Siler on March 14, has sparked outrage among Siler's family and friends. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, was intended to thank the community for its support during recent incidents. However, Siler's family and friends find it disrespectful and are calling for its removal. Torres is currently on leave as the investigation into the shooting continues. Siler was shot after arming himself during a vehicle and foot pursuit, as he was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant. This incident occurred just 10 days after Torres shot and wounded 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with knives.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan. The militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack. The group is anti-Iranian and has targeted Shiites, aiming to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iran has criticized Pakistan for failing to rein in the terrorists. The Pakistani government condemned the attack and stated that they are investigating the incident and will apprehend the militants if they entered Pakistan after the attack.

In a political discussion in Japan's parliament, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani assured that the country's Air Self Defense Force had never encountered extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects. This was in response to a query from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who had asked if aircraft were ever scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. Inoki, known for his distinctive chin and red scarf, has a history of political and entertainment achievements, including founding the New Japan Pro Wrestling organization and traveling to Iraq to secure the release of Japanese hostages. He also claims to have seen a UFO himself. This isn't the first time Japanese politicians have discussed the implications of visitors from another planet; in 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba pondered the legal ramifications of a defense against an invasion from outer space.

A passenger, Jin Pai, at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in eastern China, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was standing on broke. Pai was standing on the toilet rim due to cleanliness concerns, but the toilet collapsed, causing him to fall and sustain injuries. He was found bleeding on the toilet floor and required several dozen stitches. Pai initially confessed to his friends that he was squatting on the toilet but later told police he was sitting when the toilet gave way, possibly to avoid paying compensation. Authorities believe the incident was an accident and reminded people that the toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested on multiple charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The charges stem from allegations that Rebbie sexually abused a girl in her home over a four-year period and filmed her and others using a hidden camera in a bathroom. The investigation began when a 15-year-old girl discovered the hidden camera in her bathroom. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, but had specifically purchased the camera to record the 15-year-old victim. He is currently being held on a $500,000 bail and his preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1.

The passage discusses a unique photography series by Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama, which features portraits of teenage daughters standing next to their fathers leaping into the air. The daughters maintain a poised expression while their fathers display energetic poses, despite some older fathers showing pained expressions. The fathers are dressed in sharp suits, possibly referencing the term "salary man," while the daughters wear casual clothing. The photographs are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks and are part of a book roughly translated as "Daughter and Salaryman." Despite little information about the project, the images have gained significant online interest due to their curious nature.

The dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director has sparked discussions about Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England cricket team. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, was seen in a range of emotions during a team photo shoot for Surrey at the KIA Oval before the start of the County Championship season. Despite looking deep in thought, Pietersen was jovial and joked with photographers and teammates. His return to Surrey is an attempt to force his way back into the Test set-up, with England hoping to regain the Ashes this summer on home soil. Pietersen last featured at international level during England's disastrous Ashes tour in Australia last year, which saw his side suffer a whitewash series defeat.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, has dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender and Inter Milan and Parma right back with 25 international caps, was initially fired due to poor performance but was rehired the next day. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, Ze Maria was fired again, leaving Ceahlaul 16th in the standings and six points away from safety. Serbian Vanya Radinovic will replace Ze Maria, who was the club's third coach this season.

Radamel Falcao, formerly of Monaco and Atletico Madrid, has had a challenging loan spell at Manchester United, scoring only four goals. His former teammate Nabil Dirar suggests that Falcao may regret the move, despite not being content in France. Dirar believes Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played more and participated in the Champions League. Falcao's struggles at United are likely due to his inability to replicate his pre-injury form. Manchester United have the option to make Falcao's transfer permanent for £46 million, but his performance this season makes it unlikely they will do so.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy in New Zealand on Saturday. The offender, described as 'very tall', demanded cash from the dairy owner's daughter and made off with the till and about $1500 in cash. The masked man threw the cash register to the ground before fleeing. Police have no information on the suspect's identity and are appealing to the public for help. No weapons were used during the robbery, and the robber remains at large. Anyone with information is asked to call Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for the second time on Monday. She was initially arrested on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, which involved kissing and allowing the student to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. After being released on bail, she was arrested again after another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January in her car across the road from another school in Dallas. The second arrest came after a school police officer learned of a possible relationship between Granado and another student. She was subsequently suspended from teaching and put on administrative leave. Granado was booked into Irving County Jail and released after posting a $50,000 bail. It is not known how she intends to plead to the second set of charges against her.

A video of a large crocodile carrying a dead dog in its mouth has been viewed over half a million times online. The incident occurred in the tourist hotspot of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, where the crocodile was seen swimming through a public marina with the dog, wearing a red collar, in its jaws. The dog belonged to a local bike shop owner. The crocodile held onto its catch for hours, causing shock and amazement among onlookers. The area is known for its crocodile population, with a sanctuary located nearby. The video has sparked horror and negative reactions towards crocodiles on social media. However, crocodiles are a common sight in Puerto Vallarta, as the beach resort is built amongst the mangroves that the creatures have called home for centuries.

Steve Bruce remains optimistic about Hull City's chances of avoiding relegation from the Barclays Premier League, despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton leaving them in a precarious position. Hull have managed just six wins this season, falling short of Bruce's initial target of 10. Hull's struggles are attributed to long-term injuries of key players such as Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Despite their challenges, Bruce is confident his team can secure the necessary results in their remaining six fixtures, which include difficult matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Meanwhile, Southampton moved up to fifth in the table after their win, but manager Ronald Koeman had to address a penalty dispute between James Ward-Prowse and Sadio Mane.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, has been banned from teaching for at least two years after he allowed pupils to change their exam answers and altered some himself, invalidating the entire school's SATs results. This incident occurred at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, where Guffick asked pupils to make changes to their SATs exam answers after the exam session had finished. The Department for Education annulled all SATs exam results for the school following an investigation by the local education authority. Guffick admitted to the allegations and accepted that his actions amounted to unacceptable professional conduct, but insisted he only asked pupils to make their answers more legible. The panel concluded that Guffick's conduct was dishonest, but not fraudulent or seriously dishonest. He was banned from the classroom for at least two years and was given 28 days to appeal against the decision to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, has been struggling for regular playtime at the club since his arrival in 2010. Despite this, he has a lot to be happy about in his personal life. He is married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, and they have a son together. The couple got married in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius in 2014. Lindegaard, who is currently third-choice at Old Trafford, has made just 19 league appearances in five seasons. Despite his lack of success on the pitch, he enjoys a happy personal life with his wife and son.

The 13 glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium, previously owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson since 2008, failed to find a buyer at a Sotheby's auction on Wednesday. Despite an estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000, the only bid was a non-winning $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. Jackson, who bought the 10-feet-tall letters "on a lark," had hoped a new generation would own and enjoy this iconic piece of Yankees and New York City history. The letters had been atop Yankee Stadium since 1976 until its final game in 2008. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe regarding their recent actions involving nitrous oxide and shisha pipes. He reminded them of their professional responsibilities and urged them to learn from the experience. Neither player will be disciplined, and Rodgers wants to move past the incident. Rodgers also discussed the return of Steven Gerrard for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, but did not reveal whether Gerrard would be an immediate starter. Rodgers' main focus is guiding Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management. He reflected on past near-misses and emphasized the importance of learning from losses to improve and ultimately achieve success.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's midfielder, is enjoying his time at home in London after the international break, as indicated by a picture he posted on Twitter with his dog. He recently played well for Germany in their Euro 2016 qualifier against Georgia, which they won 2-0. Despite missing Arsenal's last game due to illness, he is expected to play in the upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool. Since returning from injury in January, Ozil has been performing exceptionally, with four assists and three goals. He has also expressed that he is finally adjusting to English football and feels he fits in 'perfectly'.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club is content with manager Luis Enrique and has no plans to replace him. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal, is close to winning the La Liga title. Despite rumors of Enrique's potential replacement, Bartomeu expressed satisfaction with the manager's performance. Enrique's contract runs until 2016, and Barcelona is one of the few clubs still in contention for three trophies this season. The team recently defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club. His current contract had 14 months remaining, and after negotiations, he is set to sign improved terms worth around £100,000 per week until the summer of 2020. Henderson, 24, has been one of the most improved players under manager Brendan Rodgers and has contributed 13 assists and seven goals from midfield this season. He is being considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy. Liverpool's Chief Executive, Ian Ayre, expects England forward Raheem Sterling to be at Anfield for a long time, although talks with him are not expected to resume until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, a full back for Chelsea, has expressed his desire to remain with the club until his contract ends, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Luis signed a three-year contract with Chelsea last July but has faced challenges in securing the left back position. Atletico Madrid hopes to leverage this situation, but Luis has stated his happiness and intention to stay at Chelsea. Luis recently played for Brazil in friendly matches against France and Chile, but his focus is now on the Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is pushing his team to stay focused and win every game, with Luis echoing the need for concentration and preparation for the challenging games ahead.

Nathan Hughes, a Fiji-born No 8 for Wasps, had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after accidentally colliding with George North's head during a try-scoring play on March 27. Hughes was initially suspended for recklessness, but the ban was rescinded due to lack of intent and evidence of accidental collision. The incident left North unconscious and was his third concussion in two months. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss against Toulon, but is now free to return to action immediately, although he is not in the squad for Wasps' upcoming match against London Welsh. The appeal panel concluded that no foul play took place in the incident.

A summary of the passage would be: The striking red sunsets witnessed in Seattle and other parts of the Pacific Northwest, including Oregon and British Columbia, were caused by wildfires in southeastern Siberia. These fires were initially started by farmers burning grass in their fields but quickly grew out of control due to strong winds, leading to the destruction of numerous villages. The smoke from these fires was carried across the Pacific Ocean by atmospheric winds, resulting in the intense red sunsets. This phenomenon occurred because smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors like green, blue, yellow, and purple, allowing red and orange to penetrate the air unfiltered. The colors were particularly intense during sunrises and sunsets due to the increased atmospheric light travel. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets will lose their red hue.

A Missouri mom, Becky Schoenig, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was later found and returned to her, but with some modifications made by the thieves. The car now had red rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of getting upset, Schoenig took to Facebook to express her amusement, writing "I want to thank the car thieves for pimping out my vehicle for me.... This b***h is pimpin now!!!" She is now getting the vehicle professionally cleaned to deal with the smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Schoenig also plans to create a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Mick Sexton, the man who located her car and notified police.

Manchester City players, including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The team is currently on incentivised contracts to comply with financial fairplay rules. Manchester City, who lost to Manchester United in the recent derby, are in fourth place, just four points ahead of Liverpool. The top three finishers in the Premier League qualify automatically for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. In total, the City squad has around £12million resting on reaching their European target. The team has struggled in 2015, losing seven times, including early exits in the FA Cup and Champions League. Manchester City now faces a battle to sign world-class players like Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba, who also interests Manchester United.

The Under 18 teams of Manchester United and Manchester City played a 'mini-derby' match at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with United winning 1-0. The match was attended by close to 1,000 spectators and entry was free. The match-winner was Callum Gribbin, who scored a delightful free-kick. The result leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City have lost both matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series. The match showcased the talents of young players from both teams, with many of them being local and English.

Joe Hart, England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised fellow goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a 'legend of the game' after Buffon claimed his 147th cap. Hart, who earned his 50th cap in the same game, expressed his admiration for Buffon, stating that he still looks up to the Italian veteran and is inspired by his career. Hart also expressed his desire to continue playing for his club and country and accumulate more caps.

Chipotle, a popular Mexican restaurant chain, has entered the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app. This service will be available in 67 cities for online and mobile orders, with a nine per cent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. Chipotle has previously declined collaborations with third-party delivery services but has now chosen to work with Postmates, which employs independent contractors similar to Uber. The chain's success is evident, with presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton recently spotted at their restaurants. Chipotle is not alone in this venture, as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring delivery services.

The parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have written an emotional plea to the Justice Department to take the death penalty off the table for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was found guilty on all 30 charges related to the bombings. The Richards, who also had their 7-year-old daughter severely injured in the attack, argue that years of appeals would prolong the painful reminder of what was taken from them and their two remaining children. They propose that Tsarnaev spend the rest of his life in prison without any possibility of release and waive all of his rights to appeal. The Richards stress that they are only speaking for themselves and hope to turn the page and look towards a better future.

A mystery billionaire has transformed a Boeing 747 into a luxurious home, complete with bedrooms, lounges, and an onboard restaurant. The custom-built jumbo jet, which typically carries 600 passengers, was modified over three years to meet the owner's specifications at an estimated cost of £400million. The plane features a large dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a lounge, a 'state room,' and an 'aeroloft' with eight full beds for passengers. The interior design resembles a luxury hotel, with a main suite, conference room, and guest bedroom/office. The plane can accommodate several dozen passengers and offers a hotel-like ambience, far surpassing the luxury of first-class commercial flights.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft from Florida to the International Space Station. The mission aimed to land the rocket stage on a floating barge, but it was unsuccessful, with the rocket tipping over upon landing. This was SpaceX's second attempt to land a Falcon 9 on a drone ship. The Dragon spacecraft will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station, including an espresso maker, and return with over 3,000 pounds of cargo. This is SpaceX's sixth mission to the International Space Station. The company aims to reduce space travel costs by reusing rockets.

Priscilla Presley, Elvis Presley's former wife, will be a witness at the inaugural wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The wedding will take place at the Westgate Hotel, where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows. The winning couple, to be announced next Monday, will receive a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel suite stay, airfare, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla Presley has been involved in the design of the chapel, which is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis' artifacts outside his Memphis home. Couples interested in being the first to wed at the chapel must submit a video or photos with an explanation of why they deserve the prize. Priscilla Presley emphasized that the chapel is a first-class establishment and not a joke.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League, as they sit four points behind them. Henderson played his 47th game of the season in the 2-0 win over Newcastle United, equalling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute with a fine skill, and Joe Allen scored his first Anfield goal with 20 minutes to go, capitalizing on a defensive mistake. Newcastle had a strong shout for a penalty when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez in the area, but it was not given. Liverpool's players congratulated Allen on his goal that secured another vital win in the Premier League battle.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A, a crucial match for Champions League spots. Miralem Pjanic scored the winning goal in the 25th minute after a swift counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis was instrumental in securing the win, saving multiple shots by Napoli in the second half. The win provisionally placed Roma four points ahead of city rivals Lazio. Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches, leaving them in fifth place. The match was played under tight security due to a previous incident involving a Napoli fan. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho. Despite a possible penalty claim for Napoli, the referee did not award it. Napoli forward Lorenzo Insigne returned late in the game after a knee injury.

The passage describes a dull football match between Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town in League One, which resulted in a goalless draw. The match was a reflection of Doncaster's uninspired season, leaving them in mid-table mediocrity. The lack of excitement in the game posed a challenge for Doncaster's media team to compile match highlights. They ultimately decided to make it brief, with only 27 seconds of highlights, including 14 seconds of actual match action. The video, featuring the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle, was humorously deemed a 'must-see' for all football fans.

In the provided passage, Roland Giroux has an unusual relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish. Despite marine pets typically lacking the ability to interact through touch, Giroux manages to stroke and massage his fish, which seems to enjoy the sensation. The fish swims around Giroux's hand, allowing him to gently cup it and stroke it with his finger. The fish even swims up Giroux's arm and circles his fingers. This relationship developed over time, starting with hand-feeding the fish frozen blood worms, which led to the fish becoming more sociable. Giroux noticed that the fish enjoyed being stroked and would become frustrated if he didn't interact with it daily. He now spends at least 15 minutes each day massaging and playing with his fish. The blood parrot cichlid was originally bred in Taiwan around 1986 and is a hybrid of the midas and the redhead cichlid.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes, a fiery character in the England cricket team, known for his aggression and natural exuberance. He has a history of channeling his aggression inappropriately, such as breaking his wrist punching a locker after being dismissed. However, he has shown positive responses to guidance from England coach Peter Moores, who has helped him manage his aggression and respond appropriately to on-field incidents. Stokes' character is appreciated as it adds excitement to the game, which can sometimes be perceived as producing robotic players. England wants to have Stokes in the team as much as possible to help him hit his full potential, but he will need careful man-management to ensure his aggression is controlled and he does not become pigeon-holed. The team also wants to play the second spinner in Adil Rashid, which could potentially impact Stokes or Chris Jordan's place in the team, but England wants both to play as much as possible to grow into the international game.

The Euro 2016 qualifier between Wales and Belgium, scheduled for June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium, has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams are leading Group B with 11 points each, with Belgium ranked fourth in the world and leading due to a superior goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has boosted expectations for qualification, with the Football Association of Wales reporting high demand for tickets. Despite speculation of moving the match to the larger Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules and the Wales squad's preference for the Cardiff City Stadium have kept the venue unchanged.

The England Under-17 football team, coached by John Peacock, has announced its squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The team, which is the defending champion, qualified with a perfect record and will compete in Group D against Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7. The squad includes talented young players from various Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo of Chelsea, and Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi of Arsenal. Liverpool pair Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have been recalled after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers. The team will also play against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht player Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered a top talent from Anderlecht's youth academy. He has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Despite being offered a spot at Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12, he chose to stay and continue his studies. Manchester City have spoken with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to negotiate a compensation package for the young player. Manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to build for the future by acquiring the promising Evangelos Patoulidis.

A transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, aged 33, was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. Santillan, a Mexican national, worked in London, Paris, and Miami. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been released on bail. Scotland Yard appealed to anyone who had contact with Santillan before her death to come forward. The police are investigating the case and urged anyone with information to assist in understanding the motive behind the incident. Santillan was pronounced dead at the scene, having suffered injuries to her head and neck.

A woman named Dawn, who had seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show to confront her family friend and housemate, Jamie, who is a convicted burglar, for stealing £207 that was set aside for her baby's gravestone. Dawn and her partner, also named Jamie, had been saving up for a £500 gravestone for their baby, Daniel James. When confronted, Jamie initially denied taking the money, but a lie detector test revealed that he was lying. After the show, a distraught Dawn expressed her feelings of betrayal and heartbreak, stating that she wanted to put a headstone on her baby's grave to show her love for him.

On Wednesday, ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group that faced killings, captures, and displacement when ISIS overtook their towns in northern Iraq last summer. The released individuals were mostly women, children, ill, or elderly. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil, the Kurdish regional capital. The exact number of released Yazidis is unclear, with counts ranging from 217 to 228. This is not the first time ISIS has released Yazidis, as they have freed scores of others since their initial attacks last year. The Yazidis are a Kurdish descent minority group with a pre-Islamic religion, and they have historically faced persecution. ISIS's invasion of Iraq's north last summer forced hundreds of thousands of minorities, including Yazidis, from their homes. ISIS's treatment of the Yazidis has been particularly cruel, with reports of mass killings, rapes, and enslavement of female captives.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham sensation who has had a remarkable season, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. Kane's impressive performances have earned him a place in Roy Hodgson's England side. A new animation, produced by Copa90, showcases some of Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his debut goal for England. The video is titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?' and has been released ahead of the awards ceremony on Sunday, where Kane is up against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, believes Brendan Rodgers should continue as Liverpool's manager despite a trophyless season and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher emphasized that Rodgers' future should not be determined by a single game and acknowledged the difficulty in integrating new players. He expressed hope that Rodgers, along with the team and staff, will improve next season, aiming to win a trophy and secure a top-four finish. Carragher also highlighted the importance of making the right signings to avoid repeating this season's performance. The passage also mentions Carragher's community work on Merseyside, for which he received a Beacon Award.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy gun confiscated by security at East Midlands Airport due to it being deemed a security risk. The toy, a plastic Nerf gun that fires sponge darts, was detected by the X-ray machines during a security check for a flight to Lanzarote. James' father, Phil, criticized the security checks as 'ludicrous' and 'over-zealous.' After returning from their holiday, James was bought a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but stated that they had offered to post the toy back to the family's home. The airport defended their decision, citing regulations set by the government that state no items resembling prohibited items may be permitted through security.

A man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, identified only as 'Rich', has posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. The 31-year-old is looking for a non-drinker and non-smoker who is fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, and good around the house. She should also be a good cook, great in bed, and enjoy the outdoors while also being a 'princess when need to be'. Rich describes himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, with brown hair and brown eyes. He does not drink, smoke, or do drugs, and enjoys traveling, sports, fishing, and camping. He is 175cm tall, well-endowed, owns his own properties, makes great money, and loves cars and bikes. Rich promises to spoil his potential partner with lots of benefits and is not shy of spending money on her. He also stated that former partners need not apply.

The Football Association chairman, Greg Dyke, is advocating for significant changes in English football, including increasing the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to twelve and altering the definition of 'home-grown' to mean training in England for three years before the age of 18. Dyke faces opposition from the Premier League. Five former England managers - Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren - have expressed their support for Dyke's proposals in a letter, warning that failure to implement these changes could further harm England's chances of winning the World Cup. They cite the shrinking pool of English talent playing at the highest level as a disadvantage for any England manager. Despite this, there are signs of encouragement with the emergence of young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane. However, the former managers emphasize that these young talents are not being given enough opportunities.

In the upcoming episode of the show, Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, becomes a father to a baby daughter. Despite his marriage to Demelza, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, being out of duty, he expresses his love for her. However, the timeline of Demelza's pregnancy is questionable, as she goes from announcing her pregnancy to giving birth in a short span of time. This has been noted by fans, who have humorously commented on the quick pregnancies in the show, comparing it to a previous pregnancy storyline involving Elizabeth, another character vying for Ross's affection.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to focus on their own performances and ignore their relegation rivals as they aim to avoid relegation from the Barclays Premier League. The Foxes are currently bottom of the table but have improved their chances of survival with back-to-back wins, including a last-minute victory over West Bromwich Albion. Despite other teams being dragged into the relegation battle, Pearson insists that his team's fate is in their own hands and they must concentrate on their own games to give themselves a realistic chance of survival. He also warned against over-optimism, stating that results only help if they have done their own job.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration, traveling nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers) from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey, documented by scientists from Oregon State University, surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's extensive trip, which included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggests she might be an eastern gray whale, not an endangered western whale as previously thought. This discovery raises questions about the genetic differentiation between the species and the actual number of western gray whales, which is estimated to be around 150.

In a surprising turn of events, a 1,000ft stretch of seabed rose to the surface overnight along the coastline of Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, on Japan's Hokkaido Island. This sudden emergence, reaching up to 50ft in height, was likely caused by a landslide triggered by melting ice and snow. The new landmass, measuring approximately 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, caught the local residents off guard as they reported no sounds or tremors during the occurrence. The incident is not linked to the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake in the Kathmandu Valley. Marine organisms, such as seaweed and sea urchins, are still attached to the newly emerged landmass.

Gregory van der Wiel, a full back for Paris Saint-Germain, has dismissed rumors of his departure from the club in the summer. Despite a disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc following his exclusion from the Champions League match against Chelsea, Van der Wiel affirmed his contentment with the club, expressing his love for it, the city, and his teammates. He stated that he is not considering leaving and is interested in signing a new contract. However, the club's reported interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves may impact Van der Wiel's future at Paris Saint-Germain.

Carlos Tevez, the top scorer in Serie A and a striker for Juventus, has expressed his desire to leave the club this summer, despite being on track to win a second Serie A title and still having a chance at European glory. Tevez, who started his career at Boca Juniors in Argentina, has a contract with Juventus until 2016, but he is reportedly close to returning to Boca Juniors. However, Boca Juniors' president Daniel Angelici has stated that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Despite Juventus' reluctance to lose their star player, they have accepted Tevez's decision and have already started looking for potential replacements. Tevez's international manager Tata Martino has stated that any potential move would not affect Tevez's Argentina future.

The passage describes a Champions League match between Bayern Munich and Porto at the Allianz Arena, where Bayern Munich won 6-1, securing a place in the semi-finals. The goals were scored by Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Despite Porto's two-goal lead from their previous match, they were outplayed by Bayern Munich. The excitement of the match led to Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola ripping his trousers, revealing his underwear. Guardiola joked about the incident, saying he would need to buy new trousers for the next match. The passage also mentions that Guardiola removed his suit blazer during the latter stages of the match.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, resulting in injuries for all ten individuals. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy with chest injuries, as well as a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain, were airlifted to hospitals. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. A man suffered hand lacerations, and two females escaped injuries. The highway was closed off, with diversions in place south of Fernvale. Emergency crews found one person trapped inside their vehicle and used hydraulic cutting gear to free them. The Rescue 500 helicopter airlifted a number of patients to hospital. Police stated that the highway would be closed for a few hours.

This weekend, Arsenal, currently second in the Premier League, will face off against league leaders Chelsea. Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is eagerly awaiting the match and recently acquired an Apple Watch to count down the time until the 4pm kick-off on Sunday. Meanwhile, Arsenal's Jack Wilshere, who has been out for five months due to injury, is expected to return to the team. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere has the potential to be a key player for Arsenal, but his fitness record has been a concern. Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six league games remaining.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford. Despite sending off three players from both teams this season, Clattenburg is considered one of the Premier League's leading referees. He has shown only two red cards this season, both to United players: Tyler Blackett in the 5-3 defeat by Leicester and Luke Shaw in the 1-1 draw with West Ham. City captain Vincent Kompany was also sent off by Clattenburg during the international break. The derby could ultimately decide who finishes second behind expected winners Chelsea, as United are currently a point above City. Clattenburg will be joined by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, while Jonathan Moss will serve as the fourth official.

MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of viewing embattled MP Billy Gordon as 'a little black puppet on a string', suggesting they assumed Gordon would resign after recent domestic violence accusations and admission of a criminal past. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, empathized with Gordon's position, citing his own experiences with racism. Gordon was forced to leave the Queensland Labor Party and will continue as an independent, causing chaos for the government's slim majority. Katter's statement sparked criticism on social media for his choice of words. He defended his use of 'black puppet', stating it was due to his dark complexion and Cloncurry origins, and that he aimed to highlight racial overtones. Katter used examples of federal MPs becoming government puppets but assured Gordon would not follow suit.

A teenager named Dayna Dobias, aged 19, from Downers Grove, Illinois, is using dance to challenge stereotypes about disabilities. Born with cerebral palsy, Dayna has faced bullying and discrimination but is determined to inspire others with her enthusiastic dance videos. She aims to change perceptions about disabilities and encourage people to look beyond her condition. Despite initial predictions that she may never walk, Dayna is not only dancing but also driving, attending college, and even doing motivational speaking at local schools. She hopes her videos will not only entertain but also inspire others to think before judging and to see her as just like everyone else.

Orlando City, an MLS team with a significant Latin-American fanbase, has shown interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez. The Mexican international has struggled during his loan spell at Real Madrid but is still sought after by eight European sides and several Premier League clubs. Manchester United is willing to sell him for around £8million. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

A group of at least three individuals doused a car with gasoline and set it on fire at a South Los Angeles 76 Station around 12:15am on Saturday. The driver of the car, who remains unidentified, reported an argument with the suspects while refueling. The suspects attempted to carjack the driver, who fled as they began spraying gasoline on his white Dodge Charger, which had two passengers inside. Although no one was injured, the car's front end was completely destroyed. The incident is being investigated as arson by the Los Angeles County Fire Department, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance footage is being used in the investigation.

A chiropractor from southern Iowa, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement admitting to his misconduct and agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these allegations, Manuel received outstanding evaluations for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com. The agreement requires Manuel to prove that the circumstances surrounding the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can resume practicing chiropractic in the state. These circumstances included bartering sex for services with some patients and recommending that patients stop taking medication he prescribed to them. Manuel's former practice was located in the small agricultural town of Lamoni, Iowa.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland. The U.S. crew reported the Russian pilot's actions as aggressive due to the close proximity and high speed of the interception. Russia claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward its border with its transponder off, but the U.S. denied this. The Pentagon and State Department plan to file a complaint through diplomatic channels with Russia. This is not the first such incident; a similar encounter occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk.

In Salt Lake City, an FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a hotel parking lot, along with other belongings. The rifle was properly secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains to a truck safe inside the car. The theft occurred overnight at the Marriott Springhill Suites, where the agent was staying. The thief broke the car window and used a rope to pull the rifle case out. The case's handle was broken off and found on the pavement. The agent's other bags and clothing were found at a nearby hotel, but the sniper rifle remains missing. The theft happened a week before President Obama's visit to Utah. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and police are unsure if the agent's car was specifically targeted. The rifle's serial number has been entered into a national crime database.

In July 2012, Luigi Costa, a 71-year-old man allegedly killed his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in Red Hill, Canberra. Costa is accused of stomping on Freebody's head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa after the incident and found evidence of his declining mental state, attributed to dementia and alcohol abuse. Costa's fluctuating mood, confused mental state, and a trail of feces from the crime scene to the toilet suggested his compromised brain function. Professor Mullen believes Costa was suffering from dementia in the months and possibly years leading up to the event. Costa's state of mind is crucial to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack is proven.

In the passage, Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a 10th-minute penalty against Burnley at Goodison Park, despite the presence of Leighton Baines, who has a strong record of scoring penalties. Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, but Everton still won 1-0 thanks to a goal from Kevin Mirallas. Martinez argued that Barkley was within his rights to take the penalty and that he encourages multiple players to be confident in taking penalties. Despite the miss, Martinez praised Barkley's responsibility and willingness to take control of big moments.

Two passengers were found dead in their cabin on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, in what appears to be a murder-suicide, according to the cruise line, Holland America. The incident occurred on March 29 during a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise that departed from Tampa, Florida. The FBI is currently investigating the case, and the authorities will make the official determination on what occurred. The deceased passengers were discovered by the cleaning staff after knocking on the cabin's door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has led Curacao to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 World Cup. Curacao advanced after a 2-2 draw in a second-leg match at Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team had previously won 2-1 in Willemstad. The crucial goal was scored by Charlton Vicento in the 87th minute, after coming on as a substitute. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a World Cup losing semi-finalist in 1998 as a player and in 2014 as assistant to coach Louis van Gaal. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, a decorated footballer who has won numerous European titles, considers helping Leicester City stay in the Premier League as significant as winning a trophy. Despite Leicester's precarious position at the bottom of the table, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances of avoiding relegation. He acknowledges the difficulty of the task but believes in his team's ability to secure the necessary wins. Cambiasso, who joined Leicester after successful stints at Inter Milan and Real Madrid, has become a key player for the Foxes and is content with his life in the East Midlands. His current contract expires at the end of the season, but he has hinted at the possibility of extending his stay.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her two children under five by her own mother, Debbie. Gemma has a history of drinking, partying, and using legal highs, and Debbie suspects her of stealing. Debbie has been caring for the children since they were four months old, after social services threatened to intervene. Debbie is now considering banning Gemma from seeing the children due to her untrustworthy behavior and lack of responsibility towards her children. Gemma admits to stealing from her mother in the past but denies stealing an iPad from one of the children.

In a match between Chelsea and Manchester United at Stamford Bridge, Chelsea took a 1-0 lead after Eden Hazard scored a goal. However, the goal was controversial as it was preceded by a strong challenge from Chelsea captain John Terry on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao. The challenge caused Falcao to lose the ball, which was then picked up by Cesc Fabregas and led to the goal. During halftime analysis, pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed that Terry's challenge was a foul and should have been penalized. Souness described it as a "decent forearm smash" and Henry expressed sympathy for Falcao as a fellow striker. Redknapp acknowledged that while Falcao could have stayed on his feet, Terry's challenge was still a foul.

In a surprising incident, Hillary Scott, the co-lead singer of Lady Antebellum, was aboard a tour bus that caught fire on a Texas freeway. Everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated. The fire was likely caused by a rear tire blowout. Although the bus was severely damaged, Scott expressed gratitude for their safety and the help they received. Notably, Scott's Bible was the only item left undamaged in the back lounge of the bus. The other two band members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus at the time. The band is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

The Scottish scientist Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is developing a space laser system that converts sunlight into energy using mirrors and semi-conductors on satellites orbiting Earth. This energy can be transmitted back to Earth to power homes, potentially making solar power viable in places like Scotland and enabling rapid restoration of power in disaster-hit areas. The system is not as powerful as depicted in science fiction and cannot be used as a weapon. However, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges the need for careful consideration of who controls these satellites. This concept is different from a recently proposed idea of using lasers on the International Space Station to clear up space debris.

A predatory convicted paedophile, Stephen Munden, 54, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. Munden, who has a 'fanatical obsession' with young girls, was last seen leaving the hospital on Tuesday at 6.15pm. He is described as about 5ft 8ins tall, of a heavy build, with dark hair, and may have shaved off his beard. Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl and was convicted of sexual offences, including possessing indecent images of children. He denied the offences, claiming they were accidental. Munden suffers from autism and mild learning difficulties, and has difficulty controlling his sexual interest in small children. A manhunt has been launched to find Munden, and anyone with information is urged to contact the police.

In summary, V. Stiviano, the former female companion of Donald Sterling, has been ordered by a Los Angeles judge to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts after being sued by Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling. The gifts included luxury cars and a duplex, and were given to Stiviano by Donald Sterling, who made his fortune in real estate. The lawsuit accused Stiviano of targeting extremely wealthy older men. The court decision was celebrated by Shelly Sterling's lawyer as a victory for the Sterling family. Donald Sterling's downfall came after a recording surfaced of him making racist remarks to Stiviano, which led to his ban from the NBA and the termination of his ownership rights in the Los Angeles Clippers.

Thierry Henry, former Arsenal player and current Sky Sports pundit, has expressed criticism towards Arsenal's recent transfer activities. He believes the team needs to acquire four top-tier players in the summer: a goalkeeper, a center back, a defensive midfielder, and a striker. Henry made these comments following Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea. He also expressed doubts about Olivier Giroud's ability to lead Arsenal to a Premier League title, despite Giroud's 14 league goals this season. Henry suggested that Arsenal needs a high-quality striker, citing Chelsea's successful signings of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as examples. Arsenal is currently third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

A young woman, who was a victim of years-long abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, the boss of Bega Cheese, has shared the severe impact it had on her life in a Sydney District Court. Van Ryn has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including the persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim expressed fear for her future relationships and questioned why she was targeted. She revealed that she didn't understand the wrongness of the abuse as a child and only spoke up after learning of Van Ryn's arrest. The victim has since struggled with depression, self-harm, and attempted suicide. She worries about Van Ryn's future release and its potential impact on her relationships with men.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old midfielder for Arsenal, has expressed that he is feeling 'better and better' as he prepares to return after a year-long absence due to a serious knee injury. Gnabry last played for Arsenal in the Champions League last-16 second leg against Bayern Munich in March 2014. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under 21s against Reading, signaling his recovery from the injury that had stunted his progress. Gnabry is optimistic about his return and is looking forward to his next game.

A young accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after falling down a 70ft cliff while attempting to evade a taxi fare. The 23-year-old graduate was out drinking in Cardiff with friends before catching a taxi to Penarth, South Wales. However, they didn't have enough money to pay for the ride. In an attempt to avoid paying, Phillips and his friends ran from the taxi driver, Dave Sidaway. Phillips ran in a different direction from his friends and fell down the cliff at the end of the disused Northern Promenade. His body was discovered the next day by a dog walker. The coroner, Andrew Barkley, recorded a verdict of accidental death, stating that Phillips was likely disoriented and unaware of the danger posed by the cliff.

The passage describes a situation where thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay fiasco have not received any compensation. Despite the chaos, the passport agency made a £42 million profit. Managers received bonuses up to £3,500, while desperate families who paid extra for rushed travel documents or missed trips did not get refunds. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved between April last year and January this year, with a total payout of £203,066. The Passport Office could not provide the number of rejected claims due to a 'system failure of our customer complaint database'. The Home Affairs Committee chairman, Keith Vaz, was 'astonished' at the low number of compensations. Many holidaymakers, including Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham who lost £1,500 on a trip to Morocco, did not receive any money back.

A 1930s semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, is up for sale, featuring original elements such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro food jars. The house, priced between £200,000 and £250,000, boasts the original bathroom and kitchen, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage cupboards. Despite some upgrades like double glazing, the potential cost of renovations might deter developers. The house is set to be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but took over as the 49ers' starting quarterback in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. Kaepernick led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994 but ultimately lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
The 1997 American comedy-drama film, Soul Food, was produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel. It was released under Fox 2000 Pictures.

The passage provides information about two unrelated topics.

Anne Rice, the author, was born in New Orleans and spent her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco.

Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey. It connects the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken. This route provides access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American television network that broadcasts in Spanish. It is owned by Comcast, under the NBCUniversal division known as NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, born and raised in East London and Essex, co-founded Blur with Graham Coxon after meeting at Stanway School. Blur's debut album, Leisure, was released in 1991. Historically, at the beginning of the 20th century, Camden's population was primarily composed of European immigrants. A city is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.

The passage discusses Bret Easton Ellis, who is a writer known for his work on the screenplay for the 2013 film "The Canyons." The film, directed by Paul Schrader, is an original work by Ellis and falls under the genre of erotic thriller-drama. However, it received critical derision upon its release.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates held in Illinois between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate, and Stephen Douglas, the incumbent Democratic Senator. The debates took place in seven different towns across the state.

The passage mentions two significant literary works and their authors. Homer, an ancient Greek poet, is attributed with writing the Iliad and the Odyssey, which are considered the cornerstone works of ancient Greek literature. Separately, The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel penned by American author Joe R. Lansdale.

Christopher Scott Kyle, born on April 8, 1974, was a veteran of the United States Navy SEAL and a sniper. Tragically, he was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh on February 2, 2013, at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece band comprised of Chris Cornell from Soundgarden as the lead singer/rhythm guitarist, and Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk from Rage Against the Machine on lead guitar, bass/backing vocals, and drums respectively. Brad Wilk, known for his drumming in Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07), started his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage with Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991. As of 2016, Wilk is part of Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, consists of Zack de la Rocha as rapper and vocalist, Tim Commerford as bassist and backing vocalist, Tom Morello as guitarist, and Brad Wilk as drummer.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born on December 1, 1985, is an American multi-talented artist who works as a singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. Monáe gained critical acclaim in 2010 with the release of her first full-length studio album, "The ArchAndroid," which is a concept album sequel to her first EP. This album was released by Bad Boy Records.

Winter's Tale, published in 1983, is a novel penned by author Mark Helprin. It is a magical and sprawling story set in a fantastical version of New York City, featuring elements of both realism and the supernatural. The narrative follows the journey of the protagonist, Peter Lake, as he navigates through time and space, encountering a variety of characters and facing numerous challenges. The novel explores themes of love, redemption, and the power of storytelling.

Lake Providence is a town located in East Carroll Parish, northeastern Louisiana, United States. It serves as the parish seat. The passage also mentions the University of Mississippi, where 55% of its undergraduates and 60% of all students are from Mississippi. Additionally, 23% of the students are minorities, and international students come from 90 nations. However, the connection between Lake Providence and the University of Mississippi is not explicitly stated in the passage.
The series "Flaked" was renewed for a second season consisting of six episodes in July 2016. This second season is set to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr had a significant political career, serving two terms in the New York State Assembly (1784-1785, 1798-1799), holding the position of New York State Attorney General (1789-1791), and being elected as a U.S. Senator from New York (1791-1797). His career reached its peak when he became the vice president.

The Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed for the Soviet space program by the Korolyov Design Bureau, now known as RKK Energia, in the 1960s. It was initially built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs and succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft. The Soyuz was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program, starting with 8 unmanned test flights, followed by the first 19 manned launches. The name "Soyuz" translates to "Union," as in "Sovetskiy Soyuz" or "Soviet Union." The Soyuz spacecraft remains in service today.
Steve Ditko, a significant figure, received his training from Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School located in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine, an American rap metal band, broke up in the same year that their fourth studio album, Renegades, was released (2000). This was due to growing tensions and led to lead vocalist Zack de la Rocha quitting and starting a solo career. The remaining members formed the rock supergroup Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007. In the same year, Rage Against the Machine announced a reunion and performed together for the first time in seven years at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or simply SENSEX, is a stock market index comprised of 30 reputable and financially stable companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one such company, listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange as a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, as well as on the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially known as the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is located on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It is the 14th most populous country in the world and the ninth most populous in Asia, with an estimated population of 92.7 million. Vietnam shares its borders with China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, and is surrounded by the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced one of the highest economic growth rates globally, and in 2011, it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Despite its economic progress, Vietnam remains one of the four remaining one-party socialist states that officially espouse communism.
The 2005 American sports drama film, Dreamer, was written and directed by John Gatins, marking his first time as a director.

Bhagat Singh was a renowned Indian socialist revolutionary, known for his charismatic personality. He gained prominence through two significant acts of defiance against British rule in India. Tragically, his life was cut short at the age of 23 when he was executed. His courageous actions and untimely death transformed him into a revered folk hero of the Indian independence movement.

Aparshakti Khurana debuted in Bollywood with the 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," which is about a wrestling competition. The film was directed by Nitesh Tiwari and starred Aamir Khan.

James VI and I (19 June 1566 - 27 March 1625) was the King of Scotland from 24 July 1567 and subsequently became the King of England and Ireland from 24 March 1603 until his death. Despite ruling both Scotland and England, they remained separate sovereign states with distinct parliaments, judiciary, and laws. James was a proponent of unifying the parliaments of England and Scotland. During his reign in England, he encountered numerous challenges with Parliament.
