Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand actress known for her work on stage and screen. She was part of the original cast of the soap opera Shortland Street and gained recognition for her roles in Xena: Warrior Princess, The Cult, and Legend of the Seeker. Cormack has also appeared in films like Separation City and the Australian series Rake. She portrayed Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor and is most recognized for her recent portrayal of Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, a role she held for four years before leaving the show in 2016.

Rob Sheridan is an American professional who was born on October 11, 1979. His career encompasses graphic design, directing, and photography, with his most notable work being associated with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is a renowned actor and comedian who has appeared in several films, including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a comedy film released in 2015, directed by Fred Wolf and co-written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.

Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Reference(s):
Angela Evelyn Bassett ( born August 16 , 1958 ) is an American actress .

The album Artpop received mixed reviews from critics but was a commercial success. It debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, becoming the second consecutive number-one record for Gaga in the US. It sold a total of 757,000 copies and was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, titled Stadium Arcadium. This album marked Frusciante's last contribution to the band as he confirmed his departure from the group in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, a highly influential and controversial figure, served as Prime Minister and implemented policies known as Thatcherism. Despite ongoing debates about Thatcherism, she is often regarded as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan is an American multi-talented individual, excelling as a musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Besides his musical pursuits, he has also made a name for himself in writing. He has contributed weekly columns, discussing a diverse range of topics, for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.

Tom Baker, an English actor, is not only known for his acting roles but also for his work as a narrator. His narration projects span across various mediums, including commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain, and it is the third largest city in the country with around 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative center. The larger metropolitan area of Valencia has a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million people, making it the third largest metropolitan area in Spain. The Valencian Community, also known as the Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain with Valencia as its capital.
Buffy Summers, the main character, was depicted in the film by Kristy Swanson and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The TV series "Make It or Break It" concluded with its third season, which was announced as the final season on April 26, 2012. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a multidisciplinary field within computational linguistics that focuses on developing methodologies and technologies to convert spoken language into text using computers. It combines knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. SR applications include voice user interfaces, such as voice dialing, call routing, and appliance control, as well as search functions, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft control. The growth of SR is evident in the increase of academic publications and the widespread adoption of deep learning methods by industry players like Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC. Many of these companies have revealed that their speech recognition systems are based on deep learning technology.

Richard Alf was an American businessman and former comic book store owner, born on January 26, 1952. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970 and served as its chairman. The event was originally founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention by a group including Alf, Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. It was later known as the San Diego Comic Book Convention. Alf passed away on January 4, 2012.

The passage discusses "Fist of Legend," a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury." The original "Fist of Fury" featured Bruce Lee as the main character. Therefore, a concise summary would be: "Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee."

In the Turkish Open, France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par, followed closely by McIlroy at 15 under par. McIlroy, the world number three, is aiming for his first title since May and has carded a third consecutive 67, including an eagle on the 12th. Despite a few mistakes, McIlroy remains optimistic about his chances of a low round. He is also targeting a third Race to Dubai title, leading England's Danny Willett by 271,214 points. Other notable players include England's Chris Wood and Richard Bland, who are fifth and seventh respectively.

The passage discusses Sheikh Ali Salman's views on the political situation in Bahrain, particularly the need for meaningful national dialogue. He emphasizes the importance of the government showing willingness to offer "concrete solutions" and the need for dialogue with reformists within the Sunni Muslim royal family, such as Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa. Sheikh Salman mentions a seven-point plan agreed upon with the crown prince before the intervention of Gulf Co-operation Council troops, which would have moved Bahrain towards a constitutional monarchy. He expresses hope for US Secretary of State John Kerry's role in pressuring for human rights and democratic practices, and criticizes the UK government's private approach to urging reform. Sheikh Salman also reiterates al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations and calls for the release of imprisoned opposition leaders and human rights activists.

The passage is about the death of Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and early-music movement exponent. He passed away at his home in Cambridge after a long illness. Hogwood was known for his work with numerous orchestras worldwide and his significant contributions to the early-music movement. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and led it for three decades, during which they made over 200 CDs, including a complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was also a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor at the University of Cambridge, and professor-at-large at Cornell University. Tributes from colleagues and fellow musicians highlight his generosity, intelligence, and influence on the music world.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide cases, a decrease from the previous year and the lowest since 1976. The majority of these homicides involved a sharp instrument, with knives being the most common. 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. The Justice Secretary emphasized the need for continued efforts to prevent violent crime and address alcohol misuse. However, the Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman cautioned against over-optimism, citing previous revisions in homicide figures and a rise in sexual and violent crimes.

The Cherries lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking Sunderland's first Premier League win this season. Dan Gosling scored the first goal for the Cherries in three games. Despite creating enough chances to win three games, according to manager Eddie Howe, they were unable to score more than once. Sunderland's goals came from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty. The Cherries were unable to equalize, even after Sunderland's Steven Pienaar was dismissed. Howe emphasized the importance of moving on from the loss.

The passage discusses Australia's policy of detaining migrants arriving by boat and resettling them elsewhere, which has been criticized as "brutal" and "inhumane" by the New York Times. Prime Minister Tony Abbott defends the policy, stating that it is necessary to prevent deaths at sea. Abbott also comments that the Islamic State is worse than the Nazis, sparking criticism from Australian Jewish groups who argue that the two cannot be compared. Abbott later clarifies that he is not in the "business of ranking evil".

The US has suspended talks with Russia regarding the cessation of hostilities in Syria, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks against civilians. The main trauma hospital in rebel-held eastern Aleppo has been hit in an air strike for the third time in a week, and hundreds of people, including children, have died since government forces launched an offensive to take full control of Aleppo. The US accuses Russia and the Syrian regime of targeting critical infrastructure such as hospitals and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching civilians. Russia denies involvement in the deadly aid convoy strike and says the US failed to fulfill the agreement to improve the humanitarian condition around Aleppo. The US also criticized Russia for failing to divide jihadist groups from the moderate opposition. The two sides will continue to talk about counter-terrorism operations in Syria to avoid unnecessary clashes.

The passage discusses a report by think tank Policy Exchange, which proposes selling high-value vacant social homes to fund the construction of new social housing. This move could raise £4.5bn a year, enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 social homes, and create the largest social house building program since the 1970s. The report argues that this would help reduce the number of people waiting for social housing by about 500,000. However, Labour criticizes the proposal, stating that it would displace hard-working families on low wages from neighborhoods. The report suggests that 21.8% of the total social housing stock in the UK, or 816,000 properties, could be sold to raise up to £159bn. Critics argue that this would push the least well-off out of expensive streets and create segregated communities of rich and poor.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old man from Swansea, died last week at his home. Swansea is currently experiencing a measles epidemic with 942 cases reported. Although measles was confirmed to be present in Colfer-Williams, further tests are needed to determine if it was the main cause of his death. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have been hospitalized due to the illness. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash a few days after being discharged from the hospital. His mother reported that he saw an out-of-hours GP on April 17th with a rash covering his body, but not his arms. He was found dead the following morning. Public Health Wales confirmed a diagnosis of measles, but the cause of death is still under investigation. The family is unsure how Colfer-Williams contracted measles as no close family members have it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.

Vincent Hudson, aged 54 and residing on Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offense against a boy under 16 years old. The alleged incident occurred in 2001. Hudson is scheduled to appear before the North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

The match between Neil Aspin's Gateshead and Adam Lockwood's Guiseley ended in a 1-1 draw. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute with a goal by Jake Lawlor, assisted by James Hurst. Gateshead's Wes York scored the equalizer in the 62nd minute after a slip by Derek Asamoah. Both teams had unbeaten streaks coming into the match, with Gateshead not losing in nine National League matches and Guiseley unbeaten in five.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club, intends to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed due to a town green application. The plan was approved by Bristol City Council in November and will commence in May if no judicial review is filed by March. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the club's plans at a shareholder meeting on Tuesday.

Cuadrilla, a company conducting shale gas drilling tests in Lancashire, has suspended operations after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) reported that the tremor was similar to one that occurred on 1 April, both of which were centered near the drilling site. Shale gas drilling, or "fracking," involves fracturing shale rocks to release gas using hydraulic pressure or tiny explosions. The process has been controversial in the US due to environmental concerns, but the UK's Commons energy select committee has called for support of the process, arguing that environmental problems can be overcome with regulation and good industry practice. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution and has stated that any process involving the injection of pressurized water into rocks can cause earthquakes. The latest tremor was felt by at least one person in Poulton-Le-Fylde and was located near the drilling site at a depth of approximately 2km. Cuadrilla is currently examining data collected by the BGS before deciding whether to resume drilling.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud after a two-day trial at Liverpool Crown Court. He was accused of giving the impression he was collecting cash for the Hillsborough Justice Campaign while busking with a banner for the charity draped on his bagpipes in April 2015. Carpenter, who has played in the city centre for more than 30 years, denied the charges and claimed he was simply busking and not collecting funds for the charity. He was cleared of two other counts of fraud by a jury. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

In the Championship game between Ipswich Town and Queens Park Rangers, Ipswich won 3-0. Grant Ward scored the first goal for Ipswich, followed by Luke Varney's goal after QPR keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance. Tom Lawrence scored the third goal for Ipswich. QPR offered little in attack, with their only significant chance coming late in the game when sub Sandro headed Tjarron Cherry's corner against the post. Ipswich had struggled to score in previous games but dominated this match, with Christophe Berra and Cole Skuse coming close to scoring more goals. The win lifted Ipswich up to 14th place in the Championship, while QPR slipped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance, while QPR boss Ian Holloway criticized his team's lack of mental toughness and solidity.

The passage discusses a 23-year-old individual named Wells who performed well in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66. Wells expresses enthusiasm for the club's direction and the elite performance environment created by the coaches, which motivates the team members.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. The team's strong performance was led by Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams. Churcher highlighted the front row and front five's impressive 70-plus tackles in the game. The Reds will face seven teams below them in the table in their upcoming eight games, along with league leaders Old Elthamians. Despite the win, Churcher believes there is room for improvement and emphasized the need to build on their recent performance.

The police have arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, who is accused of raping a 74-year-old nun. Nazrul, allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, was apprehended at a railway station in Kolkata. This marks the sixth arrest in the case, with police identifying eight suspects, two of whom remain untraced. All five previously arrested suspects have named Nazrul as the perpetrator. The arrest was made based on a tip-off that Nazu had returned to Kolkata by train after fleeing to Bangladesh. The incident, which involved the theft of money from the convent school, its ransacking, and the rape of the nun, occurred in Ranaghat town on 14 March and sparked widespread outrage and protests across India.

The passage discusses an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, the founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London. In the video, Opie explains the primary reasons for changes in consumer buying habits, citing the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports as significant factors influencing product availability and popularity among UK consumers. The interactive elements of the video also delve into the evolving ownership and ranking of major UK brands. The video is recommended to be viewed in full screen and offers links to additional non-interactive information. The topics covered in these links include Chinese-owned entities, food freezing tips from BBC Good Food, an annual survey ranking the top 20 consumer brands in the UK, and information about the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising.

In the given passage, two incidents of fraud are reported. In the first incident, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was deceived by someone posing as a BT employee. In the second incident, a woman in Stranraer lost money to a caller who claimed to be from BT technical support and gained remote access to her computer. These incidents occurred on 15th September and 22nd September respectively. Police Constable Siobhan Pellett warned about the ease with which these fraudsters gain access to victims' computers and urged people to be cautious when receiving cold calls. She emphasized that banks, building societies, and reputable businesses never ask for banking details or account numbers over the telephone.

Duffy, aged 37, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone Rovers, the third-ranked team in the Championship, following his departure from Swinton Lions. He will make his debut as head coach in the team's final league game against Toulouse and continue through the Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy, who has previously coached Scotland and played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has been praised for his work at Swinton under challenging conditions. His former assistant Stuart Littler will take over his position at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, along with a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The individual involved, a rider, had sustained head injuries and was unconscious on wet sand, causing them to be very cold. The rider was treated at the scene before being airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales for further medical attention.

In a UN conference held in Geneva on Wednesday, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to allocate a radio frequency for satellite tracking of planes, aiming to improve the current tracking system that relies on ground-based radars. This decision was influenced by the disappearance of flight MH370 in March 2014, which exposed weaknesses in global air navigation systems. The new system will enable satellites to receive transmissions from aircraft, allowing real-time tracking of planes anywhere in the world. The UN's aviation arm, ICAO, has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, which will include aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in case of emergency.

Julian Hernandez, who went missing at the age of five, has been found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Julian is now 18 years old. Bobby Hernandez, aged 53, has been arrested and is currently being held at a jail in Ohio. The FBI received a tip about Julian's possible whereabouts after he encountered issues while applying for college. The FBI collaborated with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to verify Julian's identity. His mother has been informed about his recovery. Bobby Hernandez is also facing charges for tampering with records in Ohio to obtain a driver's license in 2012. He is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio on a $250,000 bail. It was suspected that Bobby Hernandez was involved in his son's disappearance back in 2002, when he reportedly took Julian to pre-school but then fled.

Firefighters battled a blaze at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's site in Duncan Street on 2 March, causing travel disruptions and service reductions. The Environment Agency suspended the firm from accepting waste due to the fire. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had visited the premises nine times in the past year and found the operators, Asset and Land, to be "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws. However, the fire service raised concerns about the potential impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The Environment Agency revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, after which the company will no longer be able to operate at the site and must remove all waste. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills in response to the situation in Ukraine, particularly in the Crimea region where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong. The first bill suggests that a referendum or a plea from a territory's leaders could trigger provisions for a territory to become a new "subject" of the Russian Federation. The second bill aims to expedite the process of issuing Russian passports, waiving fees, previous residence requirements, and the need for sufficient funds or renunciation of Ukrainian citizenship. This bill is intended to support Russian-speaking Ukrainians who are seen as defenseless against a perceived "brown threat," a reference to World War Two fascists. The fast-track procedure for Russian passports was announced in Sevastopol and several Russian MPs, including celebrities, have visited Crimea.

The McLaren F1 team, with a rich history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently struggling. Despite having two world champions in their lineup, including Fernando Alonso, they are facing a slump due to issues with their Honda power-unit. This is a stark contrast to their previous successes, such as dominating the 1988 season with 15 wins out of 16 races. The team's history has been a cycle of triumph and decline, with their first decade focused on building up the team, followed by periods of domination and decline. Ron Dennis, who has been a key figure in the team's history, insists that success will return, and that McLaren will be the next team to win the title after Mercedes. However, their current situation is challenging, with their success resting on the progress of their car and the improvement of their Honda engine.

Thomas Baker, also known as Tommy, was fatally shot in the head and chest outside the Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on January 27. The 44-year-old from Everton was attacked while getting into his car shortly after leaving the Phoenix Gym at the market. Three men from Liverpool, aged 29 and 32, have been arrested and remain in police custody for questioning. Detectives believe the perpetrators had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour before the shooting. Merseyside Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene and traveled along several roads, including Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. Detective Chief Inspector Bev Hyland appealed to several individuals captured on CCTV near the meat market who have yet to come forward, as they may hold key information for the investigation.

The passage discusses five ways to celebrate Christmas online, focusing on virtual church services, a Bible-themed fantasy game, nativity videos, and Manga versions of biblical stories. Everyday Church Online offers virtual services with a global congregation, while Guardians of Ancora is a game aimed at 8-11-year-olds that teaches Bible stories. Popular nativity videos include "The Digital Story of Nativity" and "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle." Manga Messiah is a Manga version of the nativity story available in 33 languages. Social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram are also used by religious groups to connect with their communities during the holiday season.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a request to acquire 250 hectares of common land, with backers offering around 320 hectares of replacement land. The inquiry has received conflicting expert opinions on the potential damage to habitats and plant life due to the development. Natural Resources Wales expressed difficulty in determining the equal value of the replacement land but is not opposing the development overall. An ecology report by the developers claims a "net gain" in biodiversity, which is disputed by the Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, and Welsh government ministers will have the final say on the plans.

The passage describes a situation in Chechnya where over 100 people have been detained on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three reportedly killed. The detainees, including some influential Muslim clerics and TV presenters, were allegedly tortured with electric shocks and beatings. The detentions and killings have been linked to widespread homophobia in the mainly Muslim North Caucasus republic. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov has denied the allegations, with his spokesman claiming there are no gay people in Chechnya. The detentions have been condemned by the Russian LGBT Network and Novaya Gazeta, a newspaper that first reported the story. Chechen clerics have responded by saying the report insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men, and have called for retribution against the instigators. The situation has been compared to previous murders of Novaya Gazeta reporters who investigated crimes in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is helping people flee the persecution and has threatened to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute anyone.

Investing Solutions, a letting agent, has received substantial benefit payments over the past two years by housing single homeless men, primarily aged 35 and over. The company operates in seven London boroughs and is one of the largest recipients of housing benefits in the UK. The company profits by charging housing benefits for each individual housed in a property, rather than the property itself, leading to higher total benefit payouts than the rent passed on to the landlord. Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing, a charity that refers clients to the company, are both based in the same building and were founded by Samir Patel. While neither organization acts illegally, homeless groups have criticized their relationship as exploitative. Tenants have reported issues with the properties, including lack of heating and hot water, rats, and damp. Despite these concerns, local authorities are responsible for ensuring taxpayers' money is safeguarded in private sector housing.

In a well-contested game, the British basketball team, coached by Joe Prunty, led for most of the first three quarters before being overtaken by the Netherlands in the last 10 minutes. The team was led by London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence with 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon with 13 points. Despite a strong start and a comeback in the last six minutes, the British team lost 71-60. Prunty was pleased with Gordon's performance, who joined the team despite missing out on the London 2012 Olympics. The team will now begin their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary. Prunty emphasized the importance of completing every play and maintaining intensity on both ends of the floor during the qualifiers.

The passage discusses a waiver submitted by former five-weight world champion Conor McGregor to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for using 8oz gloves instead of the standard 10oz gloves for his upcoming boxing debut against Floyd Mayweather. The NAC will debate this matter on 16 August, as lighter gloves offer less cushioning and could potentially lead to more punishing punches. McGregor, who has used 4oz gloves in his UFC career, will face criticism from boxing personalities for his move from the octagon to the ring. However, NAC executive director Bob Bennett has studied McGregor's abilities and believes there are several reasons to approve the fight, including McGregor's knockdowns of Nate Diaz, his granite-like chin, and his age and size advantage over Mayweather. Despite not having knocked anyone out in 10 years, Mayweather has expressed his intention to wear 8oz gloves for the bout.

The passage describes the closure of the Dundee-based Sunday Post's London office on Fleet Street, marking the end of an era for British journalism. Fleet Street was once synonymous with the nation's biggest newspapers and was considered the pinnacle of a journalist's career. The first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published in Fleet Street on 11 March 1702. The street was famous for its many bars and pubs, constantly occupied by journalists both socializing and seeking stories. The passage mentions two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for the Sunday Post and were based in Fleet Street for many years. They share their memories of the street in its heyday, describing the atmosphere as one of constant activity and camaraderie. However, the departure of the last two journalists from Fleet Street marks the end of an era, as most national newspapers have moved away from the street to other parts of London, adopting new computerized printing technology. The buildings they left behind have gradually morphed into other uses, such as the headquarters of Sainsbury's supermarkets and a Pizza Express. The passage also mentions the role of media tycoon Rupert Murdoch in moving his papers off to a purpose-built complex at Wapping in east London in 1986, which led to a bitter, year-long dispute that ended in defeat for the unions. Despite the end of this infamous era of British history, the journalists who worked on Fleet Street still feel a sense of excitement and pride in their place in history.

J.K. Rowling, the Harry Potter author, expressed her appreciation for the decent people on Twitter after facing abusive comments. She had previously tweeted that her personal line had been crossed by some comments. Rowling had faced criticism last year for donating £1m to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum and had been called a traitor for her political views. She revealed she had blocked some abusive Twitter users she believed had been supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). However, she also mentioned she had responded to other really nice SNP supporters and had discussed their political commonalities. The SNP took 56 of the 59 seats in Scotland in Thursday's election and is now the third largest party in the UK.

The study conducted by the University of Edinburgh researchers found that children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action than better-off children for the same crime. Poverty increased the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. The strongest predictor of a young person not being in education, employment, or training by age 18 was a history of being in trouble with the police. Poorer young people were five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their better-off counterparts. Household poverty was identified as a factor that increased the likelihood of young people offending. People who lived in extreme poverty were more likely to be victims and perpetrators of crime. Boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, and girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely as girls from more affluent households to be involved in violent crime. The study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 and was funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, the Nuffield Foundation, and the Scottish government. The Scottish government spokesman stated that Scotland is becoming a safer place to live with recorded crime at a 41-year low and homicide figures at their lowest level in 39 years. However, the study suggests that crime tends to be highly concentrated amongst poor people and within poor neighborhoods, and this has not changed despite crime being at its lowest level for decades.

In the early hours of Sunday, 25-year-old Karl Haugh was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate. Robbie Walsh, along with two other men, was accused of assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh. The two other men were released without charge, while Walsh was remanded in custody to reappear in court next week. It is alleged that Walsh and the two men entered the Marian Estate looking for Mr Haugh, leading to a fight involving weapons. Mr Haugh received a fatal stab wound to his back. Police recovered knives and golf clubs from the scene, including a knife handle and a blood-stained blade. The incident has caused tension in the Kilkee area.

In May 2014, Phil Flanagan, a Fermanagh MLA from Sinn Féin, tweeted a comment about Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, suggesting he had harassed and shot people. The tweet was deleted within an hour after being alerted by victims campaigner Ann Travers and DUP assembly member Arlene Foster. In a High Court hearing, it was ruled that the tweet was untrue and without foundation. Flanagan was ordered to apologize on Twitter and the court reserved judgement on the amount of compensation. The insurance firm indemnifying MLAs at Stormont refused to cover Flanagan in this case, leading to a separate court action. Elliott expressed disappointment in the length of the process but was ultimately satisfied with the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, a company with over 230 employees and a history dating back to 1874, has increased its sweater production due to high demand. This surge in demand is attributed to the successful launch of their own branded range in January and growth in their private label business. The company sells its products in various European countries such as Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain, as well as in markets outside Europe including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. They have increased their weekly production from 7,500 to 9,500 sweaters. The managing director, Benny Hartop, credits this success to the dedicated staff and anticipates continued growth in the future.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot recall the color of the traffic lights. He denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn, a mother of three and a lollipop lady for 20 years, is now receiving treatment in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

The passage describes a NATO exercise aimed at improving anti-submarine warfare capabilities, with a focus on the German U-boat U33 acting as the enemy submarine. The exercise is a response to growing concerns about Russian submarine activity, as Russia has been investing heavily in its military strength, including its submarine fleet. The task of locating a submarine under vast stretches of ocean is likened to finding a needle in a haystack. The exercise involves warships, anti-submarine warfare helicopters, and for the first time, underwater unmanned vehicles or drones. The lack of any UK maritime patrol aircraft is highlighted as a significant gap in Britain's defences, making it difficult for the UK to conduct anti-submarine warfare alone. The exercise serves as a reminder that NATO needs to be ready for potential threats from Russian submarines.

The passage discusses the escalating crisis in South Sudan, where ethnic violence has led to a mass exodus of refugees into neighboring Uganda. Since July, 340,000 people have fled the violence, with an average of 2,500 South Sudanese becoming refugees each day. The violence, characterized by killing, rape, and targeting of civilians along ethnic lines, has been primarily perpetrated by the Dinka tribe against the Equatorians and Nuer. The civil war began as a dispute between Dinka President Salva Kiir and former Vice-President Riek Machar, who is Nuer. The violence spread to the Equatoria states in July after rebel troops fled the capital. Uganda has been coping well with the influx of refugees, providing them with land and resources to start planting crops. However, the country is beginning to struggle with its generous approach as it now hosts nearly a million refugees. The international community is urged to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the massacre of civilians.

McKenzie, aged 38 and with a professional boxing record of eight wins and one draw, is set to fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship on 12 November at York Hall. McKenzie transitioned to boxing in 2013 after leaving football, having previously played for Norwich and Peterborough. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, a former three-time world champion.

The Bridgwater Community Hospital is set to be replaced with a new facility, funded by a £330m investment for new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is deemed outdated and cramped. The total cost of the project is £33m, with the remaining balance paid for by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital is planned to be built on land at Bowers Lane, subject to planning permission, and is expected to be completed by autumn 2014. The project is part of a larger initiative to modernize healthcare facilities in Somerset, with three out of 13 community hospitals already replaced in the past five years.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre. He was either in or near a black Mercedes car when the incident occurred. The victim was taken to Northern General hospital but succumbed to his injuries. Local residents identified him as a member of a family living close to the scene, who were gathered for a celebration when the attack happened. Many came out to help after hearing the shot. This is one of several recent shootings in Sheffield, with previous incidents occurring in the north of the city, not near Upperthorpe. These include a 25-year-old man being seriously injured in Shiregreen, shots fired through an elderly couple's window in Southey Green, and shots fired at houses in High Green.

The passage discusses the activities of various hacker groups involved in the Ukrainian conflict. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are the most prominent pro-Ukrainian hackers. They have hacked into Russian interior ministry servers, email accounts, and electronic payment systems. They also use DDoS attacks to disrupt separatist websites and monitor CCTV systems in rebel-held areas. Cyber Berkut, a staunchly anti-Western group, is on the other side of the conflict. They have hacked Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and claim to have disrupted electronic vote-counting systems. They also claim to have leaked Ukrainian defense ministry data and blocked President Poroshenko's website. Russian activist group Anonymous International focuses on Russia's domestic affairs but has also published leaked documents related to Ukraine. The authenticity of some of their leaks has been questioned.

The passage describes the farewell speeches of several MSPs, including Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Annabel Goldie, who are leaving their positions ahead of the election on May 5th. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional during these speeches. Alex Salmond, former first minister and SNP leader, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the need for the parliament to assume greater responsibility for the country's governance. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling the promises made during the referendum campaign. Duncan McNeil warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system and accountability. Annabel Goldie humorously mentioned her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is launching an investigation into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners, their families, care providers, and public bodies to develop recommendations for improving care. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While Rochira aims to highlight good care practices, she also intends to expose the impact of poor care on older people. Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the review's goals but expresses disappointment that no care provider expert is included in the main advisory panel.

In the year leading to June 2016, Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group experienced an increase in pre-tax profit by £800,000, reaching £3.5m, despite a £1m decrease in turnover to just over £100m. The company reported growth in international sales, both in Europe and in new markets abroad. Harbro manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store brand shops across Scotland, catering to farming and rural communities with a diverse range of products. The company acknowledged the unpredictability of the agricultural outlook and the challenging times faced in the past 12-18 months but expressed confidence in the industry's resilience. The impact of Brexit remains to be fully understood, but Harbro Group is optimistic about its ability to handle any resulting business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead in a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. Another man in his 80s was taken to the hospital. Police are looking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the murder. He is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair, and of average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a checked short-sleeved shirt. Police have warned people not to approach him and have urged anyone with information to contact them. Additional patrols are being conducted in the area for residents' reassurance.

The passage discusses a speech given by David Lipton, the second in command at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), at the National Association for Business Economics in Washington on Tuesday. Lipton highlighted the weakening global economy, stating that the IMF's latest assessment shows a declining baseline. He described the current situation as a "delicate juncture." This statement follows the release of China's trade figures, which showed a significant drop in exports by a quarter compared to the previous year. The IMF anticipates downgrading its current global growth forecast of 3.4% in its next economic predictions release in April. The slowing global economy, particularly in China, has ongoing implications for businesses and industries that have relied on China's growth.

The passage discusses the issues surrounding a new vessel at the Cowes crossing, which has faced multiple problems since its launch on 14 May. These issues include breakdowns, running aground, suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues, and damage to cars. Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing would be free until 2 July and a review of the project would be conducted by auditors. Local businesses, such as shopkeeper Angie Booth's Valu-4-U, have been negatively impacted by the vessel's problems. The question of compensating local businesses is under discussion. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the issues but stated that they were teething problems expected with a prototype. He mentioned that electrical problems had been rectified and ramp extensions were being manufactured to prevent vehicle damage. He also stated that the grounding issues were related to seamanship and had been resolved.

A fatal crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. The incident involved several vehicles and resulted in the death of a 32-year-old man at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until the evening for investigation purposes.

The passage discusses Matching Models, a London-based international temp agency that advertised for a personal assistant with specific physical attributes, including "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup". This advertisement was criticized by the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) as "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women". Employment lawyer James Lynas stated that the advert was "clearly unlawful" and could be considered discriminatory against older women. Matching Models' founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the agency's hiring practices, stating that looks are important to their clients. However, EHRC's chief executive Rebecca Hilsenrath emphasized that first impressions should not be based on hair color and urged Matching Models to act like a 21st-century business. The agency's clients include MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, the Renault Formula 1 team, and Harrods.

The incident took place at a hostel connected to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where an office assistant named Mahesh allegedly shot two students, Gautami and Sirisha. Gautami was fatally shot in the head, while Sirisha sustained severe injuries but is expected to recover. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April. Despite India's strict gun control laws, gun violence in schools is rare, with the last known incident occurring in 2007 near Delhi. The motive behind the shooting remains unclear.

The advocacy group Glaad found that between June 2016 and May 2017, there were 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters in shows. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16. However, Glaad expressed concern over the deaths of more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters. The report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's study was based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series. Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis acknowledged the progress but emphasized that numbers only tell part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has decided not to stand for re-election following criticism over a loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council, when he was the council leader. The loan, amounting to £10.25m, was intended for the rebuilding of Sixfields stadium and development of nearby land, but the money is now missing and subject to a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. Despite initially intending to stand for re-election, Mackintosh announced his decision ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. He has denied any wrongdoing.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, fatally shot 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in April, firing into a car full of teenagers as they were leaving a party in Balch Springs, a Dallas suburb. Initially, police claimed the car was reversing aggressively towards the officer, but this was discredited by footage showing the car driving away. Oliver was fired for policy violations and charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official. If convicted, he could face 5 to 99 years in prison, which would make him the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas county since 1973. The trial date has not been set and Oliver is currently free on bail.

The passage discusses the decision of the then president-elect's wife, Melania Trump, to delay her move to the White House until her son Barron finishes his school year. This decision has sparked mixed reactions, with some criticizing it and others supporting it. Historically, only two other First Ladies have not moved into the White House during their husbands' presidencies. The passage also mentions that Melania Trump has indicated Barron will be her top priority, suggesting she may not take on the full-time role of her predecessors. The role of the First Lady is officially ceremonial, but in recent times, they have also supported and promoted various causes. The passage ends by discussing how past presidents' families have adapted to life in the White House, with some maintaining a sense of normalcy.

A 72-year-old man was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been tasked with investigating the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland has stated that it is cooperating fully with the investigation and awaits the findings. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) has instructed Pirc to conduct this investigation, and Pirc will submit a report on its findings to the COPFS in due course.

The passage describes a yellow warning of wind issued by a meteorological agency, predicting gusts up to 75mph (120kmph) in certain areas, particularly to the west of the mountains. The unusual easterly direction of the wind could exacerbate its impact. Disruption to travel on roads and at sea is expected. The affected counties are Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. Overnight gusts have already caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, leading to the closure of Telford Road, a main route into the town. The road is expected to remain closed for most of Monday for clean-up work.

In the game, the Giants took an early lead through Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. The second period saw Mike Forney score a powerplay breakaway goal to make it 2-1, only for Andy Bohmback to tie the game again. Mike Radja then scored from an acute angle and James Desmarais extended the lead to 4-2, before Nottingham's David Ling scored one back. The teams will meet again on Saturday night. Nottingham currently leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

The Chinese Grand Prix was marked by several incidents, including a collision between Ferrari teammates Sebastian Vettel and Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. Despite the damage, Vettel finished second and Raikkonen fifth. World champion Lewis Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing, and made five pit stops, finishing seventh. Hamilton now faces a 36-point deficit to Mercedes teammate Nico Rosberg, who won the race. The race was also marked by a confrontation between Vettel and Red Bull's Daniil Kvyat, who collided on the first lap. Hamilton and Raikkonen also had to pit early to replace damaged front wings. The race was shaped by an incident-packed opening, with a number of collisions on the first lap leading to the introduction of the safety car on lap four. Hamilton and Raikkonen had already pitted once to replace front wings damaged in first-corner collisions. Hamilton's progress was affected by damage to the car in the incident with Felipe Nasr. Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff said the front wing had damaged the leading edge of the floor and the barge boards when it came off and that the car had lost a "lot of aerodynamic performance". After a further switch to the medium compound tyres to last the race, Hamilton was not able to recover as much ground as the Ferraris and faces an uphill battle if he is to stop Rosberg winning his first world title this year.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, aiming to advance the discussion on a topic largely ignored in German football. His announcement was met with widespread support from teammates, football administration figures, and the public. Hitzlsperger's decision is considered a significant step in the fight against homophobia in football, as Germany, like England, has struggled with this issue. The last German footballer to come out was second-tier player Marcus Urban in 2007. Hitzlsperger's announcement is seen as a watershed moment, with hopes that it will encourage others to be open about their sexuality and contribute to breaking down the taboo surrounding homosexuality in football.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played a significant role in Brighton's promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years, making 32 Championship appearances this season. His contract is set to expire, and he is eager to sign a new deal to remain part of the team. Brighton is currently leading the Championship, with a four-point advantage over Newcastle, and aims to secure the league title in the final two matches. Sidwell has previous Premier League experience with several clubs and believes he deserves another chance to play at the top level. He feels he has exceeded expectations in his performances and hopes to negotiate a new contract.

In this football match between Blackpool and Colchester United, the Seasiders took the lead in the 12th minute with a goal by Jamille Matt from three yards. Colchester equalized from a corner after 17 minutes through Kurtis Guthrie. Both teams had chances to take the lead, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred missing from eight yards and Colchester's George Elokobi and Guthrie being denied by goalkeeper Sam Slocombe. The match ended 1-1, with Colchester finishing with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The 29-year-old player, who had previous stints with Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season. Despite his efforts, the team was relegated from League One. He has now joined the U's and could debut in the EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa. Colchester began the season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is raising £1.5m for a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire, dedicated to police officers who have lost their lives in the line of duty over the past 250 years. The memorial, expected to be completed by 2019, will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff. The death of PC Keith Palmer in an attack outside the Houses of Parliament in March prompted the greater emphasis on the need for this memorial. The memorial will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to the families of fallen officers as a personal memorial. The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the memorial.

Manchester United secured a 1-0 win at Sunderland, maintaining a 15-point lead at the top of the table with eight games remaining. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on their upcoming matches, including the derby against Manchester City. United has won 50 out of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games and aims to surpass Chelsea's record 95-point haul in 2005. Ferguson plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries sustained by Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea. Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley were not started in the Sunderland match, but Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez will be available for the Chelsea game. Ferguson praised his team's determined defending and courage in the face of a strong second-half performance from Sunderland.

Google's chairman, Mr. Schmidt, stated that the company paid what was "legally required" in taxes, which amounted to £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. He suggested that it was up to the government to change its tax system if it wanted companies to pay more taxes. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge, the head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms. Google, along with other multinationals, has been criticized for minimizing their UK tax payments by routing sales through Ireland. European Union leaders recently agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities." Mr. Schmidt has previously argued for corporate taxes to be levied in the country where the economic activity and risks occur, rather than where products are consumed, and has called for a debate on international tax reform.

The NHS regulator, NHS Improvement, aims to reduce the agency staff bill from £3.6bn to £2.6bn by the end of the financial year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m so far. The cap limits payments to 55% above normal shift rates for all staff except senior managers. The goal is to decrease overall agency staff costs and reduce reliance on them. Despite progress, the NHS is still short of its target, with trusts being 10% down on their goal. The agency bill is decreasing, but it's unclear if spending on other pay bill areas has risen. The figures do not include NHS "bank" staff or overtime costs. NHS Improvement will publish league tables on trusts' agency spending and collect data on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust due to suspicions of high earnings. Examples of hospitals being quoted double the rates for doctors have been found. NHS Improvement chief executive Jim Mackey emphasized the need to further reduce agency staff expenses.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a thriving commercial hub, now stands as a symbol of Ireland's economic downturn post the Celtic Tiger era. However, local traders like Matt O'Brien, who runs a men's clothing shop, have noticed a recent uptick in business. Despite this, they believe more can be done to stimulate local commerce, such as improving broadband infrastructure and removing parking charges. The main opposition party, Fianna Fáil, criticizes the government's investment in water meters, suggesting the funds would be better spent on broadband improvement. The government, however, highlights its efforts to boost the economy, such as the proposed Center Parcs tourism development in County Longford, which could employ around 1,000 people. Despite these signs of recovery, the midlands still seek more targeted efforts to bolster their economy.

The passage describes a cricket tournament that concludes on 29 May in the same stadium. Eight teams are participating, playing against each other twice, with the top four teams qualifying for play-offs. The tournament's leading run-scorers are Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249), while Warner and De Villiers have hit the most sixes (12). De Kock scored the highest individual innings (108). McClenaghan leads with the most wickets (9). Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The passage also lists the fixtures and results of the tournament.

In summary, the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, causing environmental issues due to their non-recyclable nature and improper disposal. To address this, England will implement a 5p charge for plastic bags from October, aiming to promote reuse and reduce waste. This strategy has proven successful in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where similar charges have led to decreased bag usage. Environmental campaigners hope this charge will also decrease bag waste in England.

The passage describes a windy day in Wales that caused disruptions and damages. A school roof was ripped off in Rhosgadfan, and hundreds of homes experienced power cuts. Train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges were also reported. The disruptions followed a yellow 'be aware' warning for wind across Wales. The highest gusts of wind were recorded on Friday afternoon at Mona on Anglesey. Irish Ferries cancelled six of its fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin due to adverse weather conditions. Arriva Trains Wales warned of possible delays for all services between Llandudno Junction to Holyhead. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to the expected high winds. Winds eased into Friday evening, with earlier restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge lifted. However, a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend has led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip in the sea.

Michael B. Jordan expressed his excitement for an upcoming film, in which he will reunite with his Creed director Ryan Coogler. He did not reveal his role but mentioned looking forward to working with Lupita Nyong'o, who won an Oscar for 12 Years a Slave, and Chadwick Boseman, who plays Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in Fantastic Four, while Nyong'o played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The film, Black Panther, is set to release in February 2018.

The historic theatre at Alexandra Palace, built in 1875, is planned to be revived for various performances, including theatre, cinema, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios, located at the eastern end of the Palace, will also undergo repairs and refurbishments. The goal is to reopen the theatre in 2018, subject to successful fundraising. This theatre and studios restoration is part of a larger project to transform the east wing of Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. The glazed east court will be repurposed for public use and exhibitions. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8m, while Haringey Council is providing £6.8m towards the project. The total cost for refurbishing the entire east wing is £26.6m, with the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust committed to raising the remaining £1m by summer 2017. Despite being unused for decades, the theatre retains much of its original decor and stage machinery, having been originally designed for opera, musicals, plays, and various forms of entertainment, including early cinema screenings.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from the England national team. He earned 61 caps since his senior debut in 2009 and was part of two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, starting in 2004. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

In Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, Marcy Smith and her family's house was consumed by a fire that started from burning rubbish in the wood stove. Her son David woke her up in time to escape, but their pets did not survive. The fire spread rapidly, and the fire alarm did not activate. The family fled with only their pyjamas, but the community has since provided them with clothing, shoes, and even a bike for David. Marcy expressed her immense pride in David, acknowledging that his actions saved their lives.

The energy drinks giant is contemplating a £200m bid for the Premier League club, West Ham. The club was bought by Sullivan and Gold in 2010 for £105m, and they now own over 85% of the club. Since West Ham's move to London Stadium in August, there have been rumors of takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Last year, Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to pay off debts but emphasized that he and Gold plan to pass ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards took place in Los Angeles, with The Fault in Our Stars winning best movie and its star Shailene Woodley winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Other winners included Bradley Cooper for best male performance in American Sniper, Channing Tatum for best comedic performance in 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep for best villain in Into the Woods. Kevin Hart won the comedic genius award and brought his kids on stage. Robert Downey Jr. won the Generation Award and was presented with it by his Avengers co-stars. Clips from upcoming movies were also shown.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 player, was loaned to United by the Dons in July and has scored five goals this season. He debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, praised the acquisition as brilliant and highlighted Smith's maturity and value as an attacking option. St Mirren, currently bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

In the passage, Northumberland County Council announced that their Jetpatcher machines will start repairing potholes due to the warmer weather. They aim to fix 145 potholes daily for the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to repair damaged drainage systems caused by heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

The incident occurred in December 2016 on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland. Six workers, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while performing shutdown work with pipe equipment. The workers were not wearing the proper personal protective equipment (PPE) at the time of exposure. Although the level of exposure was less than 1% of the reportable limit to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), EnQuest reported the incident and took additional precautionary steps to prevent future exposure. The workers, who are concerned about potential long-term health effects, have undergone medical assessments and continue to receive support from their employer, Wood Group. The incident has raised concerns about transparency and safety in the offshore industry.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The artwork is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The decision to return the sculpture to India came after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). Although there is no conclusive proof of theft, the museum took note of the art dealer's manager's confession to dealing in looted Indian antiquities. The ACM plans to take legal action for compensation due to the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. The tremor was felt in various cities, including Milan and Florence, but no immediate injuries or damage were reported. The quake was followed by several aftershocks, causing phone lines and power supplies to be cut in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution. Italy is prone to earthquakes, with a deadly quake in L'Aquila in 2009 resulting in almost 300 deaths. In October 2012, six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of multiple manslaughter for providing false reassurance before the L'Aquila quake. The latest tremor was described as a classic earthquake for the area, being medium-strong and fairly shallow.

In the given passage, Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, has successfully grown a fruit plant despite his initial doubts about South Yorkshire's climate. The fruit is still unripe and attached to the plant. Grant expressed his joy upon seeing the results of his efforts.

The game 'Grand Theft Auto V' by Rockstar, originally scheduled for release on 27 January, has been delayed until 24 March for additional testing and polishing. Rockstar assures fans that this decision is in the best interest of the game's quality. As a consolation, online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release, and screenshots of the PC version showcasing enhanced detail have been released. The PC version will support up to 4K resolution and triple monitor configurations. Minimum specifications for running the game on PC have been published. 'Grand Theft Auto V' holds the record for the fastest-selling entertainment product, generating $1bn in revenue within three days of its initial release on 17 September 2013.

The 76-year-old artist, who has been previously shortlisted and longlisted for the John Moores Painting Prize, won the £25,000 award for his painting Squint (19). The painting, which depicts a leper squint, was praised by judge Ansel Krut as "quite extraordinary" and "a little bit like a tone poem". The artist plans to use the prize money to buy materials for his work. The John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain's oldest art awards, established in 1957, and has been previously won by artists such as David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The pro-government Turkish newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked by masked assailants, resulting in no casualties. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously at both offices, located 20km apart, early on Thursday. The buildings' windows were shattered by gunfire, and numerous spent bullet casings were found at both scenes. Police have cordoned off the area and are currently searching for the assailants, with no group claiming responsibility yet. Last September, pro-government protesters attacked the offices of the daily Hurriyet.

The 24-year-old player, previously contracted with the Stags and recently on loan at Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, will officially join the Mariners on 1 January. Marcus Bignot's side has reached an agreement to bring him in on a free transfer, making him Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

The passage discusses Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger's views on Gareth Southgate's interim role as England's football coach and the speculation surrounding Hector Bellerin's future at Arsenal. Wenger praises Southgate's experience and observational skills, while stating that he is focused on his own job. Southgate has two upcoming matches to prove his competency for the permanent role. Wenger also addresses the speculation surrounding Bellerin's potential move to Barcelona or Manchester City, stating that Bellerin will be offered a new contract and his long-term future is at Arsenal. Lastly, Wenger mentions that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in August.

A local man, employed at Fruehauf on Houghton Road, is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police, in collaboration with the Health and Safety Executive, are conducting a joint investigation into the incident. The company, Fruehauf, is reportedly cooperating fully with the investigation.

In summary, Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay. The RMT union had alleged that some workers on two freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will bring contracted out services back to operator Serco Northlink from next month. The freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay are currently operated by Seatruck, which is contracted to run the service by Serco Northlink. Seatruck had argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck did not accept. The new arrangements will be implemented early next month, subject to finalizing financial and regulatory details. Mr. Yousaf expressed his pleasure at the agreement in principle to end this long-running issue and confirmed that all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage going forward. Serco Northlink was awarded the six-year £243m Northern Isles contract in 2012 and operates three ferries and two cargo boats to the Northern Isles on a route heavily subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, aged 64, passed away in the hospital on May 14, six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, aged 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, aged 57. The couple had been in a relationship for several years and were experiencing a rough patch. On May 7, Jamie Mitchell visited his mother at the park and the three of them went to the holiday park bar, where Jamie got heavily intoxicated. A confrontation occurred between Jamie Mitchell and Mr. Dickie outside, which was broken up by bystanders. Jamie Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault in relation to the fight. Both Jamie and Samantha Mitchell admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events, initially claiming that Mr. Dickie had pushed Samantha and she had pushed him back. However, Jamie later confessed that he had tried to separate the couple, resulting in what he called a "tragic accident". The pair will be sentenced on February 6.

Rod Temperton, a renowned songwriter, passed away in London at the age of 66 following a short battle with cancer. He was known for writing hits such as Off The Wall and Baby Be Mine for Michael Jackson, and Boogie Nights for his band Heatwave. Tributes were paid by various artists and industry figures, including Chic guitarist Nile Rodgers and Michael Jackson's sister LaToya. Temperton, nicknamed The Invisible Man due to his low profile, traced his songwriting ability back to his father's influence. He started his career in the 1970s with disco group Heatwave, penning hits like Boogie Nights and Groove Line. His work caught the attention of producer Quincy Jones, leading to a collaboration on Michael Jackson's albums Off The Wall and Thriller. Temperton's songs, including the title track Thriller, helped make the album the best-selling of all time in the US. He also worked with artists like Anita Baker, Donna Summer, and Aretha Franklin, and won a Grammy in 1990.

The passage discusses the discovery of ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon by a team of researchers including Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University. Over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" were found, which were previously concealed by bamboo-dominated rainforest until modern deforestation allowed their discovery. The purpose of these sites is still unclear, but they are thought to have been used sporadically as ritual gathering places, similar to the Maya pyramids of Central America or Britain's Stonehenge. However, unlike other ritual sites, the geoglyphs were constructed amongst taller vegetation and were likely not visible above the forest canopy. The research also indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems free from human influence prior to the arrival of Europeans, but rather a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products created by humans over 6,000 years. The team suggests that the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests may still retain a strong legacy of these ancient "agroforestry" practices.

Nick Kyrgios, the 21-year-old Australian ranked 12th in the world, defeated Sam Querrey, ranked 29th, in the first round of the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios won 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes. Despite his recent success, including winning the Japan Open, Kyrgios expressed feeling tired and bored during the match. He attributed his fatigue to the travel and lack of sleep, as well as the long commute to the Qi Zhong Stadium. Last year, Kyrgios was fined for a profane outburst at the same tournament.

The human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine, which is currently administered to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect against cervical cancer, is being advocated by scientists and charities to also protect against head and neck cancers. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation. Charities and organizations, including Tenovus Cancer Care and Cardiff University's HPV research team, are urging the Welsh government to roll out the vaccination for boys as well. They cite an increase in head and neck cancer cases, particularly among younger men who are non-smokers. The HPV vaccine has been administered in schools since 2008, with 85% of girls in Wales having been vaccinated. The Welsh government has stated that it will consider the committee's recommendations regarding any proposed changes to the HPV vaccination programme.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old boy from West Calder High School, passed away after battling a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He was diagnosed in August and had been documenting his journey on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey, with the help of his mother, sister, and girlfriend. Jak's positive attitude and love for Rangers FC touched many people, and his Facebook page gained over 28,000 likes. Despite feeling unwell, Jak briefly attended his school prom and was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. He also received the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. Jak spent time in hospitals, meeting players from various sports teams and the cast of the musical Wicked. On January 23, Jak and his family learned that his cancer had spread, and doctors decided not to pursue further treatment. Jak expressed his determination to fight the pain and thanked everyone who had helped him. After receiving the news, Jak's family urged people to donate to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. Jak enjoyed several memorable experiences before his passing, including visiting the Kelpies, having a romantic meal with his girlfriend, attending a party in his honor, and spending time in a supercar and on a quad bike. A special football match is planned to raise more money for charity at the Energy Assets Arena, home of Livingston FC.

In a low-scoring match, Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda in the 89th minute with a goal from Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had an earlier goal disallowed for offside. Egypt will now face Ghana, who also won their match against Mali, in a battle for the top spot in Group D. Uganda, who have not qualified since 1978, are now out of the tournament.
