The match was characterized by a resolute Ugandan defense and a lack of clear chances for either side.

Lancashire County Council has designated land from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus for a new railway station. The sports college closed in August, and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus, owned by Newcastle College, is currently not in use. The decision was made after a comparative study by Network Rail of the proposed sites. Skelmersdale's original railway station closed to passengers in 1956. The council plans to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The preferred location is large enough to allow for future expansion and has good highway access and connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The authority will now start the process of acquiring the relevant land. Skelmersdale, one of the largest towns in the north west of England without its own railway station, was designated a new town on 9 October 1961.

A substantial number of plants were discovered in an intricate grow house within a warehouse close to Ashbourne during a search conducted on Saturday morning. A man estimated to be in his late 40s was apprehended at the location.

The passage describes an incident in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, where a 28-year-old woman was found with severe injuries, having been dragged by the neck through several streets. The woman, who remains unidentified, underwent an emergency operation and was airlifted to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, turned himself in to the authorities. Both individuals are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is yet to be determined, according to a spokesman for Hannover prosecutors, Thomas Klinge. Police have secured the area and are appealing for witnesses.

The study conducted by the Cass Business School, the University of Warwick, and the University of Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay raise but are 25% less likely to receive one. The research, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, debunked the "reticent female" theory, which suggested that women were less likely to ask for more money. The study found no evidence that women were more reluctant to ask for a raise due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a female stereotype. The researchers took into account various factors such as the size of the employer, industry, parental status, and qualifications. The study also found that women and men under 40 asked for and received pay raises at the same rate, indicating a potential shift in negotiating behavior. The researchers suggested that this trend could continue as younger women become more senior. The findings led Professor Andrew Oswald to conclude that there may be an element of pure discrimination against women in the workplace.

Oxford City Council has been using funds to investigate potential burial site locations but has yet to find a suitable one. The two existing cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. Despite the challenge, the council is still looking for options. The council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has run out of suitable land within Oxford. All council-owned sites identified so far have been discounted due to size, ground conditions, high water table, or covenant restrictions. Once the two remaining cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, the use of reserved plots, and the interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July will be able to use an app to access augmented reality content, such as videos and band interviews, via signs and posters at the festival. This feature will also allow people worldwide to interact with the festival remotely. The festival lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The app's content will be updated leading up to and during the event, enabling users to access information, interviews, and tickets in real-time.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". Despite showing symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, Many Clouds had no significant underlying health issues and had never collapsed before. The horse had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. The BHA is determined to understand what causes these symptoms and prevent them in the future. Many Clouds' death was due to a haemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack.

In 2004, a 15-year-old girl was raped by a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage. Ayrton, now 34 and known as Davina, denied the charge but was found guilty. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, will be sentenced on 4 March and was remanded into custody at a male prison in Winchester due to being a risk to herself and a potential flight risk. The victim recalled the events clearly, stating she had only consumed a small amount of alcohol and shouted at Ayrton to stop the attack, but her friends did not wake up. Ayrton revealed the attack to a care home worker in 2014.

The Serbian team, including world number one Novak Djokovic, lost 6-4 6-4 to the Brazilian duo Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in the Rio Olympics. This defeat followed Djokovic's elimination from the singles event by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, 29, had previously experienced a surprise loss to American Sam Querrey in the third round at Wimbledon in July. Despite this, he went on to secure his 30th Masters title in Toronto prior to the Olympics.

In Saturday's event at Carrbridge in the Cairngorms, over 20 competitors, including participants from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US, will compete in a chainsaw carving competition. The contestants are only allowed to use chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend his title and keep the first place winner's prize, the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, has not played since sustaining a severe foot injury during a World Cup warm-up with Italy in September. He is nearing a return to the game and aims to be fit for the Six Nations tournament in February. Webb mentioned that he is currently in a pre-season phase and his recovery is progressing well. He plans to assess his progress week by week. Initially, a return at the beginning of February was discussed, but Webb has asked his physios to expedite his recovery by a couple of weeks. Wales will commence their Six Nations campaign against Ireland in Dublin on February 7. Webb, who has been capped 16 times by Wales, has extended his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union. Despite receiving offers from other clubs, he decided to remain with Ospreys, the team he debuted for in 2007. Webb expressed his commitment to his home region and his desire to be in the best position to represent his country.

The incident started on Tuesday morning when US border agents near Sumas, Washington, encountered two men carrying backpacks containing a total of 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy. One man, identified as Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody immediately. The other man, Nathan Hall, dropped his backpack, fired a weapon at the agents, and fled. Hall was later arrested by the Abbotsford Police Department in British Columbia. A Bellingham, Washington woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for planning to pick up the two men at the border and transport the drugs to San Francisco. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy as well as drug possession and distribution charges. The area where the incident occurred is a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service has reported a significant increase in counselling for children suffering from online abuse, with over 4,500 children in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The actual number of children affected is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven have reported being tormented, abused, and scared to go to school due to online trolls. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, has called this a wake-up call, emphasizing that bullying can have severe impacts on young people's lives, especially with cyber-bullying following them home. She urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children, as bullying does not stop on its own. The report was released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which is working with various groups to combat the issue. A young person who contacted Childline shared their experience of being told to kill themselves by an online group, causing significant distress. The young person's parents did not fully understand the impact, advising them to stand up for themselves or stop playing, highlighting the difficulty of dealing with such situations. Advice from young people on dealing with bullying was also provided.

The passage discusses recent developments in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, primarily focusing on Israel's response to a UN Security Council resolution. The resolution, passed on Friday, called for an end to settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which are considered illegal under international law. The US abstained from vetoing the resolution, infuriating Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who claimed the White House helped draft the resolution. The US denied this accusation. More than 500,000 Jews live in about 140 settlements built since Israel's 1967 occupation. The resolution was rejected by Israel, particularly due to its condemnation of building in East Jerusalem, which Israel sees as part of its capital. In response, Netanyahu summoned ambassadors, recalled Israeli ambassadors, cut aid, and cancelled a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. A planned vote on authorizing new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot was postponed at the request of Netanyahu's office to avoid straining relations with Washington before US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech. Kerry is expected to lay out his vision for ending the Israel-Palestinian conflict and address Israeli government critiques of the Obama administration. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas hopes the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France will end the occupation.

The passage describes the events surrounding Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, including her visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and the opening of a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens. It also mentions the release of a picture of the Queen, the Prince of Wales, Prince William, and Prince George for stamps to mark the occasion. The Queen's birthday is being celebrated with various events, including the unveiling of a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway and the lighting of a beacon. The passage also includes comments from Prince William, who paid tribute to the Queen as a "guiding example" of what a good monarch should be. He also addressed recent criticisms of his own commitment to royal duty, stating that he takes his responsibilities seriously but is trying to find his own way. The passage also mentions that the Queen's birthday is being celebrated with the release of ten stamps, including a stamp sheet featuring four generations of the Royal Family.

In the EFL Cup match between Cheltenham Town and West Ham United, the Premier League side took control before half-time with two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Despite the hosts going close via Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header, the visitors could have added further goals. The fourth-tier side performed respectfully but did not sufficiently test Hammers goalkeeper Adrian. The match ended with a 2-0 win for West Ham United, ending League Two's representation in the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision with a VW Transporter driven by Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig. The incident occurred on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court. He was fined £1,000, banned from driving in the UK for two years, but received no jail sentence as per the victim's family's wishes. Werner expressed remorse and was unable to explain the cause of the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British citizen from Southall, west London, is facing a potential life sentence for his involvement in the Syrian conflict. He left the UK in January last year and joined Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, which included many British men. Khawaja was active online, posting videos and pictures of his experiences, and was involved in appeals for donations and video diaries. However, some of the group's material showed gruesome scenes of death, including an image of Khawaja holding a bag containing a head. Khawaja returned to the UK last June, with the help of his cousin Tahir Bhatti, who has admitted assisting an offender. Khawaja was arrested at Dover and has admitted four offences. He was considered so dangerous that he was held in the special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects at London's maximum security Belmarsh prison.

Jackson, aged 22, has been signed by Barnsley as their third signing for the upcoming season. He scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, where they finished eighth in the table. Jackson is known for his pace and ability to challenge defenders, as highlighted by Barnsley's caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom. Jackson had previously declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the next season.

The passage describes an incident where numerous sealed bottles of 'Vanish' have washed up on several Cornish coasts, including Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion. The bottles are believed to have come from a container lost by the MV Blue Ocean during stormy weather near Land's End in May. The National Trust and conservationists are concerned about the potential harm to marine life. While the Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirmed that the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of 'Vanish', they stated that there is currently no concrete evidence linking these bottles to that container. The public is advised to keep a safe distance from the bottles and not attempt to recover them.

A serious road accident happened on the A9 in Caithness near Berriedale around 14:00. Unfortunately, one person died, and several others sustained minor injuries. The road was shut down, and traffic was diverted through the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland confirmed that they are still investigating the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, played a significant role in Bolton's promotion to the Championship, making 14 appearances last season. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has since made 83 appearances in all competitions. Despite being overlooked initially, he made a notable contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite is the fourth player, following David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, to sign a new contract with Bolton after their promotion.

The Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being willing to "concede everything" regarding Brexit, while Labour's leader in the Lords, Baroness Smith, claimed the Lib Dems were giving people "false hope". The two parties had previously collaborated to inflict defeats on the government concerning EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, their cooperation ended when MPs rejected those amendments, with Lib Dems insisting on them and Labour deferring to the Commons. A Labour source accused the Lib Dems of "grandstanding" for campaign material, while Lib Dem Baroness Ludford criticized Labour for "waving through the government's plans" and "lining up with the Conservatives" for a hard Brexit. Despite a history of alliances on various issues, tensions remain between the two parties, with a Labour source predicting "residual tensions" and little demand for a "progressive consensus summer drinks" gathering.

In this election, defense is not a priority for most political parties, with the economy, NHS, and immigration being more pressing concerns. The UK military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya may have contributed to a sense of combat fatigue among the public. The size of the UK's regular Army is being reduced from 102,000 to 82,000, and the Royal Navy and RAF have also seen significant cuts. The UK has no Maritime Patrol Aircraft and relies on NATO allies to hunt for Russian submarines. The UK has fallen to sixth place in defense spending, behind the US, China, Russia, Saudi Arabia, and France. A commitment to spend 2% of the nation's wealth on defense is conspicuous by its absence. The Conservatives, Labour, and the Lib Dems have promised to bring down the budget deficit, which will likely result in more cuts to defense spending. The Conservatives and UKIP are committed to renewing Britain's nuclear deterrent with a like-for-like replacement, while Labour and the Liberal Democrats have different plans for the nuclear deterrent. There is no political consensus on Trident, and it may be up for grabs in the next Strategic Defence Review. By the end of this decade, the UK will have two new operational aircraft carriers, but there is a danger that they will be more like the emperor's new clothes due to manning and equipment issues. Politicians have long boasted that Britain can punch above its weight on the world stage, but it's becoming harder to live up to that rhetoric.

The Spanish football club Barcelona, who signed Neymar for £48.6m, has been under investigation for alleged misappropriation of funds and tax-related crimes in relation to the transfer. Despite denying any wrongdoing, Barcelona made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to cover potential interpretations of the contracts. The total cost of Neymar, including fees and wages, is estimated to be £106.8m. The case is still ongoing, and there has been no confirmation of it being dropped after Barcelona's payment. Neymar has scored 7 goals in 18 league appearances and 3 in 7 Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a car accident caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Luciw's family and colleague, who was also injured in the accident, believe that older drivers should undergo regular driving tests and medical examinations. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must fill in a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses, but this does not include a medical or driving test. Age UK supports older people driving safely for as long as possible. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) has no plans to restrict licensing on the basis of age and states that evidence does not show that older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse in women. Many women have reported debilitating side effects, leading to questions about the safety of these procedures. An independent review was conducted, but two patients on the original review group resigned, claiming the final report was watered down. Health secretary Ms. Robison announced that independent expert Alison Britton will examine the review process and its conclusions. The report recommended that procedures not be routinely offered for pelvic organ prolapse and that patients be given a range of treatment options and information to make informed choices. It also suggested mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for an all-out ban, the government cannot ban the procedures, as that power lies with the UK regulatory body, the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the controversial final report. Over the past 20 years, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants, with some experiencing painful and debilitating complications, leading to over 400 women taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, aged 23, broke the 25-year-old 5000m indoor record set by Liz McColgan at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. Muir's time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds was 14 seconds faster than McColgan's record. McColgan initially raised concerns about whether Muir's race met all the criteria for record-breaking attempts, as Muir was the only competitor to finish the 5000m race. However, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's potential, stating that she had the ability to run a 5000m in 14.30 and compete with the best in the world. Muir had previously broken her own British 1500m record and reached the 1500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung emerged victorious in the event, riding Sam, who was a substitute for Fischertakinou due to an infection in July. Astier Nicolas from France secured the silver medal, while Phillip Dutton from the USA won bronze. William Fox-Pitt from Great Britain finished 12th, marking a significant comeback just 10 months after being in a medically induced coma following a fall. Despite a flawless show-jumping performance on Tuesday, Fox-Pitt's medal chances were dashed by a disappointing cross-country phase on Monday, where he incurred several time penalties, dropping him from the lead after the dressage phase to 21st place. Jonty Evans from Ireland finished ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift. The passage also invites readers to meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse at some of the Official Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics and provides information on getting into equestrian sports.

In a tense and fluctuating match, Andy Murray, a 30-year-old Briton, defeated Fabio Fognini, the 29th seed from Italy, with a score of 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5. The match lasted for two hours and 39 minutes, with Murray securing the match point at 20:57 BST. Despite Fognini having five set points to force a fifth set, Murray won five consecutive games to advance to the last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will face Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Earlier, fellow Briton Johanna Konta reached the second week for the first time with a 6-4 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari of Greece. Murray acknowledged the tense end of the match and admitted that the tennis was not at its best at times, but he managed to get through.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 due to a sudden death. Police found several people still at the bar, with alcohol being served as late as 04:49 BST, violating licensing hours. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The defense admitted that the premises had not been run properly and had been operating well into the morning. The judge ordered the closure of the bar for three months, fined Ms. O'Neill £3,000, and Mr. Thomas £1,000. The judge expressed concern over Ms. O'Neill's "appalling record" and stated that it was one of the worst cases he had come across.

The Ulster Unionist Party, led by Mike Nesbitt, launched their manifesto titled 'Real Partnership', emphasizing partnership over domination. The party aims to make the election a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. However, Nesbitt's comments about vote transfers to the SDLP have sparked controversy. Nesbitt stands by his remarks, stating he would rather form a partnership with the SDLP than Sinn Féin. The manifesto includes calls for action on waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is worse off due to Brexit. The party also calls for cleaning up Stormont, focusing on incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption.

The Justice Minister of Northern Ireland, Claire Sugden, has confirmed a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval to align Northern Ireland with England and Wales regarding automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. This law, known as 'Turing's Law', will grant posthumous pardons to deceased men and allow living men to apply for pardons. The motion is expected to include provisions for both posthumous and living gay and bisexual men. The minister has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offences. The motion aims to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as in England and Wales. The motion will now be considered by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second in a 1500m race with a time of 4:19.12, breaking the previous Scottish record set by Yvonne Murray in 1994. This performance also places her second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd. Muir, who holds the Scottish records for both the 1500m and mile, expressed her pleasure in achieving the new record and her excitement in finishing close to the Kenyan winner, Faith Kipyegon. Muir, who is also a veterinary student, started her season with an 800m victory in France and plans to compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm. She aims to secure a spot on the Great Britain team for the Rio Olympics at the British trials in Birmingham.

The passage highlights that there are 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as the "most excellent" for water quality. The pictures of these beaches are being presented. No further details are provided in the passage.

The Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, who are believed to have poisoned Alexander Litvinenko in London in 2006, had no personal motive to kill him. He suggested that the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot, with numerous reasons for wanting Litvinenko harmed or dead. Litvinenko died in hospital after drinking tea laced with a fatal dose of polonium-210 during a meeting with the suspects. Horwell emphasized that the involvement of the Russian state did not imply President Vladimir Putin's direct involvement or order. Litvinenko's defection to the UK in 2000 and his accusations against the FSB could have been perceived as treachery. Horwell also mentioned that the suspects left a trail of polonium and had no credible explanation for the scientific evidence against them. Despite the Met Police's desire to try them for murder, extradition attempts have failed, and the suspects remain in Russia.

In the passage, it is announced that Steve Smith, 26, will be the new captain of the Australian cricket team, succeeding Michael Clarke who retired after losing the Ashes to England. Smith will also lead the Twenty20 team in Aaron Finch's absence. David Warner, 28, has been appointed as Smith's vice-captain. Smith has previously captained the team in three Tests against India and has played in 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Warner has been given the vice-captain role despite past disciplinary issues, with selectors believing he will respond well to the added responsibility. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron, the leader of a liberal party, has expressed his passion for LGBT-plus rights and stated that defending equal marriage would be a top priority during his leadership. He aims to extend the marital rights of transgender people, specifically addressing the spousal veto issue that prevents transgender individuals from having equal access to marriage. Farron was previously questioned about his views on homosexual sex as a sin but did not provide a direct answer. He also voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about the protection of individual liberties, but assured that he supports equality and is in favor of equal access under law for all people, regardless of their sexuality.

In 2015, Sanofi, a French company, shut down its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Now, Accord Healthcare plans to utilize the plant for its pharmaceutical production, aiming to employ many former Sanofi staff. The company believes this investment will have a highly positive impact on the area. Nick Forbes, the leader of Newcastle City Council, welcomed the news, stating it strengthens the region's reputation as a hub for the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare, a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to around 60 countries worldwide.

The local authority announced the departures of Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland. Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving at the end of his contract on Friday. Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are both taking voluntary redundancy and early retirement. Opposition leader Stephen Flynn suggested these departures reflect the council's struggle to retain senior staff and predicted further departures. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for the trio's dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, Martin, had a crash at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike faced mechanical issues. Martin initially announced his retirement from road racing but later clarified that he has no plans to race on Hondas this year. He did not participate in the North West 200 and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. Martin expressed that the TT was a disaster and he didn't enjoy it. He felt he was more of a test rider than a competitor. After further testing at Cadwell, he informed the team that the bike wouldn't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix, leading to his withdrawal from the event. Martin expressed his interest in racing classics and unique events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC's victory was widespread across northern states and Nigeria's commercial hub, Lagos, while the PDP only managed to win in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The PDP's decline was further emphasized by their loss in key northern states and states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose a challenge for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall, they were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP, which was in power for 16 years, will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader after facing widespread allegations of corruption and criticism for not doing enough to end the Islamist-led insurgency in the north-east.

The passage discusses allegations made by environmental lobby group Mighty against agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek. Mighty accuses Olam of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to the haze caused by agriculture fires in Indonesia. Olam rejects these allegations, stating it has a strict sourcing policy with zero tolerance for burning. Temasek, as the majority stakeholder in Olam, could be linked to the annual haze if the allegations are proven. The palm oil industry is often accused of unfair labor practices, deforestation, and burning of plantations. Olam is also accused of bulldozing rainforests in Gabon for palm oil plantations, but the company claims its partnerships in Gabon are responsible and transparent.

The passage discusses a restaurant that started serving "puppy platters" following the introduction of a new law allowing dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they are outdoors. The event took place on August 27, 2016.

Fernando Forestieri, the forward, is uncertain to play due to a knee injury, having only featured as a substitute in the last two games. Derby County striker David Nugent may return after missing the draw with Huddersfield due to a groin injury. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield, who scored a late equalizer against Huddersfield as a substitute, is hoping to be recalled to the starting lineup.

Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube, which was imposed in 2012 due to the upload of the controversial film 'Innocence of Muslims'. The ban was lifted as Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube. While Google has provided a process for the Pakistani Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to request blocking of offensive material, YouTube has stated that government requests for content removal will not be automatically granted. The lifting of the ban has been welcomed by many young Pakistanis, but some activists are calling for transparency regarding the deal between Google and the government.

The passage discusses a potential conflict of interest in the upcoming Fifa presidential elections, set to take place in 18 days. Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, shares a nationality with one of the five candidates, Gianni Infantino. Liberian FA boss Musa Bility has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations. However, Andreas Bantel, a spokesman for Scala, argues that there is no conflict of interest as the regulations do not mention nationality as a cause for conflict. Bility, who failed an eligibility check for the elections, has pledged his vote to Prince Ali and urged fellow Africans to do the same. The other candidates include Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale. The election will take place in Zurich, Switzerland, and will be voted on by Fifa's 209 members.

In the passage, it is reported that Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were fatally injured at Harford Attachments in Spar Road while working in a paint-spraying area around 09:00 BST on Monday. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. The incident is being investigated as a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, resulting in a fireball effect. The police have made significant progress with forensic inquiries and witness statements, while the Health and Safety Executive is also gathering evidence with the help of inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia and Morocco faced issues with their participation in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was threatened with expulsion due to complaints lodged against Caf during the 2015 Nations Cup, but an apology resolved the issue. Morocco was initially banned from the qualifying draw, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola fears. Equatorial Guinea stepped in as hosts, leading to a controversial penalty decision in a quarter-final match against Tunisia. Tunisia wrote a letter to Caf, which was misinterpreted as an accusation of corruption. However, the issue was resolved after a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. If Tunisia qualifies for the 2017 finals in Gabon, it will be their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup.

In the 95th minute of a game at Etihad Stadium, a mass fracas occurred, leading to the charge. Chelsea won the match 3-1 against Manchester City. City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, while Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement in the incident. Aguero, aged 28, received a four-match ban for his second dismissal due to violent conduct this season, following a high and late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz. Fernandinho clashed with Fabregas after Aguero's challenge, resulting in a three-match ban for the Brazilian midfielder. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot program in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd, Wales, focusing on patients whose family doctors suspect cancer but show no symptoms or signs. This comes a year after doctors visited Denmark to observe their diagnostic systems. Officials from the Cwm Taf Health Board noted that Denmark's health service improved cancer detection rates. The concern is that patients in Wales without clear symptoms may wait too long for diagnosis, as they do not fit easily into any specific treatment pathway. This means family doctors refer patients back and forth for various tests, which can take several weeks. Consequently, there is a fear that too many patients start treatment when their cancer has already developed or cannot be improved. Forty doctors in Cwm Cynon believe that something could refer patients to the diagnostic center at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant within seven days. The estimate is that around six patients per week will be seen and receive different tests, with the hope that this will happen on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with "worrying" symptoms receive a diagnosis in the Cwm Taf area. Doctors want to reach a higher percentage of patients without such clear symptoms. A similar clinic will be set up at Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of another trial by the Abertawe Bro Morgannwg Health Board. The trials have been developed over the 12 months since specialists returned from Aarhus, Denmark. Denmark went there to establish diagnostic centers due to concerns about the country's cancer detection rates. According to Dr. Gareth Davies, Director of the Wales Cancer Network, the program will reassure patients and speed up the process. If a family doctor sees a patient who is unsure but worried and feels something is wrong, they can refer the patient quickly to the clinic, meaning the patient will be seen quickly and hopefully receive a diagnosis. Gareth Jordan, a family doctor in Aberdare, says the pilot program could make a big difference to patients' lives. "I could say, 'I've seen this man, he's lost a lot of weight... I can't send him away for specialist tests or if we do, the tests will be done in a timely manner'. "But the fact that they are seen in one place and everyone sees rapid progress, the likelihood is early diagnosis if they have cancer in my opinion." If the Cwm Cynon pilot program is successful, other health boards in the area will offer the same service in the following months.

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford by a significant margin, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, setting up their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and 71 not out in the second, as well as contributing with the ball. Pakistan struggled, scoring 198 in the first innings and 234 in the second. The series will continue with the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment in their performance and hoped for improvement.

In the passage, it is mentioned that head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with interim coach Rob Howley as part of his team. Forwards coach Robin McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales for the third time, having led tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to support McBryde. The WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips stated that they are in advanced discussions with other individuals for the summer tour and hope to confirm the full management team soon. Welsh Rugby Union chairman Gareth Davies, who is also on the Lions' selection panel, believes that the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team. He stated that the summer of 2017 is a real opportunity for Welsh coaches and will benefit Welsh rugby in the years ahead. He also mentioned that the tour of New Zealand will provide the ultimate test and inspire each individual.

In this football match, Hull City secured a 2-1 victory over Southampton, ending their six-game losing streak. Charlie Austin's early penalty gave Southampton the lead, but Hull fought back in the second half with goals from Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall made several crucial saves. The win was Hull's first in the league since 20 August, but they remain in the bottom three. The match was marked by injuries to Hull's starting strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane.

A motorcycle crash occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The motorcyclist, a local resident, was killed in the collision, while the tractor driver involved was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police have not released further details about the motorcyclist and have appealed for witnesses to come forward. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

The passage describes a political crisis in Macedonia, sparked by covert recordings that appear to show government officials plotting illegal activities. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has been releasing these recordings since 2015, accusing the government of wiretapping thousands of people and revealing corruption at the highest levels. The government denies these accusations. President Ivanov recently cancelled an investigation into these claims, stating he wanted to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections. However, his move was criticized by the opposition, EU officials, and Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who said it was not in line with the rule of law and put Macedonia's EU membership at risk. Protests have been held in response to the president's decision.

The passage discusses the recent sacking of Swansea's manager, Bob Bradley, and the appointment of Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams to take charge of the upcoming match against Bournemouth. Swansea aims to hire a new manager soon, with Paul Clement as the preferred choice. The club's rise from near bankruptcy to the Premier League is mentioned, along with their reputation for playing exciting, possession-based football. However, Curtis believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. Despite this, Curtis is confident that the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and reminds new signings of the club's history and importance to the area.

In a crucial League One match, Dagenham & Redbridge needed a win to stay in contention for survival, but ultimately lost 3-2 to Leyton Orient, resulting in their relegation to the National League. Dagenham had reached the Football League for the first time in 2007 under manager John Still, who is now tasked with leading them back to promotion. The team has struggled with the worst goal difference in League Two and a less effective attack, with veteran striker Jamie Cureton scoring only nine goals this season. Still has expressed his commitment to helping Dagenham gain promotion next season. Leyton Orient, now two points away from the play-off spots, won the match after a nervy second half, with interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasizing the team's need to win games to secure a play-off position.

Steven Gerrard, former Liverpool captain and ex-England skipper, is set to return to his former club as a youth coach in February. This will be his first job since retiring as a player. Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp confirmed he had a conversation with Gerrard, who expressed his desire to become a manager in the future. Klopp described Gerrard's appointment as "wonderful news" and praised his potential to be a successful manager, citing his playing experience and willingness to learn. Gerrard made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and won several titles before leaving in 2015 to join LA Galaxy. He retired as a player in November after a 19-year career. Gerrard was previously linked with the manager's job at MK Dons but deemed it to be "too soon". He is currently working towards his UEFA A coaching license, which is required to manage in the Premier League.

In the described match, Morton took an early lead with McManus scoring in the 15th minute. Their advantage was further extended when a deflected strike by Ross Forbes found the net. Alloa reduced the deficit before half-time with a goal from Kyle McAusland. However, Morton secured a comfortable win with another goal from McManus and a late goal by Denny Johnstone.

Ofsted has discovered evidence of children being taught in unsuitable conditions in three now-closed places in Birmingham. Operators of illegal schools could face up to 51 weeks in jail. The government is also considering stricter regulations for places teaching more than 6-8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, reported that inspectors were disturbed by the conditions they found. A total of 18 unregulated schools, primarily in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been investigated recently. Three places in Birmingham have been shut down due to suspicion of running illegal schools. Sir Michael believes these cases are just the beginning and is worried about the risk of abuse or radicalization. Places teaching over 20 hours a week must register as a school. Some part-time education centers or "flexi schools" are operating legally, but concerns exist that some are exploiting the right to home educate to run illegal schools. Sir Michael criticized officials for providing unclear advice to the proprietors of the closed places. The government has funded a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools. While most investigated places have been in Muslim communities, inspectors may also look into similar unregistered centers operated by other groups. The Education Secretary has now asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools. For a prosecution to be brought against an unregistered school, the Education Secretary's consent is required. The government consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is a new distillery located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, Scotland. It is the first distillery to open in the region since 1837 and is part of a larger movement to establish the Scottish Borders as a "region of distilling excellence". The distillery is unique in its small scale, with a still that is one of the smallest production stills in the UK and an operation that fits into a cowshed. The gin is made using local botanicals from the Teviot valley, with the aim of capturing the local flavor palette and "terroir". The name Lilliard was chosen to reflect the local landscape and the strong female production team, as it is the name of a legendary Borders figure who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The distillery is a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site and is eagerly anticipated by the local community.

Harry Whitlam died after Gary Green, who was more than two times the legal driving limit, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm near Leeds in August 2013. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. He was prosecuted under health and safety legislation as the incident occurred on private land. Harry's mother Pam Whitlam expressed the devastating impact of Harry's death on their family and emphasized the importance of not driving under the influence, whether on public or private land.

Luis Suarez, a 27-year-old Uruguay striker, is now allowed to train and play in friendly matches for his new club Barcelona. He was previously suspended from all football-related activities for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. The Switzerland-based Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) ruled that the sanctions imposed by FIFA were generally confirmed, but preventing Suarez from taking part in any football activity was "excessive". Suarez will still have to serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games, and his competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be at Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez's lawyers argued that FIFA's decision to suspend him was too strong a punishment, and the appeal was a success as he is now allowed to train and play in friendlies, attend matches, and take part in promotional activities.

On March 18, 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won the UK Wife Carrying Race, beating Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania, who was carrying his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. Richard and Anna trained for a week on an athletics track, which helped them win the race. The 380-metre course included obstacles such as haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. The race was open to all combinations of competitors, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and women carrying women. Richard and Anna will now compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

In October, the paper system for car tax discs will be replaced with an electronic system, allowing people to pay the charge by monthly direct debit. This change, announced by Chancellor George Osborne, has raised concerns over the future of some of the 5,000 workers at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) center in Swansea. In response to these concerns, Transport Minister Stephen Hammond stated that job roles would change and employees would need to be trained on new processes. However, he assured that any reductions in staff numbers would be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business, rather than redundancies. This response was welcomed by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, who expressed disappointment at the reduction in job opportunities but acknowledged the advantages of the new payment system and the absence of tax discs.

The Hungarian government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, is facing pressure from the EU over three controversial laws. These laws include tight controls on asylum seekers and NGOs, and a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University (CEU). The EU objects to these laws, stating they may not be compatible with EU regulations. Thousands of Hungarians have protested against these laws. However, Hungary's Foreign Minister, Mr. Szijjarto, has stated that the EU should not interfere with "domestic issues" and that they have backing from Poland to veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights. The Higher Education Law, signed in April, could force the closure of the Budapest-based CEU, which ranks among the top 200 universities in the world. Draft legislation on NGOs is also expected to go before parliament soon, which human rights groups say would stigmatise them as "foreign-backed" organisations. The EU has warned of action in coming weeks if there are no positive developments.

The passage announces the cast for the upcoming live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast. Emma Watson will play Belle, while Dan Stevens will portray the Beast. Luke Evans is cast as the villain Gaston, and Josh Gad will play Gaston's sidekick LeFou. The role of Mrs Potts, originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version, will be played by a yet-to-be-named star. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and is set to begin filming in May at Shepperton Studios, with a release date of March 17, 2017 in US cinemas.

The columnist Adrian Gill, known for his dazzling and fearless writing, passed away after a battle with cancer. He was a giant among journalists and the heart and soul of the Sunday Times, where he worked since 1993. Despite his illness, Gill remained stoic and continued to write, with his final column about his diagnosis to be featured in the Sunday Times. His writing often caused controversy, such as his description of shooting a baboon in Tanzania and his comments about various regions and people in the UK. Gill was known for dictating his copy over the phone due to his dyslexia and had a successful career as a writer, despite his learning disability. He was married twice and had four children, with his engagement to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, announced before his death.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was attacked after a performance in Ulan Bator while wearing a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika. He was hospitalized for about 10 days due to the injuries sustained from the attack. The swastika, though associated with Nazis, is a traditional Mongolian symbol of eternity. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, which involved an unidentified Russian official, and has called local press reports "distorted". The musician's lawyer emphasized that the suspect must be investigated according to Mongolian law. The case is currently under investigation, with the suspect not being detained due to the injury not being considered serious, rather than diplomatic immunity.

In a protest against the expansion plans of an unnamed airport, campaigners from the group Plane Stupid demonstrated on its northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. The group consists of men and women who have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome. They are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. The incident has prompted the Metropolitan Police to review the airport's security.

The passage describes a cricket match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire. Glamorgan's total was largely due to Nick Selman's 101 runs off 144 balls, his second first-class century. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured regular wickets for Gloucestershire. Glamorgan's bowlers remained dominant throughout the day, with Gloucestershire struggling to score. Aneurin Donald's 36 off 30 balls was the second-best score for Glamorgan. Glamorgan managed to secure a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire's innings was a challenge due to the conditions and the strong bowling from Glamorgan. The match was evenly balanced by the end of the day. Michael Hogan was leading Glamorgan for the first time due to Jacques Rudolph's absence. Selman expressed his satisfaction with his performance and hoped to continue his form. Taylor was pleased with his bowling performance and acknowledged the challenge ahead for Gloucestershire's batsmen.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, was arrested in August by North Wales Police following online conversations with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He was charged with planning a murder attempt involving an ambush on police officers after reporting a non-existent crime. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. He intended to make a false report to lure police to the Dee Estuary, where he planned to shoot them. The threats were made twice while Hughes was intoxicated. Judge Niclas Parry, aware of Hughes's previous firearm conviction in 2009, remanded him in custody. Hughes's legal team claimed he had no intention of self-harm and would not have carried out any threat against police officers. The court was informed that North Wales Police had been particularly concerned as Hughes was on bail for firearm offenses, of which he was later acquitted. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counseling to individuals in need.

In a cricket match, Surrey, previously at 8-2, scored 255-7 with Davies and Foakes sharing a 130-run stand. Yorkshire's chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, including the wickets of Bairstow and Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire fell short at 236 all out. Yorkshire had hoped to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002, but were undone by dropped catches and Meaker's fast bowling. Surrey's skipper praised Davies and Foakes for their significant partnership, while Yorkshire's captain expressed disappointment that their top-order batsmen failed to make substantial contributions.

The 17.1m converted trawler, located 10 km west of South Stack, encountered an issue with water ingress at 07:00 BST. The onboard pump failed to manage the incoming water, prompting the crew to contact Holyhead coastguards for assistance. The RNLI lifeboat crew intervened by installing a pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

The passage discusses Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner and veterinary medicine student, who will not be participating in the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her exams being in May, just after the April event. She expresses her disappointment in missing the Games but emphasizes the importance of completing her degree. Despite this, Muir remains optimistic about her future in athletics, aiming for at least two or three more Olympics and considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. She recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the latter.

The passage discusses Liverpool's struggles in the current football season, comparing it to their successful title challenge last season. The team's problems are attributed to the loss of key players, poor transfer decisions, and unrealistic expectations. Liverpool's strikers, Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini, are criticized for their lack of goals and work-rate, which has led to a decrease in the team's intensity and pressing ability. The team's defense is also seen as a weakness, with the goalkeeper Simon Mignolet being criticized for not commanding his box. The passage suggests that Liverpool will struggle against Chelsea, who are currently performing at a higher level. The passage also discusses Steven Gerrard's physical and mental battle to secure a long-term future with Liverpool, despite his age and recent disappointments.

The passage discusses the construction of a £45m educational facility in Kilmarnock, which will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. The council plans to name the campus after renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975. He gained recognition for his first novel, Remedy Is None, and was known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for his acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works. McIlvanney was also an influential poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributor to political and sporting life in Scotland. He passed away at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

A sea mine, believed to be British and dating from the 1940s or 1950s, was discovered near the swimming pool in Gourock, leading to the evacuation of three streets and safety advice issued to residents within 500m of the device. An exclusion zone was also enforced on the river and at sea, causing disruption to ferry services. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, and the Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit decided to move the mine to a safer location due to its deterioration and unknown amount of remaining explosive material. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the evacuation procedures.

The passage discusses the funding decisions made by UK Sport for the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and Paralympics. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, which is £2m less than the amount allocated for the Rio Games. Cycling, badminton, and archery are among the sports that have had their funding cut, with badminton losing all of its funding despite winning a bronze medal in Rio. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. The decision to cut funding was made to prioritize sports with the greatest medal potential. Sports minister Tracey Crouch and UK Sport CEO Liz Nicholl have defended the decision, stating that it has proven successful in previous Olympics. However, some sports, such as basketball, handball, and volleyball, have criticized UK Sport for not investing in team sports and refusing to take responsibility for their performance development. UK Sport says that funding for the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed.

In Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area, three Victorian hotels (Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View) will be replaced by a four-star, 90-room hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The project, approved by the council with a 7-3 vote, aims to boost tourism and improve living conditions for older residents. The new development includes a six-storey hotel and nine- and seven-storey apartment buildings. Despite objections from English Heritage, the Ancient Monuments Society, and 49 residents regarding the scale of the project and potential harm to the conservation area, the council received 246 letters supporting the plans.

Pte Matthew Boyd, aged 20, was fatally attacked by Jake Vallely, aged 24, during a night out in Brecon. Vallely was found guilty of manslaughter and will be sentenced on 8 December. The incident occurred after Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge. CCTV footage showed Vallely punching and beating Pte Boyd until he was unconscious, then dragging his body away. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of any involvement in the attack. Pte Boyd, originally from County Antrim, was in Brecon for training exercises and was making his way back to the barracks when he was attacked outside a bar. The attack was described as a "despicable act" by the senior investigating officer. Pte Boyd's family paid tribute to him as a loving and caring person with a promising career ahead of him. They expressed their grief over the "void" created by his death and the "unbearable pain" they will carry for the rest of their lives.

Andrew Travers left his position as chief executive of Barnet Council by mutual agreement following an error that led to voters being turned away from polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton will temporarily take over while longer-term arrangements are made. The council apologized for the problems and offered emergency proxy votes, but voters questioned the fairness of the results. The council's review will conclude by the end of May and examine the appropriateness of arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum in June.

In the football match between Gateshead and Wrexham, Josh Gillies scored the first goal for Gateshead with a free-kick. Wrexham's Sean Newton equalized with a set-piece before half-time. In the second half, Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead, heading Craig Baxter's cross into the net. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half performance and the quality of the winning goal. Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment in his team's second-half performance and missed chances. The match ended 2-1 in favor of Gateshead.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries. Norway ranks first, while Afghanistan is last, followed by Mozambique.

The passage discusses the OneWeb venture, a project aiming to deliver broadband links from orbit to every corner of the globe using a constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000. The project focuses on high volume and low-cost satellite production, requiring new assembly line methods akin to those in factories producing cars and planes. Airbus and OneWeb have inaugurated the first assembly line in Toulouse, France, with two more lines to be set up in Florida. The first 10 satellites are scheduled to launch in April next year, with more launches following. The establishment of the OneWeb constellation requires the greatest rocket campaign in the history of spaceflight, with more than 20 Soyuz vehicles booked for launches. OneWeb is not the only company planning a mega-constellation, but it has raised $1.7bn in equity and is in talks to secure loans for completion. Debris mitigation is a concern, and OneWeb aims to set new standards in debris mitigation by de-orbiting old, redundant spacecraft within two years.

The Scottish government's finance secretary, Mr. Swinney, criticizes the UK government's spending review, stating it puts "unprecedented pressure" on Scotland's public expenditure. He argues that the UK government's cuts since 2010 will result in a 12.5% reduction in Scotland's discretionary budget by 2019-20. Mr. Swinney also mentions that the UK government could have reduced debt and deficit without such severe cuts. He assures that schools, hospitals, and the police service will not be compromised due to the UK government's austerity measures. The UK government's Scotland Office responds, stating that Scotland will have £390m more in spending next year, which could rise to £750m if the Scottish government uses its underspend. Labour's public services spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, urges Mr. Swinney to back up his anti-austerity stance with concrete actions.

The passage discusses the lack of suitable toilet facilities for people with severe disabilities, particularly those who require assistance or hoists for changing. Standard accessible toilets do not meet their needs. Changing Places toilets, which are larger and have additional features, are recommended for installation in larger buildings, but campaigners want these recommendations to be made compulsory. Lorna Fillingham, a mother of a disabled child, has started a petition for this cause. There are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK. The lack of these facilities can lead to feelings of isolation and exclusion for disabled individuals and their families. While there are logistical and financial barriers to installing these toilets, especially in existing buildings, campaigners are focusing on making it compulsory for newly built larger complexes. Arsenal Football Club, the first Premier League team to install a Changing Places toilet, has seen a positive response from fans and the public.

A group of Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal complaint against McDonald's with the European Commission. They allege that McDonald's forces its franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's responded by stating that they share risks and rewards with their franchisees, a strategy they claim has been successful for many years. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the complaint. The European Commission will now review the submission and has the power to launch an investigation if they find the allegations to be valid. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are bound by longer-than-average contracts and lease premises at above market rates, which they say leads to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to those owned directly by the company. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A #prayforjosh poster appeared in Holywood, County Down, as part of a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father works, and has since gone viral. A mystery donor paid for a billboard with the hashtag, and there has been a huge outpouring of support on Twitter for Josh. The campaign has reached over 79,000 people and has received support from people all over the world.

The Conservative MP for Brecon and Radnorshire, Chris Davies, has criticized the decision to close Brecon Barracks, which has been in operation since 1805. The barracks have a rich history, with troops from the site fighting in every conflict since the early 19th century. Davies has launched a petition against the decision, citing high unemployment levels in the area and the potential impact on the town's military tourism industry. However, it is not thought that jobs are at risk, and the nearby Sennybridge training ground and infantry school at Dering Lines are expected to remain unaffected. The reorganization in Wales will see a specialist light infantry centre created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan. Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire will close in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will go in 2025. The Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith has warned that closing bases will affect the livelihoods of many people who will face uncertainty over their future.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. The industry, which only contributes a small fraction to the GDP and employs around 12,000 people, is at risk of being marginalized in the wider Brexit negotiations. The industry dislikes the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) due to its quotas and equal access principle, which led to many in the industry campaigning for a leave vote. Brexit is seen as an opportunity for the UK to regain control over its waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the House of Lords European Union Committee warns that the UK's commercial fish stocks are in waters shared with other EU states, and most UK fish are exported to the EU. The report suggests that continued market access may come at the price of allowing EU boats to fish in UK waters. The report also advises retaining many elements of the CFP post-Brexit and ensuring that total allowable catches and quotas are based on scientific advice. The UK will also continue to have international obligations to cooperate with neighboring states. The report expresses concern that Brexit could lead to four different fisheries management regimes in the UK. Despite this, many in the fishing industry believe Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats. The EU's recent agreement on new quotas under the CFP, which increased allowable catches for plaice, haddock, and prawns, is seen as a positive sign for the future of British fishing outside the EU. The government has stated that it wants to ensure British companies have maximum freedom to trade with and operate in the single market, while also reviewing fisheries management for fair access to quota, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

The US National Security Agency (NSA) has been revealed to have access to a vast amount of individual data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, social networking data, and phone records from US company Verizon. This access was enabled through a program called Prism, which provided "backdoor" access to servers of major technology companies. The extent of this access is disputed, with some experts suggesting it may be more limited than initially thought. The US government defends these surveillance tactics as necessary for national security, but privacy concerns have been raised. The storage of user data in other countries, particularly the US, has also been a point of contention due to the US Patriot Act. The existence of Prism has been confirmed to violate the privacy of users worldwide, according to Privacy International.

The venture Open AI, backed by prominent figures such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, and companies like Tesla Motors, SpaceX, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to conduct research focused on positive human impact, free from financial obligations. Despite warnings from scientists about the potential threat of AI to humanity, Open AI believes in the benefits of AI for society. The venture plans to advance digital intelligence in a way that benefits humanity as a whole, with the belief that AI should be an extension of individual human wills and broadly distributed. The venture has pledged $1bn, but only a fraction will be spent in the next few years.

Lance Bombardier (L/Bdr) Ben Parkinson, a resident of Doncaster, was severely injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. Despite losing his speech due to a brain injury, his personality and sense of humor remained intact. He was nominated to carry the Olympic torch on 26 June, which led to thousands of friend requests on Facebook. However, Facebook limits personal pages to 5,000 friend associations, preventing him from accepting all requests.

L/Bdr Parkinson walks with crutches and spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab. He is also a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits charity and raises money for military charities. His nomination highlighted his determination and unchanged intelligence and wit. His mother, Diane, described the responses as "phenomenal" and said Ben was "buoyed up" by the support and friendship he had received.

The family has received a significant increase in mail and e-mail traffic, with hundreds of requests for L/Bdr Parkinson to visit places with the Olympic torch. Facebook suggested that he could create a page instead of a profile due to his public figure status or use the subscribe feature to allow people to see his public updates without becoming friends. The Olympic torch will be carried by 8,000 people during its 8,000-mile journey to the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in London on 27 July.

In 2011, the US poverty rate remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans. This followed three years of increases. The real median income of households decreased by 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased slightly to 15.7% from 16.3%. The US had a record high poverty rate of 15.1% in 2010.

The 25-year-old cricketer, Jos Buttler, has extended his contract with Lancashire County Cricket Club until 2019. He initially joined the club, nicknamed the Red Rose, from Somerset in 2013. Buttler is known for his short-format skills and holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan in 2015. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler as one of the most talented cricketers and acknowledged his significant contribution to the team's T20 Blast victory in 2015. Giles also highlighted Buttler's positive influence in the dressing room and the benefits of his international experience to the squad. Buttler, who has been playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, is set to return to Lancashire for the T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

The passage discusses the decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall, which are currently docked in Portsmouth Harbour. The government's Disposal Services Authority is handling their sale, with a preference to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler. Bidders registered interest by 23 January, with viewings scheduled for late February and March. A final decision is expected in spring. Penny Mordaunt, Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, expressed interest in preserving at least one frigate, preferring a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence aims for the best financial return for taxpayers. The Type 22 frigates were originally anti-submarine ships but evolved into powerful surface combatants with substantial weapons systems and excellent command and control facilities. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for £3m.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced racial and political tensions leading to instability and international isolation. This began with a coup by indigenous Fijians overthrowing an elected, Indian-dominated coalition in 1987, followed by further coups in 2000 and 2006. These events harmed the economy, particularly tourism, and Fiji's international reputation, leading to suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. The population, mostly residing on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the former now making up a small majority due to coups and agitation causing many Indo-Fijians to flee. Mixing between the two groups is minimal. Fiji's economy relies on sugar and tourism industries, but also includes mining, services, and light manufacturing. Despite this, Fiji has persistent trade and budget deficits, making it a large per capita recipient of aid.

Syria is in the process of destroying its chemical weapons, but missed the recent deadline due to attacks on shipments by terrorist groups. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable. The US and others have criticized Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, but al-Mekdad denied targeting civilian areas. The Syrian government also denied reports of rebels seizing most of Aleppo's central prison. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, but only about 4% have been removed from the country so far. The process has been slowed down by security concerns. Syria is committed to its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council and aims to implement its obligations on time.

The passage discusses the shortlist for the 46th Booker Prize, which is open to all authors writing in English for the first time. The favorite to win is Mukherjee's The Lives Of Others, set in 1960s Calcutta. Other nominees include Howard Jacobson's J, Ali Smith's How To Be Both, Joshua Ferris's To Rise Again at a Decent Hour, Karen Joy Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves, and Richard Flanagan's The Narrow Road to the Deep North. Fowler's novel is the best-selling among the shortlisted books. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall, with coverage on BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

The passage discusses a celebrity, referred to as PJS, who is appealing against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on his identification in the media in England and Wales. PJS, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, had previously been granted an injunction preventing him from being named in publications in England and Wales due to allegations of extra-marital activities.
