However, the Court of Appeal judges ruled that PJS was unlikely to be able to obtain a permanent injunction as details about the allegations were now "so widespread" that confidentiality had "probably been lost". PJS's solicitors had been monitoring the internet and removing stories in breach of the injunction, but the judges said that it was now a "hopeless task". The Supreme Court will now hear arguments about whether it should grant an appeal and if so, decide if it should be "allowed or dismissed". An interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the hearing.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, was opened in 1989 and recently purchased for £345.5 million. The new owners are planning improvements to address parking and traffic congestion issues, as well as enhancing the appearance of the units. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White mentioned that the new owners view Fosse Park as an investment opportunity and aim to improve its appearance as it serves as a gateway into the city. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, confirmed that they intend to address parking and congestion problems and improve the overall quality of the park's common areas and facilities.

The film 'Beauty and the Beast' was set to release in Malaysia but was delayed due to a "gay moment" featuring the character LeFou. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a "minor edit" to the scene, as homosexual activity is illegal in the country. The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification" and a new release date is yet to be announced. The decision to review the film sparked criticism from netizens who called it "stupid and laughable". The "gay moment" involves LeFou, the sidekick of the film's main antagonist Gaston, who grapples with feelings for Gaston that range from lust to admiration.

Landlords renting properties to over three unrelated individuals must apply for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) license, which can cost around £1,000. Despite the risk of a £20,000 fine, many landlords are deterred from obtaining a license. Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Tenants in HMOs often face concerns such as fear of eviction and living in poorly maintained properties. The shortage of affordable homes forces people into unregulated rented accommodations, with about five to six calls a day received by the Shelter helpline about this issue. Nationally, mandatory licensing for HMOs applies to houses with three or more storeys and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licensing affects properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling, Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett. While landlords have generally complied with the licensing regime, a small minority have resisted applying for their license. The council has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals so far.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to prevent a second election. Fianna Fáil is willing to support a minority government but not a full programme for government. The main issue hindering agreement is water charges, with a commission being considered to determine the future of Irish Water. Fianna Fáil wants immediate removal of water charges, while Fine Gael supports their role. The election resulted in Fine Gael winning 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7. However, no party was able to form a majority government, and TDs have not elected a taoiseach yet.

The Sorrento, a ship owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, was en route to Valencia when a fire started on one of its car decks. The incident occurred approximately 27km from Mallorca. The fire escalated quickly, leading to the evacuation of passengers onto lifeboats. They were later rescued by another ship, the Puglia. At least three people were injured, with one reported to be seriously hurt. The cause of the fire is unknown. The Sorrento sent out distress signals at 13:50 local time. Initially, the captain did not think evacuation was necessary, but the fire's intensity necessitated a full evacuation. The rescued passengers are expected to arrive at Palma de Mallorca's port in a few hours, and psychologists are being arranged to provide counselling. The Sorrento may sink due to the fire damage.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs raised concerns about people, including students, voting twice, which is a criminal offense. The commission suggested better integration of individual electoral registers to identify duplicate entries. Labour cautioned against making it harder for young people to register to vote. A record 46.8 million people registered to vote in the 8 June election, with a turnout of 68.7%, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in registration applications after the snap poll was announced. However, concerns about duplicate applications persist due to the lack of direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service. The commission estimated that duplicate applications ranged from 30% to 70% in different areas, causing administrative and financial burdens. The commission recommended clearer information on registration sites and a verification function, similar to those used in Australia, New Zealand, and the Republic of Ireland. Despite a lack of evidence, the commission took claims of double voting seriously and urged those with information to contact the police. Labour's shadow minister for voter engagement warned against a blanket ban on being registered at two addresses, which could make it harder for young people and students to register to vote.

Lawrence Phillips, a former star player at the University of Nebraska and NFL player for teams including the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers, died at the age of 40 in an apparent suicide. Despite his successful football career, Phillips faced numerous legal troubles, including convictions for assaulting a group of teenagers with his car and assaulting a former girlfriend. He was serving a term of over 30 years in prison and had recently been accused of killing his former cellmate. Despite his struggles, Phillips was remembered as an intelligent person with good qualities by his former coach at Nebraska, Tom Osborne.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram who is officially classified as a soldier, was promoted to the rank of lance corporal in Chester, marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment. He was awarded the promotion for "good behavior" by Brigadier Andrew Williams, the colonel of the regiment. Lance Corporal Derby XXX is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century. He joined the regiment in February 2014, has his own army number, gets paid for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. During his career, he has also helped switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial commemorating the 1914 Christmas Truce.

This passage describes a thrilling football match between Liverpool and Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League quarter-finals. Liverpool won 4-3, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time. The victory was a testament to Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp's ability to turn doubters into believers, as his team overcame a 2-0 deficit in the first half. The match was played in a highly charged atmosphere at Anfield, with both sets of fans contributing to a memorable night. Klopp's touchline demeanor and the performance of his players, including Philippe Coutinho and Divock Origi, were key factors in Liverpool's victory. The win moved Liverpool a step closer to earning a place in the Champions League and set up a semi-final tie against Sevilla.

The passage describes a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, where UK government minister David Davis expressed his intention to keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about the Brexit negotiations. He proposed a monthly meeting to share analysis and allow the devolved administrations to voice their views. However, Scottish government minister Mike Russell expressed the need for more transparency about the UK government's plans and criticized the lack of clarity on the UK's strategic intentions regarding EU market access. Russell emphasized that membership in the single market is essential for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government hopes to overturn a High Court judgment on triggering Article 50 in an appeal to the Supreme Court next month, but the Scottish government intends to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal.

The passage describes a study conducted by Prof. Kevin Sinclair and his team at the University of Nottingham, where they examine a flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane) cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal. The sheep undergo physical examinations to check for signs of disease or osteoarthritis. The study aims to determine if cloned animals age normally and remain healthy, as there are concerns that the cloning process might transfer "age-memory" into the next generation, causing cloned animals to develop age-related diseases at a younger age. Dolly's early death from a virus and osteoarthritis raised concerns about premature aging in cloned animals. The study involves extensive tests and assessments, including joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans, focusing on three age-related co-morbidities: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results, which could impact the future of cloning, will be published soon. The cloned sheep, now approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays, appear to be in good health.

In the passage, Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten 4-7 favourite horse won a race, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. The horse, Shutter Speed, will compete in Chantilly instead of the Oaks at Epsom, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Tasleet (14-1) won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. Shutter Speed secured a fifth Musidora win for both Gosden and Dettori. Despite the soft ground, Dettori praised Shutter Speed as a top-drawer horse. Gosden expressed concern about the ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes and will decide on his participation after walking the course. Shutter Speed will compete in France's Oaks, while Gosden will rely on Enable and Coronet in the Epsom Oaks. Gosden expressed satisfaction with having a month to prepare Shutter Speed for Chantilly. The short gap between Thursday's Dante Stakes and the Derby may prevent Gosden's colt Cracksman from participating in the Dante Stakes.

The passage discusses the volatility of the British pound due to uncertainty surrounding the Brexit referendum. The pound initially fell against the dollar, euro, and Japanese yen, but experienced fluctuations throughout the day. The Leave campaign argued that the pound merely returned to March levels. Investors have been concerned by polls indicating a decrease in the likelihood of a Remain vote, as well as global economic worries. This uncertainty has led to increased volatility in the pound, with hedge funds short-selling and markets on full Brexit alert. Asian stock markets also experienced significant drops due to concerns about the economic impact of Brexit. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1%, with Lloyds Banking Group being the biggest faller. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argued that a weaker pound could benefit UK exporters, citing a narrowed UK trade deficit in April due to increased exports.

The Iron are in the sixth position in the National League, just one point and position away from the play-off spots. Despite a six or seven-hour journey and conceding a goal after five minutes, Cowley thought they posed a lot of questions to a strong Barrow team. Barrow's league unbeaten run extended to nine games with the win, while Braintree's losing streak reached three games. However, Cowley remained optimistic, stating that their journey so far has been remarkable, but challenging as they are a part-time team facing their toughest challenge yet. They plan to embrace and enjoy the challenge.

The passage discusses a significant change in planning decisions in Northern Ireland, where from April 2015, the responsibility will shift from the Planning Service to local councils themselves. This move is seen as a democratization of the planning system, with Michael Corr, creative director of PLACE, optimistic about the opportunity for councils to develop their own community and development plans. However, concerns are raised about the skills of politicians to handle these responsibilities and the potential for discrimination, as seen in the 1960s with public housing allocation. Environmental group Friends of the Earth warns about the need for a strict code of conduct to ensure fairness and transparency, expressing concern over close relationships between developers and political parties. The group also advocates for public knowledge of political party donors, which becomes increasingly important with politicians having more powers with financial consequences for developers and objectors. Some local politicians oppose this move due to potential donor deterrence and the relevance of the £7,500 limit for declaring donations in Northern Ireland.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was found injured by its owner, Sarah Nisbett, in Winchburgh, Scotland, after being shot three times with an air weapon. The cat was taken to the Scottish SPCA and had to have its left back leg amputated due to the severity of its injuries. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward. The incident has sparked renewed calls for the licensing of air weapons in Scotland, with the Scottish SPCA's Chief Superintendent Mike Flynn stating that the new licensing regime should ensure that only those with a lawful reason are allowed to possess such a dangerous weapon. Last year, the Scottish government held a consultation on licensing air weapons, but a majority of respondents opposed the plan.

Liverpool has signed Belgian international Christian Benteke from Aston Villa on a long-term contract, making him their second most expensive signing. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, was brought in to revive Liverpool's attack after they struggled for goals last season. Liverpool has also signed forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi this summer. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge have expressed their confidence in Benteke's ability to succeed at Liverpool.

The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that tablet usage in schools is rapidly growing, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them to some extent. However, there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using these devices. The highest use of tablet computers was found in academy schools. Despite the lack of definitive connection between tablets and improved results, head teachers reported a positive impact, and they help motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement. The study also found that young people are immersed in technology at school and home, with many pupils taking internet-connected devices to bed for social media. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers are particularly useful for helping boys and poorer pupils learn to read. The use of technology in schools is expected to grow, reflecting the reality of how pupils live at home and what they will find at work.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs that depict the lives of children from the 1880s to the 1990s. The images not only capture moments of childhood but also serve as a social history of Liverpool through the decades. Curated by Kay Jones, the exhibition includes a portrait of the Rollo children from 1887 and a portrait of a young maid from around 1900. The exhibition aims to showcase both the joyful and challenging aspects of childhood experiences. It will be on display until 25 September.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back with experience at Barrow, Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, has joined a National League rival after mutually terminating his Barrow contract. He may face his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, who has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, has also joined the team, subject to international clearance. Manager Nicholson praised Anderson as a leader and Keating as a young, determined player. The team, currently four points above the relegation zone, has only won one of their last six games.

The new Bolivian legislation permits 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's poverty. The law also imposes harsher punishments for child violence, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. Despite UNICEF reporting over 500,000 working children in Bolivia, the International Labour Organization (ILO) suggests children under 15 should not work, but allows a minimum working age of 14 in developing countries. Bolivia's government hopes the law will eradicate extreme poverty. The ILO is currently reviewing the legislation for potential breaches of international child labor regulations.

The 50 year-old woman, actress Rosie O'Donnell, experienced heart attack symptoms and searched her symptoms online, discovering she had "women's heart attack symptoms" such as sudden nausea and aches. She took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, who found a 99% blocked artery and inserted a stent. O'Donnell revealed her heart attack was a "widow maker" type and warned her readers to know the symptoms and call 911. She has acted in various films and TV shows, including Drop Dead Diva, Will and Grace, and Nip/Tuck, and recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network, which was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

A 17-year-old boy named Che Labastide-Wellington from Harrow was fatally stabbed during a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, on Saturday night. The incident occurred around 00:30 GMT in an alleyway following a fight with a group of youths who attempted to enter the party. Che was pronounced dead an hour later. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Police have arrested a 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16 on suspicion of murder, while a third boy aged 14 is held for possession of an offensive weapon. Che was invited to the party and was not involved in an earlier altercation with the group of youths. Police are appealing for witnesses who were near the alleyway during the incident.

The passage describes a new approach to diagnosing cancer patients in Denmark, which was implemented following "quite alarming" survival statistics compared to other European countries. The new model has three routes: 1) Fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with "alarm" symptoms, 2) Diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose, and 3) "Yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms that are unlikely to be cancer but could be in rare cases. The changes have led to better survival rates and have not resulted in a "flooding of the system" by more GP referrals. Denmark's health system is similar to Wales, and there could be lessons shared between the two countries on how better organization can improve cancer diagnosis and treatment.

The passage discusses the establishment of a new service, led by Powys council, which will handle cases related to estate agent laws and dishonest practices. This service is a replacement for the disbanded OFT (Office of Fair Trading) and will be funded with £170,000 annually. Complaints against estate agents will still be initially handled by local authority trading standards departments, but cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act will be referred to Powys. The head of the new team, James Munro, expressed his hope that this role will demonstrate Powys' capability to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The NHS Employers management body has approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong workforce, following recommendations from advisers who suggested additional tasks for staff with more training. The Nuffield Trust review found examples of nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. However, unions warned against using this as a quick fix for NHS problems, such as gaps in junior doctor rotas and struggling GPs. The report highlighted examples of areas already experimenting with workforce reshaping and emphasized the need for more from other health staff due to the changing nature of care. The report's author, Candace Imison, mentioned "huge opportunities" in reshaping the workforce, while NHS Employers chief executive Danny Mortimer supported the report's recommendations. However, British Medical Association leader Dr. Mark Porter cautioned against compromising good quality training for doctors, and Unison head of health Christina McAnea expressed concerns about the lack of funding for training courses.

The Lower Bristol Road in Bath was closed by Avon and Somerset Police after a crash at 03:00 GMT near Rackfield Place outside the First depot. The road closure, which lasted until 14:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The A36 road was affected. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision. First reported that while some services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. The managing director, James Freeman, expressed hope for a full service running in time for the evening commute and gratitude towards the public and staff for their support and efforts during the situation.

The passage discusses a disagreement between Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) and Natural Resources Wales (NRW) regarding the potential impact of the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon project on fish populations. NRW estimates that the lagoon would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year during migration, while TLP disputes these figures and claims that NRW's methodology is not clear. TLP's own computer modeling estimates a worst-case scenario of the lagoon killing 2% of all species of fish. The £1.3bn project is seen as a test bed for larger versions around the coast, and UK government ministers are considering the findings of a review of the scheme's viability. The Welsh Government is supportive of the scheme but needs clarity on the UK government's position. NRW strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism and stands by its own evidence and methodology.

The passage announces a significant move by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster to establish a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland. This body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), is expected to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The agri-food industry in Northern Ireland is described as "hugely important" with almost 100,000 jobs. The new body is likened to the successful Scotland Food and Drink. Stormont's Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomes the announcement, acknowledging the need for better coordination of current marketing activities. However, she notes potential implications for the work of other organizations, including her own department.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree planting project at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon, inviting members of the public to participate. This project is part of a larger initiative to plant "millions" of native UK trees to commemorate the lives lost during WW1. The trust aims to plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood, symbolizing the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who died in the conflict. The charity will provide saplings for planting and advises volunteers to wear appropriate footwear. The location is about seven miles outside Derry city, just off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking available. The project aims to create a living tribute to those affected by the war and a thriving habitat for wildlife.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller about domestic violence and honor crime. The award was presented at the annual crime writing festival in Harrogate, where US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about female private investigator VI Warshawski. Paretsky's character was praised for being a "real game changer" and for changing the way readers thought about female writers. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime, an organization to support female crime writers.

Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner who made his Test debut in 2015, will return to play for Worcestershire's Rapids following the ICC Trophy in June 2017. Santner had previously played for the county in 2016 but broke his finger in his second game, which was a significant blow to the team's qualifying hopes. Santner expressed his enjoyment of his time with Worcestershire and his frustration with the injury, and is looking forward to making an impact with both bat and ball in the upcoming season. In August 2016, Worcestershire signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats of the game.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in a hit-and-run incident on a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was 19 years younger and had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove at the time of the incident. The coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, ruled the death as an unlawful killing, stating that the car had stolen license plates and did not brake or stop. The inquest revealed that Ms Ziuzina tried to claim her husband's assets within days of his death and sold his Range Rover, contents from his flat, and moved funds from his bank account. She was also found to be having an affair with a Ukrainian man. The Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry into his death but relaunched it as a murder inquiry in 2011, which is still active but not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, a boy from Merseyside, urgently needs to return to Seattle, America for T-Cell Therapy, a treatment unavailable in the UK, after his previous transplant failed. Charlie has been ill since he was three and has had three relapses, with the most recent one in April. His family was left heartbroken when the first T-Cell transplant did not work. An anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment, leaving his parents ecstatic and overwhelmed. The family is expecting to find out the date for Charlie's treatment next week.

The passage discusses the use of third-party software to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud, and Apple's response to this security breach. Apple has introduced a two-step verification system to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud, which requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone number or via the Find My iPhone app. However, this security feature remains an opt-in choice, and experts suggest that Apple should make it the default option. The two-step verification system was not previously used when device owners used Apple's backup service, which allowed attackers to download a complete backup of a user's data using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Elcomsoft's owner has acknowledged that Apple's changes guard against this technique. However, there are concerns about the recovery key being hard to remember and potentially being stolen. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage people to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

The passage discusses a potential deal where former footballer and reality TV star Mark Wright could buy 20% of the Billericay Town football club, with the details yet to be finalized. If the deal goes through, Wright would become a club director. Billericay Town currently stands eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off position. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is willing to invest £10,000 a week. The club has also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mr Ashley, owner of Sports Direct and Newcastle United Football Club, has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's working practices. He has until 21 March to respond to a letter from MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. Mr Wright's letter reveals that Mr Ashley had invited the committee to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook, but he has not accepted any of the alternative dates offered. The committee reserves the right to take further action if Mr Ashley fails to agree to attend. The treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage are issues that the committee will be monitoring. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for comment but has previously pledged to review worker rights.

The passage discusses a report titled 'Putin. War' compiled by colleagues of murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, led by Ilya Yashin. The report, based on existing media facts, accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends. Despite Russia's denial of sending troops and armour to help rebels in eastern Ukraine, the report presents evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment being decisive in securing victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. The report also reveals that volunteer soldiers are paid substantial salaries and estimates Russian spending on the conflict at 53bn roubles. The opposition plans to seek donations to extend the report's initial print run, but faces challenges due to fear and lack of interest. The report accuses Putin of masterminding and directing the war to boost his popularity, but it may face the same fate as Nemtsov's earlier reports which failed to galvanise protests against Putin.

Craig Nelson, aged 34 and also known as Craig Preston, was discovered at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire on Monday at 11:00 BST. His death was a result of head injuries, as determined by a post-mortem examination. Nelson was a resident of Wath-Upon-Dearne in Rotherham. Following the incident, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the disagreement between the Welsh government and the UK government regarding the Article 50 letter, which outlines the UK's intention to leave the EU. Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones expresses frustration over not being consulted in the drafting of the letter and feeling disrespected by the UK government. UK Prime Minister Theresa May mentions Wales in the letter, stating that powers will be returned to the UK and that there will be a significant increase in decision-making power for each devolved administration. However, it remains unclear which powers will be devolved and whether funding will accompany these powers. The Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defends the UK government's actions, stating that they are acting in the interests of the whole UK. The passage suggests that the issue of devolved powers and funding is a contentious one, with differing views between the Welsh and UK governments.

In the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry, two cars were damaged during an incident on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his shock over the "mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community". According to a post on the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page, police officers were attacked while performing their duties. The post also urged parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was removed from his position last year due to employee complaints and allegations of misuse of company funds. The board has filed a court case in San Francisco, stating they do not anticipate his return. Mr. Charney's lawyer has disputed these claims, accusing the company of invading his privacy to gain leverage. The court filing includes evidence of inappropriate emails to female employees and racially offensive remarks by Mr. Charney. These allegations are in response to Mr. Charney's defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. The company's documents state that Mr. Charney violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The board believes it would be challenging to find any company willing to hire Mr. Charney due to the potential risk to the company and its shareholders. Recently, a restraining order was granted to prevent Mr. Charney from making negative press statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses a basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The game will take place at the Copper Box in London and is GB's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017. Three members of the Greek team will be missing, giving GB a chance for revenge after their previous loss in Patras, Greece (92-64). GB guard Teddy Okereafor expresses excitement about playing in London and the game's significance in preparing for EuroBasket. After the game, GB will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up games before EuroBasket begins in Istanbul, Turkey.

The passage describes the introduction of the iPhone by Steve Jobs and its revolutionary impact on technology and society. The author, a journalist, was initially skeptical about the iPhone's significance but later realized its transformative potential. The iPhone, with its user-friendly interface, made powerful computing accessible to over two billion people and disrupted various industries, including photography. Despite the existence of cameras and internet capabilities on phones before 2007, the iPhone's attractive user interface made these features more appealing and widely used. The author now appreciates having witnessed the beginning of the mobile connected era, which started with the iPhone's launch in San Francisco.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, several cats, including seven-month-old Meereen, have died due to antifreeze poisoning. The RSPCA confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue had ingested the toxic substance, but it remains unclear whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, expressed her devastation over the loss. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock urged locals to store pesticides and chemicals safely and ensure no antifreeze leaks from their cars, as it is a common substance used during this time of year.

The passage discusses the current situation in Greece, where the Syriza government is preparing to implement more austerity measures, despite previously opposing them. The country's tourism is thriving, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year. However, there are no protests against the announced VAT increases, pension cuts, and potential reductions in farm subsidies. This calm may be due to the upcoming revelation of concessions made by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to secure €86bn in credit from the eurozone and IMF. Tsipras remains popular, although he has not ended fiscal austerity and has caused monetary austerity due to the bank closures. The new bailout will only hold if Tsipras can offer hope of better times ahead, which may require creditors to ease Greece's debt burden. The deal could lead to recovery if Brussels and Berlin avoid triumphalism and offer debt forgiveness.

In the passage, it is revealed that Ross Kemp, who portrayed Grant Mitchell in the TV show EastEnders, will briefly return to the series. His comeback is prompted by the departure of Dame Barbara, who plays Peggy Mitchell, as her character will be killed off due to cancer. Kemp's character, Grant Mitchell, was a significant figure in the soap opera, known for his involvement in family dramas. His return will reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time, leading to what are expected to be classic EastEnders episodes.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon fatally attacked Alice Ruggles, 24, after stalking her due to his obsession. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately knew Dhillon was responsible when informed of her death. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring Alice that ignoring Dhillon would resolve the issue. Prof. Ruggles acknowledged that they didn't realize the severity of the situation despite signs of stalking. Alice's parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking. Dhillon, 26, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

The French company EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point nuclear power plant project in Somerset, with contracts expected to be signed on Friday. However, the UK government has expressed reservations and launched a further review of the project, causing EDF executives to be taken off guard. The project has faced criticism for potential environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign government involvement, with one third of the cost being provided by Chinese investors. The plant is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement. Despite EDF's approval, concerns about the company's financial capacity persist, with some resignations from EDF board members and executives due to the project's financial risks. Environmentalists have also expressed concerns about the project's value for money and the need for more investment in renewable energy.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales includes a field for the name of the person with whom the spouse committed adultery. However, family lawyers advise against naming the third party as it can escalate conflict and complexity. The Ministry of Justice clarified that there is no obligation to name the person, and the form's guidance states it is usually not necessary. Despite this, some lawyers fear that individuals will still name the third party due to the form's design. If named, the third party becomes part of the court case, receiving paperwork and having the opportunity to respond. Delays and additional costs may occur if they do not respond. In 2015, there were over 100,000 divorces in England and Wales, with adultery accounting for 12,148 of them. Lawyers often discourage clients from naming the third party as it can reflect poorly on the petitioner and may be viewed negatively by judges.

The passage discusses the conflict between environmental and commercial forestry interests in Wales. While the timber industry, worth over £450m annually, needs commercial forests to meet its demands, there's been a loss of 16,000 hectares since 2001. Ministers are accused of focusing too much on the environment and native broadleaf species, which is seen as more appealing. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects of forestry development, citing its Glastir scheme. However, the current system is criticized for being too bureaucratic and not planting enough new woodland areas to meet long-term targets. The timber market is strong, with saw millers expressing a need for more timber to increase production.

The boy suffered severe injuries after being hit in Coatbridge. Emergency services were dispatched to the scene on Bank Street, near Langloan Primary School, around 16:40. The boy was then transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is considered serious.

In the passage, Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to the veterans of the Arctic Convoys, a maritime campaign during World War II. The convoys consisted of vessels that traveled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union, facing constant threats from German forces and harsh weather conditions. Over 3,000 men died during the campaign, which Winston Churchill called the "worst journey in the world." The Russian Embassy intended to award the Medal of Ushakov to the survivors in 2012, but the Foreign Office initially blocked the move due to its rules on foreign medals. However, an exception was made, and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals in June 2013. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in defending Russia or its interests.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant delays and issues with offenders completing their unpaid work sentences, also known as "community payback." The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the report's recommendations and promised action. Unpaid work sentences range from 40 to 300 hours for offenses like theft and drug offenses. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to perform tasks such as gardening and litter-picking. The report identified organizational difficulties, with offenders often leading chaotic lives and struggling to attend work on time. The inspection found instances of high-quality work and offenders viewing their sentences positively, but overall, the system was deemed inadequate. The chief inspector of probation called for urgent improvements, and the Ministry of Justice expressed commitment to more effective rehabilitation.

The comedian and activist Russell Brand has been accused of hypocrisy by The Sun newspaper for advocating for economic and political revolution to help poorer people while living in a luxury home. Brand has been criticized for this in the past, and he has addressed the issue by acknowledging that he needs to change as an individual and share his wealth. However, he also emphasizes that personal change is not enough and that systemic change is necessary to address economic disparity and ecological disaster. Brand has been unresponsive to requests for comment on potential legal action against The Sun and its owner Rupert Murdoch.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the human genome mapping process by turning it into a competitive race, which led to criticism from the scientific community. Despite his controversial methods, his efforts significantly sped up the process. After publishing the human genome, Venter focused on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in the organism Synthia. Venter's determination to become a doctor and his conviction for not wasting time stemmed from his experiences as a naval field hospital orderly during the Vietnam War. He excelled in research and realized the importance of decoding genes, leading him to use automated decoding machines. Venter's breakthrough came when he focused on messenger molecules instead of the entire genome, allowing him to produce gene sequences at unprecedented rates. His success led to the formation of his private research institute and the commercial company Celera Genomics, which aimed to crack the entire human genetic code in three years. Venter's disregard for scientific conventions brought him criticism but also financial rewards, enabling him to pursue his scientific goals independently. In 2006, he formed the J Craig Venter Institute to create the world's first synthetic life form. Venter has also collected life forms from the ocean to better understand the evolution and function of genes and proteins. His synthetic life breakthrough was controversial but could potentially create a new industrial revolution by helping wean us off oil and reverse environmental damage.

In England, a study found that 80% of children who had school lunches tried foods they hadn't eaten at home. Half of the surveyed parents reported their children requested school foods to be served at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were the least popular. The research was commissioned by England's School Food Trust after a Mumsnet survey suggested some parents gave their children packed lunches due to their fussiness. The Trust's chairman, Rob Rees, stated that school meals can help children try new foods and diversify their diets. Mumsnet co-founder, Carrie Longton, added that school meals have improved and offer healthier options, encouraging children to eat a variety of foods. Currently, 40% of primary school children in England have school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools. The survey was conducted online among parents with at least one child aged 4-17 years old.

Álvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker, has been a standout player for Juventus since joining from Real Madrid in 2014. His transfer included a buy-back option for Real Madrid, reportedly up to 30m euros (£23m). Morata has been linked with Arsenal and Chelsea and has scored three times for Spain at Euro 2016. In his two years at Juventus, he scored 27 goals, won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and played in consecutive Champions League finals, scoring in the 2015 defeat to Barcelona. Morata began his career at Real Madrid, making his debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson, aged 30, returned to Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013. He was released in May and has been without a team since. During his second spell at Forest, he made 51 appearances. Prior to his time at Celtic, he spent four seasons at Forest. His career also includes stints at Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the British supermarket giant and third largest retailer globally, is selling its unprofitable US food chain, Fresh & Easy. Approximately 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will be transferred to the new business under the deal. Tesco will loan the new business around £80m. Fresh & Easy, operating 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona since 2007, has been losing money. Tesco will incur £150m to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand, but part of it is a loan that may be repaid. If Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm focused on supermarket and restaurant businesses, makes Fresh & Easy profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits in 20 years in April.

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse initially but overcame it. He contemplated representing France but ultimately decided to target a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The passage also mentions a special guide for those interested in getting into martial arts.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields of Mont Blanc and surrounding European Alps covered approximately 375 sq km, which decreased to about 275 sq km by the late 2000s. This represents an average loss of 26% over the last 40 years. The new French Alps glaciers inventory, presented at the AGU Fall Meeting, was produced by Marie Gardent and colleagues. They assessed around 600 glaciers using map archives, past satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual inspection to verify the data. The greatest losses have been seen in the southern sectors, with glaciers almost completely disappearing in the Belledonne Massif and retreating more than three times stronger in the Ecrins Massif than in the Mont Blanc Massif. The retreat is less important in the northern Alps due to lower elevation and different climatic conditions. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has also seen a slight decrease in size.

The Scottish women's football team, currently ranked 21st in the world, is on the brink of securing their place in the Netherlands for next summer's finals. They have won all five qualifiers to date and will host Iceland, ranked 20th, at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. A victory would almost guarantee their spot. The team is determined to avoid the heartbreak of previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and last year's World Cup. The outcome of Friday's match and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September will likely decide who tops the group. The team is led by Bayern Munich forward Jane Evans, who believes that the team's chances are high despite the tough competition from Iceland. The Scottish team is bolstered by 12 players who play outside Scotland, including Evans, who recently won the women's Bundesliga in her first season at Bayern. She believes that the experience of playing in top leagues around the world benefits the national team as they aim for their first major finals.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger, was arrested in the west of England following a complaint from a woman in south London. The woman alleged harassment over a two-year period, which Campbell stated was related to some tweets from his Twitter account. He denied that the tweets were threatening and accused the media of creating "innuendo" to encourage speculation. Campbell was released on bail and is due for further inquiries in mid-September. He stated that nothing more serious than some tweets had occurred or been alleged to have occurred.

The animal rights group PETA is advocating for the replacement of the Skegness mascot, Jolly Fisherman, with a more animal-friendly version, suggesting a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice". The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, welcomes suggestions but does not anticipate much support for Jolly's removal. The Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway and has since become a symbol of the Lincolnshire resort. However, PETA's Dawn Carr argues that Jolly represents cruelty to animals, such as fish being impaled and animals being crushed in nets. PETA believes their suggestion could rebrand Skegness as a progressive holiday destination where animal cruelty is not celebrated. Mayor Macey, however, states that Jolly is loved by all and does not portray animal cruelty, adding that if the current mascot is not broken, there's no need to fix it.

The Scottish rugby team dominated their match against Georgia, with the final score being 43-16 in favor of Scotland. Scotland's tries were scored by Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (2), and Hamish Watson. Georgia's tries were both scored by Vasil Lobzhanidze. Scotland led 24-11 at halftime and continued to control the game in the second half. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised his team's performance and their approach to the game.

In the first half of the rugby match, Widnes took a 14-6 lead over Castleford, with tries from Leuluai, Ah Van, and Bridge, while Flynn scored for Castleford. Flynn scored again early in the second half, but Widnes extended their lead with tries from Ah Van, White (2), and Mellor, making it 38-12. Despite three quick tries from Castleford's Patrick, Gale, and Flynn, Widnes held on for the win. Widnes had a comfortable lead after Mellor took advantage of Castleford's indecision, but their defense faltered, allowing Castleford to make it a close finish. Widnes moved above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth, just one point above Widnes. The teams' lineups are also provided.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from the US detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, where he had been held since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban. He had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. A US review panel concluded that he was not a "continuing significant threat" and released him. Upon release, he will spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. His release was a result of efforts by the Kuwaiti government to secure freedom for all Kuwaiti detainees at Guantanamo. Mr. Odah had claimed he was in Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. His release brings the total number of inmates at Guantanamo down to 148. The US opened the facility in 2002 following the 9/11 attacks, and President Obama has repeatedly promised to shut it down.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, was observed with thousands attending early morning services at Hyde Park Corner and Westminster Abbey. The day marks the anniversary of the Anzac (Australian and New Zealand Army Corps) landings at Gallipoli in 1915. The services have become a significant event for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, honoring the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars. The dawn service included a parade, wreath-laying at the Cenotaph, and speeches, such as one by Alexander Downer, Australian high commissioner to the UK. The Gallipoli campaign was one of the bloodiest of the war, with allied forces attempting to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer, has recently joined St Mirren for a second spell and could debut against Alloa in the Championship on Saturday. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has been mainly a substitute this term. Clarkson, who has been capped twice for Scotland and has almost 400 senior club appearances, has previously played for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of the bottom side Alloa. Clarkson expressed his readiness for the upcoming game and his desire to help the club move up the table.

The turkey firm, Bernard Matthews, was acquired by food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. Despite initial concerns, the new owners have agreed to honor existing workers' pension schemes. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and current employees have an alternative pension scheme that remains unaffected by the takeover. Boparan Private Office confirmed that the current pension arrangements will continue under the new ownership. The new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitable status through greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkeys.

The passage discusses the issues surrounding a new vessel at the Cowes crossing, which has faced a "frustrating and disappointing start." The ferry has experienced breakdowns, groundings, and suspensions due to training issues since its launch on 14 May. Additionally, cars have been damaged while boarding and disembarking. Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing would be free until 2 July to acknowledge the problems and gather feedback. He also mentioned that the council has ordered a review of the project by auditors. Local businesses, such as shopkeeper Angie Booth's Valu-4-U, have been negatively impacted by the loss of trade due to the ferry issues. The question of compensating local businesses is under discussion. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated that the ferry is a prototype and bound to have teething problems, such as electrical issues, which have been rectified. The council has also authorized the manufacture of ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage. Groundings were attributed to seamanship issues, which have been resolved.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. The industry, which only contributes 0.5% to the GDP and employs 12,000 fishers, may be at risk of being marginalized in the wider Brexit negotiations. The industry dislikes the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) due to its quotas and equal access principle, which led many in the industry to campaign for Brexit. However, the House of Lords European Union Committee warns that the UK may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal. The report also suggests that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit and the UK should ensure that total allowable catches and quotas should continue to be based on scientific advice. The UK will also continue to be under international obligations to co-operate with neighbouring states. The report also raises concerns about the potential of four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry still argue that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats. The government has stated that it wants to ensure British companies have the maximum freedom to trade with and operate in the single market, while also reviewing fisheries management for fair access to quota, sustainable stocks and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney, a teacher, admitted to taking or allowing indecent images of young boys to be taken between 2004 and 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to attend a sex offenders program. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was removed from the teaching register due to his offenses being fundamentally incompatible with the standards expected of the profession. The panel found a strong likelihood of the behavior recurring due to the volume of images and duration of the conduct, and prohibited him from re-registering for two years. Geaney was not present at the hearing.

Firefighters battled a blaze at the Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited site on Duncan Street on 2 March, causing travel disruptions. The Environment Agency suspended the company from accepting waste following the incident. Despite being "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the company was unable to be reached for comment and has until 7 August to appeal the suspension. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had visited the site nine times in the past year, raising concerns about potential fire impact on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The Environment Agency decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, after which the company will no longer be able to operate at the site and must remove all waste. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

Syria is in the process of destroying its chemical weapons, but has missed the recent deadline due to attacks on shipments by terrorist groups, according to Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad. Syria has only handed over about 4% of its 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons so far. The US and Russia have expressed concern over the delay. The Syrian government denies using barrel bombs in Aleppo and accuses the US of supporting terrorist elements. There are conflicting reports about rebels seizing control of Aleppo's central prison. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims rebels have taken control, while state television insists soldiers have thwarted the attack. Syria is committed to fulfilling its obligations to destroy its chemical weapons, according to al-Mekdad.

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford by a significant margin, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, setting up their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and 71 not out in the second, as well as contributing with the ball and in the field. Pakistan struggled, batting for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second on a pitch that offered little assistance to the bowlers. The series is expected to be tight, with Pakistan playing a tour game against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is launching a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners, their families, and friends to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review aims to highlight good care practices while also addressing poor care and its impact on older people. Rochira has observed the positive effects of high-quality care during her travels across Wales but has also received concerns about the quality of life and care in residential homes. The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care Forum Wales chair Mario Kreft expressed support for the review's goals but expressed disappointment that no care provider expert is included in the main advisory panel.

Former Aberdeen midfielder Paul Sheerin, aged 39, has been appointed as the new manager at Pittodrie, succeeding Neil Cooper. Sheerin has been serving as player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, but the team was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing last in League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser stated that manager Derek McInnes selected Sheerin after a thorough process. Sheerin, who has played for various Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, has also won a Scotland Under-21 cap. He led Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and securing promotion in 2011.

The passage discusses the management changes at Swansea City Football Club following the sacking of Bob Bradley. Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of the upcoming match against Bournemouth. The club aims to appoint a new boss soon, with Paul Clement as the preferred choice. Curtis, a former player, believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. He suggests that the constant change in management and loss of key players have diluted the 'Swansea Way'. Despite this, Curtis is confident that the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation. He emphasizes the importance of staying in the Premier League for the club and the local community.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the human genome mapping process, which earned him both acclaim and criticism from the scientific community. Despite his controversial methods, his work led to significant advancements in the field of genomics. After mapping the human genome, he embarked on another ambitious project: creating a synthetic life form, Synthia. Venter's determination to become a doctor was inspired by his experiences as a naval field hospital orderly during the Vietnam War. His research career began at the US National Institute of Health, where he recognized the importance of decoding genes. Venter's breakthrough came when he focused on messenger molecules instead of the entire genome, allowing him to produce gene sequences at unprecedented rates. He left the NIH in 1992 to establish a private research institute and later founded Celera Genomics, which aimed to map the human genetic code in three years. In 2006, he formed the J Craig Venter Institute to create the world's first synthetic life form. Venter has also pursued other projects, such as collecting life forms from the ocean to better understand the evolution and function of genes and proteins. His work has been met with controversy, but he remains optimistic about the potential of synthetic microbes to revolutionize industries and help address environmental issues.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short compared to other European countries, particularly Germany. The report suggests that only 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to over half in Germany. The report also notes that England's vocational system has 18,000 different qualifications, while Germany has 330. The report calls for apprenticeships to be expanded, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, the majority of which should be at level three or above and last for at least three years. The Association of Colleges agrees that there is a need for more apprenticeships but notes that creating 300,000 new ones would be a massive challenge. The Department for Education says it is already reforming apprenticeships to drive up standards.

The British Paralympian, Sarah Storey, secured her 16th world title in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey, who is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, is aiming for further success at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Paralympics. Her illustrious career includes 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze medals across six Paralympics in both cycling and swimming. She won four golds at the 2012 London Games and has now won 21 world titles in both sports. Storey started her sporting journey in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before transitioning to cycling in 2005.

The Hereford United football club, known as the Bulls, has been expelled from the Conference Premier league due to financial troubles. Despite a dramatic final-day escape that sent Chester down instead, the Bulls failed to meet multiple payment deadlines to clear their debts to football creditors, which amounted to £148,000. The club's overall debts were approximately £225,000, including over £70,000 owed to HMRC. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust had offered to buy the club for £1 and clear the debts, but this was not the preferred option. The club's financial woes have been ongoing since their relegation from the Football League in 2012, with average attendances dropping significantly. Chester has been reinstated as a Conference Premier club and Hayes & Yeading will stay in Conference South.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, retired from the England national team after earning 61 caps since his debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played three minutes in Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers. Milner expressed his best wishes for the team's future success under new manager Sam Allardyce.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and a key figure in the early-music movement, passed away following a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for later. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and led it for three decades, during which they made over 200 CDs, including a complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His notable recordings include a 1980 version of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood was a tutor at Harvard and held honorary positions at Cambridge and Cornell universities. He was praised for his generosity of spirit and his contributions to historically informed music. His successor at AAM, Richard Egarr, and soprano Dame Emma Kirkby, among others, paid tribute to his legacy and character.

The passage discusses a family from Northern Ireland with a son who has special needs and is currently unable to attend school. The boy's parents made the decision to remove him from mainstream schooling in June due to his struggles in coping. Despite requesting a place for him at a special school, they are still waiting for an opening as all special schools in their area are at full capacity. The boy's mother expresses her son's longing to be around people and his dislike for isolation, which has been exacerbated by the situation. The family has been informed that an extra classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school, and they hope their son can start attending soon. However, the mother fears that other families will face similar situations due to the overcapacity of the special needs school system. The Education Authority, when asked for comment, stated they cannot discuss individual cases due to privacy concerns but mentioned they are reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure availability close to children's residences.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is planning a takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons and views Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. However, Newport County has a lease to use the ground until 2023, with fixture priority if they remain in the Football League. The WRU's takeover bid will be voted on May 9. Newport County secured a 10-year lease in 2013 after promotion to the Football League. Newport RFC chairman confirmed that both County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. On the pitch, County is two points clear of relegation with two games left, and can secure survival with a win and a Hartlepool loss. Foxall stated that relegation to the National League would be a significant blow to fans and the city of Newport.

The passage describes the experiences of an individual who was kidnapped by rebels during the civil war in Sierra Leone, which ended in 2002. After escaping and being helped by a preacher named Richard Cole, the individual became involved in efforts to rebuild the nation. During the Ebola crisis in 2014, they worked to educate communities about the virus, provide support through food and supplies, and establish an Ebola treatment unit. Despite witnessing tragic incidents, such as a pregnant woman with suspected Ebola, the individual remains hopeful about the future and the role of young people in changing the world.

In summary, the Wedgwood Museum's collection of around 80,000 artworks, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs was at risk of being auctioned off to settle the pottery firm's pension debt. However, a public fundraising campaign led by The Art Fund successfully raised the required funds within a month. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum. The collection, which is significant for Staffordshire and charts a crucial part of Britain's cultural development, was at risk of being sold and scattered globally if the funds were not raised.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal, which could see Mark Wright acquire 20% of Billericay Town FC, are yet to be disclosed. According to The Sun, Wright, aged 30, is expected to become a club director. Currently, Billericay Town FC is positioned eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points short of a play-off spot. Wright's football career includes non-league stints at clubs such as Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds, and he was also the runner-up in the 2011 edition of I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here. The club has recently been acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed his comfort in investing £10,000 weekly in the club. Furthermore, the club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky, aged 35.

In this football match between Blackpool and Colchester United, the Seasiders took the lead in the 12th minute with a goal by Jamille Matt from three yards. Colchester equalized from a corner after 17 minutes through Kurtis Guthrie. Despite several chances for both teams, including a missed header by Tom Aldred from eight yards and a saved close-range effort by George Elokobi, the score remained 1-1. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

The disused Fawley power station, commissioned in 1971 on the western shore of Southampton Water, is planned to be transformed into a "merchant city" development, featuring a marina, housing, and restaurants. The development's centerpiece will be a petal-shaped glass structure atop the existing 198-metre-high chimney, making it the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. The 300-acre site, sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016, was capable of powering one million homes when it was a 2,000 megawatt oil-fired power station. The development, estimated to cost £1bn, will also include fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth, with an application for outline planning permission due later this year and building potentially starting in 2018.

In the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old Latham won Britain's second medal, a bronze, in the men's points race, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Latham chased down Adrian Teklinski of Poland, who won gold, and Lucass Liss of Germany, who got silver. In the men's team pursuit, GB lost the bronze to Italy. Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final, and the women's team pursuit finished fifth in the heats, failing to make the bronze-medal ride. Olympic gold medallist Chris Boardman praised Latham's final charge, while six-time Olympic gold medallist Sir Chris Hoy commended Latham's positioning and energy management. Elinor Barker, also an Olympic gold medallist, led a young squad in the women's team pursuit, finishing fifth. Katy Marchant was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round.

In the passage, it is revealed that Ross Kemp, who portrayed Grant Mitchell in the TV show EastEnders, will briefly return to the series following a 10-year absence. His return is prompted by the storyline involving the death of Peggy Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara, who is a close friend of Kemp. The Mitchell brothers, Grant and Phil, will reunite to bid farewell to their mother. The character of Grant Mitchell has been a significant part of the soap opera since 1990, known for his involvement in various family dramas. The executive producer of EastEnders, Dominic Treadwell-Collins, anticipates that this reunion will showcase the acting talents of Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden.

In the match at Anfield, Sadio Mane scored twice in quick succession as Tottenham Hotspur, who are second in the Premier League, had a disappointing performance. Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino expressed his disappointment in the team's lack of desire to win and stated that it would be difficult for them to challenge for the Premier League title if they continued to perform in this manner. Chelsea has the opportunity to extend their lead at the top of the table if they win against Burnley. Pochettino also mentioned that Tottenham's poor away form, with only two wins since September, is a concern. Danny Murphy, a former Liverpool and Tottenham player, commented on Match of the Day that Tottenham's defensive performance was poor and that they should have stuck with their usual back three formation against the big sides. He also noted that Tottenham's lack of pace and different mindset away from home is a concern.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC's victory was widespread across northern states and Nigeria's commercial hub, Lagos, while the PDP held on to eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The PDP's decline was further emphasized by their loss in key northern states and states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, they managed to retain control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose a challenge for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but were generally more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP, which was in power for 16 years, will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader following widespread allegations of corruption and criticism for not doing enough to end the Islamist-led insurgency in the north-east.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July will be able to use an app to access augmented reality content, including videos and band interviews. The festival features acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The app aims to enhance the festival experience and allow global interaction with the event. The app's content will be updated leading up to and during the festival, providing real-time information, interviews, and ticket purchasing options.

The passage discusses the termination of funding agreements for Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running these schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools revealed that parents tried to undermine her authority and spoke to an inspector about her. She felt alone and considered quitting but found solace when news of the Trojan Horse letter broke. On Monday, Ofsted published 21 reports into schools allegedly targeted as part of a hardline Muslim takeover, with five schools rated inadequate. Birmingham City Council will work with Saltley School, the only local authority school placed in special measures, to install a temporary governing board. Education minister Lord Nash expressed deep concerns about the way Park View School was run and decided to terminate its funding agreement. Similar letters were sent to Nansen Primary School and Oldknow Academy, setting out a list of actions to be taken before 4 July. These included ending "less favourable" treatment of non-Muslims, ceasing segregation of boys and girls, and drawing up a plan to ensure a more "broad and balanced" curriculum. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw said a culture of fear and intimidation had taken grip in Birmingham schools. Parents at the schools criticized Ofsted's reports and accused inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, also known as Vinnie, passed away in July 2012, five months after undergoing a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution argued at Ipswich Crown Court that the performance of eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, was so far below the expected standard that it was "criminal". Ms. Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The prosecution alleges that Ms. Rose failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the routine test and refer him for further investigation. This failure led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing pressure in his skull and ultimately causing his death. The prosecution claims that Vinnie's death was preventable and would not have occurred if Ms. Rose had done her job properly. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity with a man he found through an adult website and filming them between September 2013 and 2014. He also sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day 2014. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and was remanded ahead of sentencing. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh due to its greater sentencing powers. Weatherhogg was assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

Ireland made 165-5 in a T20 match against Afghanistan, with Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 no), and captain William Porterfield (39) contributing significantly.
