However, Afghanistan won the match with 171-4, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). Porterfield felt Ireland fell short of a bigger score and could have added 15 more runs. The Irish also suffered from the loss of paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem. The teams will meet again for the second T20 on Friday.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar in the summer, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. However, the total cost including wages, agents fees, and taxes will amount to £106.8m over his five-year deal. Barcelona is under investigation for potential tax-related crimes in relation to the transfer, and former president Sandro Rosell is also being investigated for misappropriation of funds. Barcelona denies any wrongdoing and has made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to cover any potential interpretations of their tax obligations. Neymar has scored 7 goals in 18 league appearances and 3 goals in 7 Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

In summary, the bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, have been accused of the killings and are facing charges of conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery. They could potentially receive the death penalty if found guilty. However, there have been concerns raised about the police investigation, specifically regarding the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. UK police officers have been working with Thai police and have now completed their review of the investigation. They will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families of the victims. Post-mortem examinations revealed that Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police claim that DNA found on Witheridge matches samples taken from the suspects.

The Scottish women's football team, currently ranked 21st in the world, is on the brink of securing their place in the Netherlands for next summer's finals. They have won all five qualifiers to date and will host Iceland, ranked 20th, at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. A victory would almost guarantee their spot. The team has suffered play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the last World Cup, making this opportunity crucial to avoid further heartbreak. The outcome of Friday's match and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September will likely determine the group's topper. The team is led by Bayern Munich forward Jane Evans, who is one of 12 players in the current squad playing outside Scotland. Evans recently celebrated winning the women's Bundesliga in her first season at Bayern. The team's success is attributed to the benefits of having more players in the world's top leagues, which Evans believes has improved the national team's competitiveness.

The passage discusses Apple's implementation of a two-step verification system to enhance the security of its iCloud service following a celebrity photo hack. This system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or phone number after entering their username and password on a new device. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and iTunes, iBooks, or App Store purchases is denied. Users can regain access with a 14-character recovery key. Previously, the two-step verification did not apply to device backups, allowing hackers to download complete backups using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Elcomsoft's owner confirmed his software was likely used in the hacks but acknowledged that Apple's changes now guard against this technique. Apple plans to encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords. Some experts suggest that two-factor authentication should be the default setting for all users.

In the 2014 European election campaign, UKIP spent the most at £2,956,737, followed closely by the Conservatives at £2,980,815. Labour spent £1,027,339 and came second, while the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs. The Green Party spent £534,249 and came fourth. The SNP spent £267,372. The total spending of these six parties was £9,347,087. UKIP spent 68p per vote, Labour 26p, Conservatives 79p, Lib Dems £1.45, and the Green Party 43p. All parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 campaign.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back with experience in Italy and English clubs like Aldershot and Exeter, has left Barrow to join another National League team. He could potentially face his old club on 18 February. Meanwhile, 21-year-old striker Keating has been signed by Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson, following a recommendation from ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating's previous clubs include Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. The Gulls, currently four points above the relegation zone and struggling with form, hope to benefit from Anderson's leadership and Keating's ambition.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". Despite showing symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, Many Clouds had no significant underlying health issues and had never collapsed before. The horse had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. The report concludes that Many Clouds was the victim of a haemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack.

The passage describes the farewell speeches of several MSPs, including Alex Salmond, Duncan McNeil, and Tricia Marwick, who are standing down ahead of the election on 5 May. Alex Salmond, former First Minister, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the need for the parliament to assume greater responsibility for the country's governance. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling the pledges made during the referendum campaign. Salmond concluded his address by saying there is no greater honor than being a member of the parliament and serving the people of Scotland. Tricia Marwick thanked Salmond for his service. Duncan McNeil, a Scottish Labour backbencher, warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system and accountability. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, humorously mentioned her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage discusses the upcoming live-action film adaptation of Beauty and the Beast. Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens playing the Beast and Luke Evans as the villain Gaston. The character of Mrs Potts, originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version, will be played by a star who remains unnamed. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. Josh Gad, known for his role in Frozen, will play Gaston's sidekick LeFou. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and is set to begin filming in May at Shepperton Studios, with a release date of 17 March 2017 in US cinemas.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will disclose its decisions at a private meeting with the victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. The meeting pertains to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 football fans were fatally injured. The CPS will decide on charges for 23 suspects, with 15 related to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and 8 related to an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into the conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police following the incident. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died in the disaster, expressed hope for closure and accountability.

The passage discusses the issue of contraband items being thrown over the walls of Chelmsford Prison, as reported by both prison staff and a nearby resident. A former inmate claims the prison is "notorious" for being inundated with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, and suggests that drones are used to deliver these items directly to prison windows. However, the Ministry of Justice denies any evidence of drone activity at the Chelmsford site. The Justice Secretary has asked for measures to be put in place to tackle this problem, and new laws have been introduced that could result in a two-year jail sentence for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot remember if the traffic lights were red or green. He denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn, a mother of three and a lollipop lady for 20 years, is now being treated in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner who has decided not to participate in the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. Muir recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, achieving a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the latter event. Despite her disappointment in missing the Commonwealth Games, Muir is optimistic about her future in athletics, aiming for at least two or three more Olympics. She also mentioned the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target, but her studies will be her main focus in the coming months.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man from County Kildare, Ireland, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search operation began early on a Saturday morning at a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, along the R112 road leading to the River Liffey. The search, expected to take several weeks, involves excavations and is led by the Gardaí. Earlier this year, a team of six detectives started a comprehensive review of Deely's disappearance, enhancing CCTV footage from the night he went missing using specialized technology. The footage shows Deely talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked. It is believed that Deely was returning to get an umbrella after the party. The detectives released the footage in April and appealed for the man to come forward, as they suspect he was the same man seen following Deely on Haddington Road shortly after. On the day of the search, the Gardaí stated that the man from the CCTV has not been identified yet and renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, the 165th ranked Argentine, secured a 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-4 victory over Stan Wawrinka in the second round of the Grand Slam. Del Potro, who has been struggling with injuries for the past few years, is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray and will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Nick Kyrgios, the 15th seed, also remains on course to meet Murray in the last 16 after coming from two sets to one down to beat Dustin Brown. Feliciano Lopez will play Kyrgios in the third round, with the winner of that tie then playing either Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Elsewhere, there were routine victories for Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

Tunisia was initially facing expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) during the 2015 Nations Cup. However, after apologizing to Caf, their participation was secured. Morocco, on the other hand, was only able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban on its participation. Morocco had been punished in February for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola virus fears. The ban was lifted, and the fine was reduced from $1m to $50,000. Equatorial Guinea stepped in to host the 2015 finals. Tunisia's dispute with Caf stemmed from a contentious penalty decision in their quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, which led to a 2-1 loss in extra time. Tunisia wrote a furious letter to Caf but did not accuse them or the referee of corruption. After a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou, the dispute was resolved, and Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was confirmed.

The McLaren racing team, with a prestigious history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently struggling. Their decline began in 2013 due to issues with chassis design, and now they face problems with the Honda power-unit. Despite their current difficulties, they have two world champions in their lineup, including Fernando Alonso, considered one of the best drivers. The team's history has been a cycle of triumph and decline, with their first decade focused on building up the team, followed by periods of dominance in the 1980s and 1990s. Despite recent scandals and a lack of wins, team principal Ron Dennis insists that success will return, and they will be the next team to win the title after Mercedes. The team's reputation and Alonso's career rest on this belief.

On 6 October 2014, a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven led to a police investigation. The police found that alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST, despite licensing hours. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The court heard that the premises had not been run properly and had been operating well into the morning. Ms. O'Neill, the license holder, was described as having an "appalling record." The judge ordered the closure of the bar for three months, fined Ms. O'Neill £3,000, and fined Mr. Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry entered the game four shy of his previous mark of 272 three-pointers, which he set two years ago. He hit six before halftime and eight overall, teaming with Klay Thompson to bring the Warriors back from a 13-point deficit. Elsewhere, Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds as the Chicago Bulls easily wiped out a 19-point halftime deficit to deal a huge blow to Miami's playoff hopes. The Bulls were outscored 33-12 in the second quarter but went on a staggering 39-8 run to open the second half. Miami missed its first 12 shots after halftime, and the freefall never stopped. The Heat were outscored 57-27 after halftime.

In this passage, Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen arrived at Melwood. They were led to believe that van Velzen was a competition winner who had won the opportunity to meet the Anfield stars and receive a dead-ball masterclass. However, it soon became clear that van Velzen was no ordinary fan, as he showcased his impressive free-kick skills in front of the Liverpool players. Van Velzen has gained popularity on YouTube by uploading videos of his free-kick exploits and he certainly impressed the Liverpool quartet. The players were amazed by van Velzen's skills and enjoyed the experience of playing football with their idol. Van Velzen also had a surprise for Balotelli, as he unveiled the Liverpool forward's infamous slogan.

The passage discusses a study that found women carrying the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Hollywood star Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed. The procedure, called an oophorectomy, was found to be associated with a significant drop of 62% in breast cancer death in women with a BRCA1 mutation. The study, published in JAMA Oncology, found that the protective effect of oophorectomy against breast cancer was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The authors called for follow-up studies on women who undergo oophorectomy as part of their initial treatment, particularly those who had the surgery within a year of diagnosis. The results were found to be particularly effective for survival benefit in women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. Women with a significant family history of breast cancer may have an increased risk of getting the disease, and genetic tests are available to women who are likely to have a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation. BRCA gene faults are more common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population. Angelina Jolie, who has the BRCA1 gene mutation, had an oophorectomy and said that having her ovaries removed did not make her feel any less womanly.

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, aged 38 and 33 respectively, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina, on Easter Sunday. The incident occurred around 10 am on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. The train, No. 80, The Carolinian, was en route from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 passengers on board were injured, although one man fell ill during the delay and received treatment. The train resumed its journey after a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes. The couple may have been homeless, as suggested by a man who met them while collecting scrap metal. The train's next destination was Raleigh, located about 25 miles from Durham.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. After retiring due to declining health, Toro is now facing deportation and is technically living in the US illegally. Despite being one of the DEA's most important assets and aiding in the prosecution of high-profile criminals such as Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, Toro has not been granted citizenship and is living in fear of being sent back to Colombia, where he believes he will be killed. The DEA has refused to help Toro with his citizenship and he is currently in limbo while trying to obtain a green card or passport. He is unable to collect social security benefits until he secures one of these documents.

The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is looking into the actions of Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd., which is using the '.sucks' domain name to charge exorbitant fees from celebrities and companies to protect their reputations. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have reportedly paid to have their names removed from these domains. Vox Populi has sold domain names such as youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, visa.sucks, bankofamerica.sucks, yahoo.sucks, and telusmobility.sucks. ICANN initially approved the '.sucks' domain but is now backtracking after complaints from an advisory panel. Vox Populi has recommended charging $2,499 a year for the domain name, and most names have been sold by resellers for around $2,000 a year. ICANN has sent a letter to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to see if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. If found to be illegal, ICANN could declare the company in breach of its contract and seek to change its behavior.

In 1988, an unnamed baby boy's body was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. The mother, who had concealed her pregnancy, admitted to placing the stillborn baby in the pond. The case remained unsolved until 2015 when DNA evidence led to the mother's identification. She was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped after she explained the circumstances. The baby was reburied in the churchyard and named Peter after the church. The mother remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

In 2010, taxi driver Michael Young mistakenly believed his passenger, Kristopher Hicks, was planning to leave without paying. Young decided to drive Hicks back to the taxi rank, but Hicks jumped out of the moving vehicle due to the driver's actions, suffering severe brain injuries. Hicks now requires round-the-clock care. The High Court ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, and the driver was ordered to pay compensation, with the exact amount yet to be decided but expected to be around hundreds of thousands of pounds. The judge determined a 50% reduction in damages due to Hicks' decision to jump from the moving vehicle. Both parties were given permission to appeal, and a further hearing will decide the final compensation amount.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as multiple storms brought reports of tornadoes. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, moving northeast and potentially threatening other communities, while other sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas. The storms also affected Missouri, with a possible tornado touching down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and property damage. More storms are expected in various regions on Thursday.

In the upcoming middleweight fight in New Jersey, Luke Rockhold is determined to be the aggressor against Lyoto Machida. Rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive win and a potential title shot. He plans to dominate Machida by being the "bull" to Machida's "matador" style. Rockhold believes he has identified weaknesses in Machida's fighting style and intends to exploit them. Despite respecting Machida's martial arts skills and long career, Rockhold is confident in his own abilities and plans to showcase his style and dominate the fight. Meanwhile, Machida is also confident in his strategy and believes he can stop Rockhold, aiming for a title shot after this fight. Both fighters are well-prepared and coming off recent victories.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, was captured on video making a belly landing at the Aero Acres Residential Airpark. The plane touched down without its landing gear deployed, causing its propellers to ricochet off the ground and its wings to bounce. The pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, managed to re-engage the engines and take off, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landing safely. The incident is being investigated by the FAA, with human error or mechanical fault being the most common causes of such gear-up landings.

Manuel Pellegrini, Manchester City's manager, has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season but has vowed to support him until the end of the season. Despite rumors of Manchester City listening to offers for Toure, Pellegrini has stated that Toure is a crucial player and will have his support. Toure has been criticized for his performances amidst Manchester City's faltering Premier League campaign. Pellegrini himself faces questions about his future with the club. Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart has stated that the players must take responsibility for their performances and that Pellegrini has the backing of the dressing room. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has warned left-back Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players by moving to Manchester City, citing the examples of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair who did not play much after joining the club. Allardyce believes Cresswell is an attractive prospect due to his impressive season and his ability to help clubs fill homegrown player quotas.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the 'Godfather of Uxbridge', will be allowed to remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was given a seven-year sentence by an Italian court in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. He was arrested on a European arrest warrant in 2013 and lost his battle against extradition in February. However, it emerged that Rancadore's case expired last October and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. Rancadore's solicitor, Karen Todner, said she was confident that the Italian government would now withdraw their application for a European arrest warrant and that Rancadore would be discharged from these proceedings. The case will still have to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court, according to the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS).

The passage discusses a Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, where Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of the three 7-2 co-favourites alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. Mr. Mole is trained by Paul Nicholls, while Sprinter Sacre is trained by Nicky Henderson and will be ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. AP McCoy and Mr. Mole will face six rivals in the race. Notably, this will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. The line-up for McCoy's final day as a professional jockey will be finalized on Friday morning. Ironically, McCoy had announced his intention to quit riding after winning with Mr. Mole at Newbury in February. Other runners in the Celebration Chase include Somersby, trained by Mick Channon.

In 1975, Marcia, the daughter of Virginia Trimble Ritter, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she went missing, and her mother was advised not to see the body or crime scene photos. However, Ritter recently viewed the photos and expressed regret for not doing so earlier. She described the horrific state of her daughter's body, including signs of strangulation, sexual assault, and missing cookie money. Barrett was arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence linked him to the crime. He was found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, is determined to win the Masters at Augusta National to complete his career grand slam and join an elite group of players who have won all four major titles. Despite only having one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, the 25-year-old believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the tournament at some point in his career. McIlroy's final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011 was a turning point in his career, teaching him valuable lessons about himself and his game. He hopes to use the golf course as his "sanctuary" from the pressure and hype surrounding the tournament.

This week was eventful with various trending stories. In New York, four rainbows appeared after heavy rainfall, captured by Amanda Curtis. In rural China, hiring exotic dancers for wakes is a common practice, but this is now being targeted in the country's crackdown on vice. Robert Downey Jr. was agitated during an interview when asked about his private life. A new trend, #kyliejennerchallenge, involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar to look like Kylie Jenner. A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, went back in time with the help of filmmakers. A prom-posal referencing bombs caused controversy, with the proposer accusing administrators of racism. Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'. Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer. A unique pregnancy announcement referenced 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad photobombed his son. All these events trended this week.

Hundreds of children in England were hospitalized due to brain damage caused by exposure to alcohol in the womb, with 272 cases of Foetal Alcohol Syndrome reported in the past year, according to the Health and Social Care Information Centre. However, experts suggest the actual number could be much higher, with research indicating at least 1 in 100 babies born in the UK may suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure, equating to around 7,500 babies each year. The syndrome is vastly underdiagnosed and children born with it do not get better. The condition can lead to a range of issues, including problems with the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. Despite government advice for pregnant women to avoid alcohol or limit consumption to up to two units no more than twice a week, there are calls for stricter guidance advising against any alcohol consumption during pregnancy.

An axe-wielding robber, Shaun Andrew McKerry, was jailed after attempting to rob a store in County Durham. The 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender, known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy," entered Shildon Post Office and Stores at 8 pm on March 15. He threatened assistant Andrea Brighty with an axe, but the store owner, Sab Dhillon, tackled him, causing him to drop the axe. Dhillon's wife, Sam, then hit McKerry with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him. McKerry was arrested by police and later pleaded guilty to attempted robbery. He was sentenced to six years in prison. McKerry had a history of criminal activity, starting with shoplifting at age 12 and accumulating 80 arrests by age 15. His previous convictions included aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary.

Four Royal Navy sailors, namely Joshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalley, have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fuelled party in a Canadian barracks. They are required to stay in Nova Scotia until their trial and have been granted bail under unusual conditions. They must surrender their passports, live at the Stadacona Naval Base in Halifax, and continue working for the Royal Navy, drawing their current pay. The alleged sexual assault took place on April 10 after the sailors returned from a hockey game. The accused face charges of sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which are punishable by up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is still ongoing, and additional charges may be brought forth based on forensic test results.

A mother, Valerie Jackson, is dealing with the challenges of raising her four-year-old son RJ, who suffers from Netherton's Syndrome, an incredibly rare skin disease that affects only 70 people worldwide. RJ's skin appears red, inflamed, and scaly, often covered in dry skin that resembles scales. Valerie regularly applies creams to prevent his skin from drying out. However, she has faced numerous instances of ignorance and abuse, including being reported to the police for child abuse by a stranger who mistook RJ's condition for signs of abuse. Valerie and her son have also been subjected to taunts and cruel comments from adults, including being denied entry to play centers and facing accusations of burning RJ. Netherton's Syndrome is a rare congenital skin disease with no cure, but symptoms can improve with time. The condition is thought to be genetic, and parents can carry the faulty gene responsible. Despite the challenges, Valerie remains dedicated to caring for her son and hopes that as he grows, his condition will be better understood.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" advertisements featuring a bikini-clad model, Renee Somerfield, on the London Underground. The posters have been criticized for promoting an unhealthy body image and have been defaced by bloggers. A petition to remove the ads has garnered over 50,000 signatures, and the Advertising Standards Authority has received more than 200 complaints. Transport for London has confirmed that the posters will be removed as the three-week advertising period has ended. Protein World has defended the campaign, stating that the image is unphotoshopped and that they aim to promote fitness and health. The company has faced backlash on social media, with users accusing the campaign of being offensive, sexist, and anxiety-inducing. Despite the controversy, Protein World has reported a rise in sales of protein powder and has no plans to change its advertising methods.

Rail firms, including First Great Western (FGW) and Virgin, have announced fare hikes of up to 87% on certain routes, just ten days after the general election. These increases come despite promises from the main party leaders to freeze prices. The most significant hike is an 87% increase on off-peak returns from London to the Cotswolds, which will rise from £33.30 to £62.40. Other sharp price hikes include a 24.5% increase on an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool with Virgin. The firms defend the rises, stating that they are necessary to bring certain routes in line with others and that the majority of price hikes affect Virgin-only fares, which are at least 20% cheaper than those offered by rival firms.

A 66-year-old former soldier, John Young, has been left blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown by vandals in Oldham, Greater Manchester. Young and his wife Elaine were in their home when the attackers began pelting stones at their front window. When Young went to confront them, he was struck in the left eye by another brick. Despite undergoing emergency surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight. The couple, who married three weeks ago, were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts when the incident occurred. Police are investigating the attack but believe it may have been a case of youths "messing around" with no known motive. Young and his wife are now too scared to live in their neighborhood and plan to move.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a new one-year contract extension following his successful return from injury. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident that tragically resulted in the death of his father, Keith. After undergoing an ankle operation, Poynton made his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. He will be available for the start of the season and has committed to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire's Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and work ethic during his recovery, expressing hope that the new contract will give him the confidence to perform well in the upcoming season.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw has been declared cancer-free after battling an aggressive form of neuroblastoma for a year. He was diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. Harley found strength during his radiotherapy treatment by wearing a superhero costume and decorating his protective mask like a ninja turtle. His story gained international attention, and he was even sent ninja turtle presents by Nickelodeon for Christmas. Harley underwent intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy. His bravery earned him a Little Star Award from Cancer Research UK and made him the face of their Kids and Teens campaign. Neuroblastoma is a rare cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK each year, with most diagnosed under five years old. The cause is unknown, and symptoms vary depending on the tumor's location. Treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, antibody treatment, and radiotherapy.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, is the subject of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England national teams. However, Tim Sherwood, Villa's manager, advises Grealish to focus on his club career and force his way into the Villa first team. Grealish has impressed Sherwood with his performances, including a standout game against Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-final. Grealish's father also agrees that his son should concentrate on his club football first. Grealish is expected to make a decision between Ireland and England at the end of the season, and he could potentially play for both teams in a friendly match.

The passage discusses the high landing fees charged at airports for private jets, which can vary significantly. The most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan, with Haneda Airport charging the highest at £4,559 ($6,850). Other costly airports include Narita International Airport in Tokyo, Kansai International Airport in Osaka, and surprisingly, Bristol Airport in the UK. Private jet travel is a growing trend among the wealthy, with millions of private flights recorded annually in the US and Europe. Major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix result in the busiest weekends for private jet companies, with costs reaching tens of thousands of dollars for a round-trip.

In Clackamas County, Oregon, Katie Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, took her dogs Cooper and Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for an ice cream treat. While Daisy took a few delicate licks, Cooper quickly gobbled up the entire ice cream cone in one bite. The video of Cooper's ice cream outing has been watched over seven million times, with mixed reactions from viewers. Some found it cute and hilarious, while others criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream. Gallegos defended her actions, stating that Cooper is an athletic dog in excellent health and that she also fed her previous dog ice cream weekly. She also mentioned that Daisy only gets a few licks due to her smaller size. In another video, Cooper and Daisy are seen visiting a Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," with Cooper again quickly consuming the entire cup's contents. Gallegos clarified that the beverage is just whipped cream and contains no coffee.

Gary Locke, formerly the interim manager of Kilmarnock, has been appointed as the permanent manager of the club after signing a three-year deal. Locke, aged 41, joined Kilmarnock as an assistant boss to Allan Johnston last summer but took over the team when Johnston resigned at the start of February. Since taking over, Locke has only lost once in seven games. He will be speaking at a press conference on Friday morning. The announcement of his permanent position was made after he shook hands with the club's chairman, Jim Mann.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the 'essential oils' she applies to him. The oils, manufactured by doTerra, are used to help Logan stay calm and focused. However, teachers at Seminole County Elementary warned they would remove Logan from class as the oils' smell was a distraction to other students. Despite receiving a letter from the school board stating the oils had created a problem, Kemp insists on continuing their use due to their positive impact on her son. The school district later clarified that they would not suspend Logan, citing it as a 'health issue'. The family uses oils with scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

On Wednesday at 3 pm, a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, consisting of 90 condos, was destroyed by a fire. The cause of the blaze is unknown, but it was intense enough to melt the paint off nearby buildings and create smoke visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the flames but were unable to enter the buildings. The complex was used as a holiday home between May and November. The building manager, who lived and worked in the complex, lost everything in the fire. The fire is being investigated, with claims that it may have started near a car parked by the complex.

The Queen, approaching her 89th birthday, was seen enjoying a ride on her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. Despite encouragement to wear riding helmets, she prefers silk scarves due to her hair. The Queen's love for horses began at age four and she has since owned numerous horses, including her current fell ponies. She has reduced her riding due to a knee injury but remains an enthusiastic equestrienne. The Queen also breeds fell ponies, one of the oldest equine breeds, at her Hampton Court stud. These ponies are known for their docile, hardy, and thick-set nature and have been used for various purposes throughout history.

A dispute over noise levels between two neighbours in North Brisbane resulted in tragedy. Leon Yeaman, 55, was allegedly killed by a single punch from Phillip Pama, 28, during an argument in front of their homes. Pama, a shift worker and father of three, was sleeping when Yeaman was reportedly making a commotion in his yard. Pama's lawyer stated that Yeaman was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling. Pama confronted Yeaman, and during the altercation, Pama allegedly hit Yeaman with a single punch, resulting in his death. Pama was granted conditional bail and is due back in court on May 18. He has no history of violence and was reportedly distraught over the incident.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-lover Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the hit, wanting the boy to slowly bleed to death. However, police set up a sting operation, sending an undercover officer to pose as a hitman. After Simonova handed over expenses money, she was arrested in her car and charged with attempted murder, facing 15 years in prison. Vanya expressed relief and hoped that the guards would "throw away the key" for Simonova's prison cell.

Jose Mourinho, the 52-year-old Chelsea football manager, discusses his faith and personal life in an interview with the Daily Telegraph. He reveals that he prays every day but only goes to church when he feels the need to, especially when he's in Portugal. Mourinho separates his professional and family life, never discussing football with his wife or praying about it. He believes in God and considers himself a good person, supporting people he doesn't even know. Despite his competitive and emotional professional life, Mourinho acknowledges that a person is more than just their professional life. He was previously fined for claiming a 'campaign' against Chelsea. Mourinho, his wife, and children were also seen at the Hunger Games premiere. His son, Jose Mario, celebrated Chelsea's Capital One Cup victory with some of the players this year.

In the passage, it is reported that after eight years, TV legend Bob Barker returned to hosting "The Price is Right," a role he held for 35 years before retiring in 2007. At 91 years old, Barker appeared agile as he led the first game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over the hosting duties to Drew Carey. Despite his time away from the show, Barker showed no signs of difficulty.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday around 12:30 am for allegedly attempting to break into a house and causing destruction of property. Baldwin was apprehended by the Metropolitan Police Department on the 3200 block of D Street SE. His security clearance was revoked, and he was placed on leave following the arrest. Baldwin was part of the foreign missions branch, which deals with the United States' diplomatic activities. He was scheduled to be arraigned on Friday afternoon, but no attorney was listed for him. This incident comes two days after a high-ranking supervisor was also put on leave due to misconduct allegations, which are being investigated by the Homeland Security Department's inspector general. Both incidents are recent setbacks for the agency responsible for protecting the president and his family.

A freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, took a risky photo of a lion from just a few feet away at the city's safari park. Armed only with a camera, Saeed approached the lion and managed to capture a couple of frames before retreating to safety. However, the clicking sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion to Saeed's presence, forcing him to quickly retreat. Saeed described the encounter as a close call and expressed that he would not be able to do it again.

A woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn, near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue. Despite efforts, paramedics could not revive her, and she was pronounced dead that evening. The woman had no identification but had a distinctive tattoo of a heart with the name 'Monique' on her right leg. The NYPD released images of the tattoo, including an artist's rendering of its original appearance, in hopes of identifying her. The cause of her death is still under investigation, and anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from living in the UK and finding they couldn't afford to buy property. The project took them a year and a half and cost around $25,000. The home is made of wood and steel, and is powered mostly by solar panels, with a wood-fired stove and gas-powered hot water. The couple now lives in their home in Nelson, New Zealand, surrounded by nature and nearly self-sufficient. They have a bedroom, a loft that doubles as a spare room for their cat, and stained glass windows. The couple plans to build another home like this in the future.

In a study conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, kindergarten students who shared iPads in class significantly outperformed their peers in early literacy tests. The shared iPad users scored around 30 points higher than students who used the device individually or did not use an iPad at all. The research suggests that collaborative learning around technology, rather than just collaboration itself, contributed to the improved performance. Blackwell recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness. The findings will be presented at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

A piglet in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation due to its ability to walk on just two front legs, despite being born without its back legs. Nicknamed 'Super Pig', the piglet has gained attention for its extraordinary balance and resilience, as it manages to regain its balance when it looks close to tipping over. The piglet happily interacts with its littermates, who all have a full set of legs. Farmer Ms. Duan discovered the piglet's unique condition when it was feeding. The piglet is not the first two-legged animal to gain popularity in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became a star attraction for its ability to walk on its front paws.

On Sunday, during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, a pit crew member named Todd Phillips was injured when he was hit by Francesco Dracone's car. Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was struck by Dracone's car as the driver exited the pit box for tires and fuel on lap 25. Dracone spun and clipped Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated for a cut on his leg and released after receiving stitches at the infield care center. Many cars struggled with traction during the race due to rain. Dracone did not finish the race and placed 23rd.

In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, a husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. The incident was captured on CCTV. Severiano confessed to the crime, stating he was jealous of men looking at his wife. The victim was a member of the dance group Jaula das Gostozuedas. After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was apprehended by police after a car crash. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car. He now faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, a renowned journalist and author, has shared her personal struggle with mental illness, disclosing that she once contemplated suicide. In an open interview with Women's Weekly Australia, the 41-year-old explained how anxiety led her to question the purpose of her life. She attributed her distress to a combination of factors including stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feeling isolated due to not having a family of her own. Wilson now identifies as an "anxious person," a label she struggled to accept in her younger years. She believes that anxiety and depression are interconnected and that recognizing this link is crucial to addressing the rising number of Australian women affected by stress and anxiety. According to Beyond Blue, one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and anxiety can often lead to depression. Help is available through Beyond Blue at 1300 224 636 and Lifeline at 13 11 14.

A pregnant woman in Portland, Oregon, named Elena Curtin, was charged with second-degree assault after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. The incident occurred when Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and asked her to leave, but she refused. Oregon law allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who won't leave a resident's home. Curtin's defense attorney argued that the ex-girlfriend was jealous and bitter about Curtin's relationship with the boyfriend, who is the father of Curtin's child. The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing and threatening Curtin, as well as attempting to drag the boyfriend back into addiction. Prosecutors dropped the charge against Curtin on the grounds that she was "completely justified in her outrage." If Curtin had been convicted, she would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was filmed being fed treats. In an attempt to trick her, her owner mixed in a broccoli spear. Gemma reacted with disgust, chomped on the vegetable, and then spat it out. Despite her dislike for broccoli, she enjoys activities such as sleeping and spending time with her human family. The passage humorously suggests that Gemma is not setting a good example for the children she lives with, as she does not appreciate her greens.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was intended for the Young Entrepreneur Awards page, which was shut down in 2011. The website's URL address transferred visitors to the porn site after the awards were scrapped and the registration was allowed to retire. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website and denied any associations with the external site. The banking giant insisted its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old boy named Marcus and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom after a fire broke out on the first floor of their Clinton, Maryland home on Sunday morning. Marcus called 911, stayed calm throughout the 11-minute call, and provided instructions to firefighters, helping them locate the siblings' room. He also comforted his sister during the ordeal. Prince George's County firefighters rescued the siblings by breaking a window and entering the room. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while their mother, stepfather, and older brother were taken to Medstar Hospital after escaping on their own.

Amazing pictures of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, have emerged. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight as a beautiful supernatural scene caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar display was seen in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. According to oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales, the glow is caused by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in the spring and autumn. This carnivorous cell, which preys on diatoms, gives off the luminous glow as a defense mechanism.

The passage discusses new genetic tests that can help determine the risk of breast cancer recurrence in patients, potentially sparing them from chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are sent to a lab where they are screened to determine the risk of recurrence. If the test, called Endopredict, shows a low score, patients can opt not to have chemotherapy. These tests are currently only available privately and cost around £2,500, but experts hope they will soon be available on the NHS. The tests can help patients make informed choices about their treatment, whereas previously chemotherapy was given to almost everyone. The side effects of chemotherapy, such as hair loss, nausea, and extreme fatigue, can be difficult to live with and for some women, the prospect of chemotherapy is more daunting than surgery itself. The tests can accurately predict a low risk of recurrence, as low as five per cent, which is as good as or better than the odds for those who have chemotherapy.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy in the last nine years, with HMS Ocean having five such cases. Eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. A strict "no touching" rule is in place at sea, suggesting women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave. Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was also flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014 around 9% of personnel were female. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones, and pregnant servicewomen are flown back on flights usually reserved for injured troops.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was found on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence. The drone was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. The amount of cesium was not immediately harmful to humans. The discovery raised concerns about potential terrorism involving drones, particularly in light of upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports but not around most of Tokyo, including the Prime Minister's residence and government buildings. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was not in his office at the time, as he was attending the Asian-African conference in Indonesia.

A security guard in China, Lu Xincai, has been commended for his dedication to caring for his elderly mother who suffers from Alzheimer's. He takes her to work every day on the back of his motorbike, ensuring her safety by tying a sash around both their waists. This routine started after his father passed away and he realized there was no one else to look after her, as his wife works in a different city and his son is still in school. Lu Xincai wakes up at 5 am to help his mother get ready and they embark on a slow, hour-long journey to his workplace. His employers have provided a room for his mother at the bank where he works, and he frequently checks on her to ensure she hasn't wandered off. Lu Xincai feels a duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to raising her children, and he expresses his love and concern for her wellbeing.

The study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found a 17.2% increase in heavy drinking among Americans between 2005 and 2012, largely due to rising rates among women. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defines heavy drinking as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men. Binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month. The increase in heavy drinking is driven by women's drinking habits as social norms change. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. Public health experts attribute the increase in excessive drinking to changed social norms, affluence, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study analyzed data from about 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System.

Doctors are performing too many unnecessary caesarean sections, which is putting women and their babies at risk, according to UN officials. The procedure should ideally only be carried out when medically necessary, as it can lead to infections, significant complications, disability, or even death. The World Health Organization states that the ideal rate of caesarean sections should be between 10 to 15 percent, but in England, more than a quarter of women giving birth now have a caesarean, with the rate more than doubling since the early 1990s. This includes a growing number of women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural birth. The procedure is also advised for women who have had a previous complicated birth, are over 40, or have a medical condition such as asthma, diabetes, or depression. However, the WHO warns that doctors are carrying out caesareans too often and underestimating the risks, with previous research finding that as many as one in ten caesareans cause infections.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, aged 44 and from West Wareham, has been arrested and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. She was discovered by the owner, Mark Conklin, at his summer home in Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, on April 17. Filkins had allegedly been living in the house for at least a week and had sold items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. The stolen items include furniture, kitchenware, linens, and a painting by the owner. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was returned to her after police posted a series of humorous photos and selfies on her Facebook page. The phone was found unlocked and handed in at Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border. Police used the opportunity to post selfies and puns on Bella's Facebook page, including a photo of the phone in a holding 'cell'. Bella had lost her phone at a friend's birthday party the night before and was contacted by a security guard who said he would leave it at the police station. When Bella arrived to collect her phone, she was greeted by officers who recognized her from her Facebook page. Bella has since put a password on her phone and expressed her gratitude to the police for their good humor in returning her phone.

In the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, Eastern South Africa, a five-day-old baby hippopotamus was tragically killed during a fight between two adult male hippos. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface after straying into the fighting adults' path. The mother hippo watched in horror as her baby was caught between the jaws of one of the brawling adults. Despite her attempts to save her calf, the baby hippo succumbed to its injuries and died hours later. The incident was witnessed by a tour operator, Stacey Farrell, who speculated that the sub-adult hippo might have acted out of jealousy or playfulness.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for £575,000, significantly less than neighboring properties. However, the lease only has three years remaining, making the annual cost equivalent to the local rental rate. The property requires renovation and is being sold by Russell Simpson. If the lease is extended, the property's value could exceed £6 million. Another similar property is also available for £595,000. The current freeholder is believed to be the Welcome Trust, and negotiating a lease extension could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year lease. The properties were built around 1893 and feature high-quality architecture. It is rare for properties with such short leases to come on the market, and potential buyers are warned about the significant premium required to extend the lease.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, prompting baristas to give away free drinks. The issue began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast. The cause of the outage was a failure during a daily system refresh. Starbucks stores were expected to open for business as usual on Saturday. Excited Twitter users spread the word about the giveaway, sharing photos of free drinks. The tech snafu occurred just one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are reportedly undergoing training and radicalization in rural areas of Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire in West Wales. These individuals participate in seemingly ordinary activities within the community but have an ulterior motive, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Instances of Islamic extremist activity in Wales date back to 1998, with the Brecon Beacons in Powys being used for training. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed in North Wales, and in 2010, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested for planning terror attacks. Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, is understood to have studied at the European Institute of Human Sciences in Highmead. DC Jones emphasized the importance of community intelligence in combating terrorism.

An Omura's whale, a species thought to be extinct, was discovered on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia. This is the first sighting in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. The 5.68m juvenile female was identified using DNA profiling. The species was first described in scientific journals in 2003 and is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and potential public display in museums.

The passage discusses the role of hormones in leadership, particularly in the context of presidential candidates. Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, believes that women's hormones make them unsuitable for the presidency. However, studies show that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men. The passage also highlights the bias against women in the workplace, citing examples of overt and covert discrimination. The author argues that equality benefits everyone and that diverse teams produce better results. The passage also mentions that Kim Campbell became Canada's first female prime minister in 1993, contradicting Rios' statement about women not being fit for leadership.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for roles in All Creatures Great and Small and portraying Winston Churchill, is selling his collection of over 200 antiques in a £100,000 auction. The 89-year-old actor, a keen military historian who studied with J.R.R. Tolkien, is auctioning off items such as a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, furniture, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. The auction will take place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, with a total of 238 lots being sold. Hardy expressed sadness at selling his collection but is downsizing his home.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted for the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, in Winter Garden, Florida. He became a suspect after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother's body was found. Shemansky has a history of mental illness, is on parole for battery on law enforcement, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. His mother was supporting him during a divorce, and neighbors believe the stress of the divorce proceedings may have led to the crime. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. The murder weapon is in police custody, but the cause of death has not been disclosed. Anyone with information on his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been granted the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, who chose to forgo the usual bidding process due to a perceived "unique strategic opportunity" to hold the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously attempted to host the 2019 event but was unsuccessful, with Doha, Qatar securing the rights instead. The IAAF Council's decision was influenced by a recent presentation from Eugene, which demonstrated the city's capability to stage a world championship event. The IAAF President, Lamine Diack, stated that this decision was a strategic choice that allowed the IAAF to access a key market and promote the global development of the sport. It is noteworthy that the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process.

An aspiring model, Leonie Granger, has been sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger targeted Hassan after seeing him with a roll of £50 notes at a London casino. She befriended him and was showered with gifts, cash, and fancy dinners. However, she left his flat unlocked one night, allowing her boyfriend and an accomplice to enter and rob Hassan. They tied him up and kicked him to death, leaving him with multiple broken bones and bleeding. Granger's boyfriend and accomplice were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison. Granger expressed regret for her actions, but the judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked."

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season, which aligns with his previous trend of declining performance post-Christmas. Despite a strong start to the season, his form has dipped significantly, and he was one of the worst players on the pitch during Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland. His performance has been criticized by Spanish newspapers, and questions have been raised about his durability. Fabregas' decline in form is taking a toll on his role as a key player in Chelsea's title charge. His assists have dropped from 15 by mid-January to just one in the following five games. Despite this slump, Fabregas still has the opportunity to break the Barclays Premier League record for assists, as Chelsea is yet to face six opponents against whom he has provided assists this season. Mourinho, Chelsea's manager, is hoping for a late-season resurgence from Fabregas to secure the Premier League title.

West Ham is in talks to sign Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old starlet from Montego Bay United, who has impressed during a two-week trial with the club's academy. Beckford, considered one of the hottest prospects from the Caribbean, also has offers from Belgian clubs. Separately, West Ham announced that season tickets for the Olympic Stadium will start at £289 for the 2016-17 season, making them the cheapest in the Barclays Premier League.

In January, a vicious assault occurred on a huntsman, Mike Lane, during a confrontation with hunt saboteurs. Despite being provided with a video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including some names of saboteurs and their car registration numbers, Wiltshire police have dropped the investigation into the attack. The victim, who was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, was left with concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. The main suspect's face was captured on video, but the police have been unable to identify him. The decision to drop the case has angered the victim and hunt supporters, who feel that the police could have done more to bring the attackers to justice.

The passage discusses the death of Adam Gadahn, a U.S. citizen and prominent member of Al Qaeda, who was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was born in 1978 and converted to Islam in 1995. He moved to Pakistan in 1998 and rose through the ranks of Al Qaeda, becoming its chief English-language propagandist. Gadahn was indicted for treason and material support to Al Qaeda in 2006 and appeared in several videos threatening attacks and urging Muslims to target American, Western, and Jewish interests. He was married to a Muslim woman from Afghanistan and had at least one child. The passage also mentions the death of another U.S. citizen and Al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, and two hostages, Warren Weinstein and Giovanni Lo Porto, in a separate operation.

The passage discusses the rising popularity of a five-year-old basketball prodigy in China named Mai Zizhuo. Mai has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old and has gained attention for his impressive skills, which include scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously. A viral video showcasing his abilities has earned him a large fanbase in basketball-loving China. The country's previous top basketball star was Yao Ming, who played for the NBA's Houston Rockets from 2002 to 2011. The video has left many viewers stunned, with some questioning if special effects were used, while others express admiration and even envy for Mai's talent.

Tom O'Carroll, a former key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for 'corrupting public morals', attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. The rally was chaired by comedian John Cleese. Hacked Off, set up in the wake of the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning for a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. The news of O'Carroll's support for Hacked Off is an embarrassment to the group.

On Thursday, the iconic Icebergs Club pool at Bondi was drained to serve as an unusual catwalk setting for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The lifestyle brand, headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss, produces unisex collections of ten pieces each. The collection showcased was entirely monochrome and designed to be worn in 20 different ways, suitable for day to night wear. The presentation took place on an unseasonably warm 28 degrees Celsius day, with guests enjoying nibbles from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria. Beachgoers and passers-by stopped to watch the androgynous designs as models paraded through the empty pool and along the break wall with a beautiful ocean backdrop.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan, aged 28, spent a family day at a safari park in Northern California. He was accompanied by his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. During their visit to Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, Khan interacted with various animals, including a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. Regarding his professional life, Khan recently announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, despite pressure to fight British rival Kell Brook in June. Khan was also linked with bouts against Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman but confirmed he was already in negotiations for a different fight.

In Jerusalem, the name of Palestinian teenager Mohammed Abu Khdeir will be removed from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and terrorism victims following objections from his family and others. Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, according to prosecutors. His father, Hussein Abu Khdeir, objected to his son's inclusion on the memorial wall at Mount Herzl, stating he did not want his son listed among "soldiers of the occupation." Almagor, an organization representing terror victims in Israel, also opposed Abu Khdeir's inclusion, describing his death as a rogue attack and not an act of terrorism. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, will remove Abu Khdeir's name following complaints. A panel of judges is currently hearing evidence against the three suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing.

A young boy in California is seen in a YouTube video using his cat as a makeshift pillow, repeatedly trying to rest his head on the cat's belly. The cat initially tolerates the boy, but after a few attempts, it gets up and moves away. The boy follows the cat each time, trying to use it as a pillow again. Eventually, the cat decides it's had enough and goes indoors. A later video shows the boy and cat reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia has witnessed a significant development as a trial witness, Robert Kushner, has lost his coaching job at a private academy after testifying about his past marijuana dealing. Kushner, aged 32, is among over a dozen former drug dealers testifying against alleged police misconduct. He revealed that some of the officers on trial had stolen $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. This revelation was unknown to the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy, where Kushner was a varsity basketball coach. Kushner had passed a background check when hired in 2010, but his 2007 charges were expunged as part of a probationary sentence. He was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation, and also pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. Kushner expressed regret for the situation and maintains his innocence regarding the 2011 charges. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, with defense lawyers claiming the case is based on false testimonies from 19 drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

Six people were injured in an explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province, China. The plant produces paraxylene, a chemical used in polyester production. The explosion occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak. Over 600 firefighters were deployed to control the fire. The plant has been controversial and faced protests due to pollution concerns, leading to its relocation to a more remote location. This is the second explosion at the plant, with the first occurring in 2013 without casualties or toxic leaks.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager renowned for wearing his socks low and children's shinpads due to superstition, has a message for Premier League referees: he won't change his ways despite their advice. Grealish made his first Premier League start against QPR in a 3-3 draw and is pleased to have the manager's faith in him, hoping for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Although no longer in a medically induced coma, Brown remains unresponsive and is not expected to recover from her current neurological state. She has a tracheostomy in her throat and does not respond to visitors or familiar voices. Despite her father's recent statement about her condition improving, doctors have indicated that the quality of her life will not be known for years to come.

Russia is leading Germany 2-0 in the Fed Cup tie, on the brink of making the final. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to beat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, after Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serve, but Lisicki's 63 unforced errors proved costly. Russia needs one more win from Sunday's matches to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm, potentially an East Coast Low, is predicted to hit the region from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts, with over 4,000 jobs still to be completed from the previous storm. The Hunter Region, which suffered through flooding and high winds in the last storm, is of particular concern. Meteorologists say the trough of low pressure forming along the coast will hit heaviest in the far northern parts of the state. The Bureau of Meteorology says it's too early to tell how severe the weather system will be, but current guidance suggests that rain will increase this week and peak between Thursday and Saturday. The SES will spend the next few days trying to complete as many jobs as possible and warning people to prepare their homes for another severe storm.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's music video for "La Vida Loca," denied claims that she attempted suicide. She clarified that she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure and a domestic accident that caused her to fall and injure herself. Italian media had reported that Moric's boyfriend suggested she had tried to take her own life, but Moric refuted these claims and stated that she was recovering at home. In the past, Moric was married to famous paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

The British public eagerly awaits the arrival of Kate and William's second child, hoping for a traditional name. According to a YouGov survey for the Sunday Times, 12% of people prefer the name Diana for a girl, after William's mother, Princess Diana. Alice and Charlotte are the next preferred names, each with 9% of the vote. If the child is a boy, 13% of people favor the name James, with Alexander being the second favorite. Of the 2,200 people polled, a quarter hope for a girl, while only 3% want a younger brother for Prince George. The poll also shows that 68% of people support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber in Khost, Afghanistan, detonated explosives near a group of protesters on Thursday, resulting in 17 deaths and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed it. The protesters were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor when the attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves, the 31-year-old Brazilian right-back, is expected to depart Barcelona this summer. This comes after his representative confirmed that Alves has turned down the club's final contract offer following seven successful years at the club, during which he won four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. The player's agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, revealed at a press conference that Alves had rejected a three-year contract extension, which was contingent on him participating in 60% of the club's matches. Santana declared that negotiations were over, expressing surprise that Barcelona had not considered renewing Alves' contract until April.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old player currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has suggested that Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti join him at the Argentinian club.
