Osvaldo believes that Pirlo and Totti, who he considers friends, would be a great fit for Boca Juniors due to their South American style of play and exceptional abilities. He also thinks that the fans at La Bombonera would be thrilled to see players of their caliber on the pitch. Pirlo is renowned as one of the best midfielders in world football, while Totti is a legendary figure at Roma. Osvaldo feels that Totti would be just as beloved if he were to move to Argentina.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, was back to his usual routine at Paul Nicholls' yard after a spectacular fall from his horse, Merrion Square, at Wincanton. The fall, which has been widely viewed online, resulted in a cut on Ferguson's nose. Ferguson expressed surprise at the incident, only understanding what had happened after watching the replay in the weighing room. Despite the ordeal, he remains undeterred and plans to continue riding. He acknowledged the fall as one of the most impressive he's seen and expressed gratitude for his luck in avoiding serious injury. The incident has also led to an increase in his Twitter followers and some friendly banter from his fellow jockeys.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, joined the hype for the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie by posting a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram. Haskell, an England flanker, returned to Wasps for the 2012 season after playing for Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders in New Zealand. He first joined Wasps in 2002 and won his first England cap in 2007. After leaving Wasps in 2009, he played in France, Japan, and New Zealand before returning to England. Since his return, Haskell has surpassed the 100 appearances mark for Wasps and has become a significant part of the England squad with 57 caps to date.

The wide leg trouser is a popular trend for SS15, offering an alternative to the skinny jean. This style has made a comeback since the seventies and can be found in various materials such as denim, prints, and stripes. Designers like Gucci and Celine showcased wide leg trousers in their SS15 collections. To style wide leg trousers, it's recommended to pair them with high heels and a simple top to maintain proportion. Denim is considered the easiest way to achieve this trend. Online label Finery London offers a similar style at a lower price point. This trend is suitable for any weather and can be seen on celebrities like Poppy Delevingne.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sipper" for a student event, despite objections from over 200 students who signed a petition against it. The students believed the movie negatively depicted the Iraq war and the Middle East. However, after a counter-petition and backlash, the university reversed its decision to cancel the movie screening, citing the importance of freedom of expression and students' right to make their own choices. The university will also offer a screening of "Paddington" as an alternative for those who do not wish to attend "American Sniper."

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, currently living in Cockburn Central, allegedly set fire to a quokka, an Australian animal the size of a domestic cat, on Rottnest Island off Perth in Western Australia on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed by the flame. The men were charged with animal cruelty and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas can be found on some small islands off the west Australian coast, particularly on Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

In the 1930s and 1940s, Alice Barker was a dancer in New York nightclubs such as the Cotton Club and the Cafe Zanzibar, performing alongside notable figures like Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Despite motion pictures being made of her, Barker had never seen any of them and had lost all her photographs and memorabilia over the years. With the help of filmmakers, a video of "soundies" (early music videos) was compiled and shown to 102-year-old Barker at her nursing home. She was delighted to finally see herself dancing.

The tradition of washing one's own car on Sundays in Britain is declining, with a third of men and three-quarters of women admitting to never washing their own car. A survey by OSV revealed that 31% of men have never washed their own car, with only 12% doing it regularly. Factors contributing to this decline include the opening of shops on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and the size of 4x4 and off-road vehicles. Cars are more likely to be washed during holidays, with Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield having the most frequent car washing. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are most likely to wash their cars, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners are least likely. The OSV spokesman attributes this decline to lack of time, larger cars, and the availability of automated machines and cheap hand car washes.

The passage discusses Martin Skrtel's admiration for Steven Gerrard, who is set to play his final FA Cup semi-final for Liverpool against Aston Villa before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel, who joined Liverpool in 2008, credits Gerrard for helping him settle at the club and considers him one of the best players in the world. Despite acknowledging that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, Skrtel believes the club has potential replacements for the iconic midfielder. Both Gerrard and Skrtel are eligible to return to Liverpool's line-up for the match against Villa after serving three-match bans.

At the age of 75, Jack Nicklaus made a hole-in-one at the par-3 contest at Augusta National, marking his first ace on the course. He was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Despite his achievement, Camilo Villegas stole the show with two aces, but ultimately lost the title to Kevin Streelman in a play-off. Nicklaus is a six-time Masters champion and one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

In summary, on Wednesday night, multiple tornadoes were reported in Kansas, with one spotted near Goddard, posing potential risks to nearby communities. Other sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. The storms also affected Missouri, with a possible tornado touching down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and property damage. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of dangerous nighttime tornadoes. More storms are expected in various regions of the US on Thursday.

In Oklahoma, reserve sheriff's deputy Robert Bates pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting a man he intended to subdue with a taser. Bates, who claims the shooting was accidental, is scheduled for a preliminary hearing on July 2. The family of the victim, Eric Harris, expressed surprise and dismay at Bates' decision to go on a Bahamas vacation during this time. The lawyer for Harris' family alleges Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies allegations of forging Bates' records. Two deputies involved in Harris' arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irishman, is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. Ahead of the fight, McGregor has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach. McGregor claims to have more motivation to win the title than Aldo, who is defending it for the eighth time. The pair have a tense relationship, which was evident during a promotional tour in Dublin where McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt in front of 5,000 supporters.

Tony Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, was cheered on by a crowd as he quickly drank a schooner of beer at an Australian rules function. However, his actions drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners who accused him of glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with alcohol consumption. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor at the University of Technology Sydney, expressed concern that Abbott's behavior set a problematic culture that emphasizes the quantity and speed of drinking over socializing. She also criticized the media and government officials for their reactions to the event, warning that such behavior can lead to people forgetting their limits. While drinking is a part of Australian tradition, Robert warned against glorifying irresponsible drinking practices and perpetuating stereotypes about heavy drinking. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott's actions, stating that there was nothing wrong with his behavior and that he works hard to keep fit.

The number of HIV cases in Indiana has significantly increased, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases linked to Scott County. This outbreak primarily affects intravenous drug users, particularly those using the prescription painkiller Opana. Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, with about 1,400 used syringes returned. The future of this program and similar initiatives in other counties is uncertain. Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy, and there are concerns about funding and potential promotion of drug use. The House approved a bill to allow 23 counties with high rates of hepatitis C to establish their own needle-exchange programs, but the Senate's support is unclear.

In summary, an ardent Arsenal fan tested his girlfriend's knowledge about his favorite football club, Arsenal, by making her take a test. The test included multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and a section for her to answer in her own words. Despite struggling with some questions, such as naming all 11 players of the starting squad and their positions, she scored an impressive 87%. Her boyfriend, who remained unnamed, was pleased with her performance and rewarded her by not ending their relationship. The test was shared on Twitter, where it received mixed reactions, with some praising the boyfriend as a 'legend' and others feeling he took things too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. After retiring due to declining health, Toro is now facing deportation and is technically living in the US illegally. Despite his crucial role in aiding the DEA in undercover stings and prosecuting high-profile criminals such as Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, Toro has not been granted citizenship and is currently in limbo while trying to obtain a green card or passport. He fears for his life if he is deported to Colombia and is prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

A 14-year-old girl in India is in critical condition with 70% burns after setting herself on fire following an alleged gang rape by five men from her village. The incident occurred in Kosi Kalan, in Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district. The girl was allegedly raped when she went outside her house to relieve herself. The accused men have been arrested. This incident comes at a time of heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following the ban of a documentary about the gang rape and murder of a student in Delhi. Recent attacks have led to street protests and calls for increased protection for women.

In the upcoming Manchester derby at Old Trafford, Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is eager to beat rivals Manchester City, but will have to do so without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, who are not yet fit enough to play. Van Gaal expressed his desire to win, stating that it would be a big step up the table and could secure a top-four finish. He acknowledged that City will provide a tough challenge, but is looking forward to the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford. United players, including Wayne Rooney, Angel Di Maria, and Radamel Falcao, have been training in preparation for the match.

In a protest against ticket prices, a group of Arsenal and Liverpool fans left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. Fans from both clubs expressed disgust at the rising ticket prices, with the cheapest tickets for the lunchtime kick-off starting from £64. The protest was sparked by the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal, with fans feeling that the money is not being used to benefit them. Fans displayed banners inside and outside the stadium, with one reading: '£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket'. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups, with supporters calling for tangible reductions in ticket prices that reflect what working-class people earn. Further protests are expected after the full-time whistle.

A newborn baby named Star, diagnosed with a life-threatening liver condition called biliary atresia, was saved after receiving a liver transplant from her mother's twin sister, Shanell. Star's parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, noticed her skin turning yellowish shortly after birth, which led to the diagnosis. After an unsuccessful attempt to unblock her bile ducts, a liver transplant became the only option for Star's survival. Neither parent was a suitable match, but Shanell proved to be an ideal candidate. Star underwent the transplant in November and returned home after six weeks in the hospital, making a good recovery. She will require regular blood and liver function tests and anti-rejection medication for life. Biliary atresia affects about 1 in 16,000 babies and can lead to liver failure and death if untreated.

In this passage, Chelsea football players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participate in Audi's Football Challenge. The challenge consists of various rounds, including firing balls into the boot of a car from close range, sinking balls into convertible Audis from long range, and playing a makeshift tennis game over an Audi R8 V10 Plus. Hazard and Ake dominate the first two rounds, but Remy and Willian manage to win the final round, which involves shooting from long range at cars. However, Willian accidentally smashes the wing mirror off one of the Audis during the final round.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, caused a highway crash in New Hampshire that resulted in the death of a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger, who pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and one count of assault for the fetus' death, faces 12 to 24 years in prison. He claimed he was not suicidal during the incident, despite previously telling investigators he was trying to kill himself. Dellinger's lawyers argued that he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, the effects of a psychiatric drug overdose, and advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis. The sentencing hearing is expected to last two days.

Lacey Spears was convicted of killing her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt and was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his anger on Facebook, hoping she would die in prison. Spears was found guilty of second-degree murder in a New York hospital. The judge who sentenced her said she suffers from a mental illness. Prosecutors argued that Spears made her son ill because she had a bizarre need for attention and that she loaded his feeding tube with a lethal amount of salt while continuing to blog about his condition. Spears' lawyer claimed she was innocent and blamed the hospital for negligence. Throughout his life, Garnett Spears suffered through repeated hospitalizations and unneeded surgical procedures, all at the hands of his mother.

The passage discusses concerns over two new strains of influenza, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused an increase in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States. As a result, an improved vaccination that includes protection against these strains is being introduced in Australia. The vaccine, which also protects against influenza A strain H1N1, will be available from April 20, but stocks are arriving a month later than expected due to the modifications. High-risk groups and those in contact with them are encouraged to get the vaccine to prevent further deaths. The vaccine to be used in Australia this winter will also be used in the next northern winter.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois are facing criticism from a National Geographic article that describes the site as lacking historical character, comparing it to an office lobby. This comes as the state of Illinois, known as the 'Land of Lincoln,' faces a financial crisis and proposed budget cuts that could impact the management of the historic site. The tomb, designed by sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, has undergone recent renovations costing over $2.5 million. Despite this, the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb is at risk of being eliminated and rolled into another department. The tomb's caretakers and supporters argue that the National Geographic portrayal is unfair and that the site is in excellent physical condition.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 90s and early 2000s fashion trends, focusing on several controversial styles that some people believe should be left in the past. These trends include JNCO jeans with extremely wide legs, bucket hats, camouflage print, over-the-top styles like designer prints and double denim, Ugg boots, daisy duke shorts, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers. The article mentions various celebrities who have worn these styles, both in the past and present, such as Rihanna, Beyoncé, Kylie Jenner, Paris Hilton, Jessica Simpson, Britney Spears, and Victoria Beckham.

This week, notable events included the appearance of four rainbows in the New York sky after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis. In China, the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes has been halted due to a crackdown on vice. Robert Downey Jr. was agitated during an interview when asked about his private life. The Kardashians sparked a new trend, lip plumping, with the #kyliejennerchallenge. A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, traveled back in time with the help of filmmakers. A prom-posal referencing bombs caused controversy at a school. Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'. Johnny Depp was unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer. A unique pregnancy announcement referenced 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad photobombed his son.

The Miami Open is celebrating milestone victories, with Serena Williams earning her 700th career win and Andy Murray his 500th, both marked by giant cakes. Williams reached the semi-finals after defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets, avenging her 2013 Wimbledon loss. However, she won't face her sister Venus, who lost to Carla Suarez Navarro. Williams will next play Simona Halep, who beat Sloane Stephens, for a spot in the final.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent figure in Pakistan known for her advocacy of human rights, women's entrepreneurship, and free speech, was shot dead by two gunmen in Karachi. Mahmud was the owner of a second-floor cafe, a hub for discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. She was a symbol of humanism, love, and tolerance in Pakistan and was known for her bravery in speaking out on controversial topics. Her death occurred after she hosted a discussion on the issue of disappearances in Baluchistan, a topic that many wanted silenced. Despite receiving death threats in the past, Mahmud continued to provide a platform for open discussion and free thought. Her death was met with widespread grief and gratitude for her work.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer, has been living as a refugee in Indian Kashmir for almost 70 years, ever since he fled the violence that followed the partition of India. Despite being born in an area of Punjab province that was part of modern-day Pakistan but within India's boundaries before independence in 1947, Ram has been denied citizenship rights and is unable to own property or vote in state elections. He is one of around 100,000 people classified as West Pakistan refugees (WPRs), most of whom live in the Jammu region of India and have never set foot in Pakistan. The reluctance of successive state governments to grant full rights to the WPRs stems from fears of upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state. The WPRs, whose families mainly originate from Punjab, have fallen foul of a pre-independence law that only grants citizenship to people born in the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir. Despite Kashmir being one of India's more prosperous states, the WPRs live in abject poverty, with generations of families becoming stuck in poverty because of their continuing refugee status. However, there is hope for change after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party won a share of power in Kashmir and is expected to champion the WPRs' cause.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering an offer from Premier League leaders Chelsea, which is believed to be around £4 million. Chelsea intends to loan Muto to partner club Vitesse Arnhem for the next season. However, Muto is keen to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut for FC Tokyo, believes the pacey forward could be a success at Chelsea. Mourinho, Chelsea's boss, has admitted that he is aware of Muto and that commercial interests do play a part in the club's transfer policy. However, he emphasized that they only sign players who are good or have potential.

The passage discusses Australia's decision to change its policy and allow the selection of their best players, regardless of where they play overseas. This change leaves England looking outdated with their policy of not selecting overseas players. The author argues that England should follow Australia's lead and select their best players, regardless of where they play, to ensure they have the best chance of winning the World Cup. The author uses examples such as Matt Giteau, Drew Mitchell, and Steffon Armitage, who have improved their game since moving overseas. The author also mentions that Jonny Wilkinson moved to France and became even better than when he played for England. The author concludes by stating that England should not let the RFU or Premier Rugby dictate who they can or cannot pick and that it is misguided not to make any Englishman available for selection.

Open Garden has developed a device called Greenstone to enhance off-the-grid networks. This egg-shaped gadget acts as a beacon or booster to facilitate message transmission in wireless mesh networks. It was created to address the limitations of Open Garden's Firechat app, which allows chatting with friends without internet or mobile signals. Firechat, launched last year and downloaded over five million times, uses Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) and Android's similar feature to create localized networks where phones act as nodes, passing data between them. Greenstone extends the range of these networks, making it useful in crowded places or areas with poor connectivity. It is still under development and currently works with Firechat at a range of around 20ft (6 meters).

A burlesque performer, Lillian Bustle, is challenging the negative connotations associated with the word 'fat' by embracing it as a positive and honest description of her body. In a TED Talk, she explained that 'fat' is just another descriptor, like 'short' or 'wife', and it doesn't have to mean 'ugly'. Lillian pointed out that size discrimination has risen in the workplace and that young girls often wish to be thinner. However, she also shared that exposure to diverse body types can lead to acceptance and even preference for different body types. Lillian uses her burlesque performances to expose her audience to a 'fat' body in a positive and glamorous way, hoping to change their perceptions. She also shared her personal journey of self-acceptance and body positivity, encouraging others to find their own 'courage reference'. Despite some negative comments, Lillian's TED Talk has received mostly positive feedback, with many viewers sharing their own stories and expressing gratitude for her message.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, has been spending a significant amount of time on the bench this season, as evidenced by his frequent appearances alongside six of his teammates. In a different context, Walcott was featured in a photoshoot with his colleagues Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, as well as runway model Olga Sherer. The photoshoot was for Paris' oldest fashion house, Lanvin, which has been Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. Despite his limited playing time, Walcott, aged 26, was included in the team's substitutes for 17 of their 33 Barclays Premier League games. He made a brief appearance in the last six minutes of Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea and is hoping to make his first start since March 14 when Arsenal faces Hull at the KC Stadium.

A collection of props and puppets created by legendary makeup effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned off at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on propstore.com on May 29. The collection, worth an estimated $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions, such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas. Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black, valued at $40,000, the Two Face mask from Batman Forever, valued at $1,500, and the Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas, listed at $8,000. Other items from Baker's 30-year career, including those from An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Batman & Robin, Hellboy, and Mighty Joe Young, will also be sold to the highest bidder.

The seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, from Wales, died in a skiing accident in the French Alps. He was a competent skier and snowboarder who started skiing at the age of three. During their last run of the day in the resort of Flaine, Carwyn became separated from his mother and headed into dense woodland, where he fell over a 164ft drop. His family described him as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster with a handsome smile that lit up any room. His death has left a vast void in their hearts. Carwyn was believed to have left the piste and entered the woodland because he had spotted the resort through the trees. Police found his body by following footprints in the snow. His family, who are well-known for their award-winning farm shop, remained in the Alps, and his body was ready to be repatriated. Back in Wales, his friends and school community were devastated by his death.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old girl from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia due to the pressure to be thin and a 'size zero'. She became obsessed with her weight, hiding food, and eating as little as 100 calories a day. Her dramatic weight loss led to a collapse and she was put on a heart monitor at North Tyneside General Hospital. After receiving support from eating disorder organizations, she began her recovery. Laura's struggle with anorexia started when she was nearly 13 stone and felt too big, leading her to go on a diet. She was influenced by the pressure from peers, media, and society to be thin. Anorexia is a serious mental health condition that affects many people, especially women around the age of 16 or 17. After her recovery, Laura made it to the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive and confidence-building experiences for young girls, away from size zero stereotypes.

The passage describes the unveiling of Liverpool FC's new home kit for the 2015/16 season, designed by US sports brand New Balance. The kit launch event took place at Anfield, featuring players such as Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet. New Balance replaced sister company Warrior as Liverpool's suppliers in a record-breaking £300 million four-year kit deal.

Despite recent speculation about Sterling's future at the club, Liverpool fans expressed their desire for him to stay, with one fan shouting, "Make sure we see you in that next season." Sterling had previously rejected a £100,000-a-week contract and was linked with Arsenal, but Liverpool remains adamant that he will not leave the club this summer.

The new kit features an all-white branding, including the New Balance logo, the Liverbird, and the Standard Chartered logo, as well as an all-new style of collar. The kit also pays tribute to the casualties of the Hillsborough disaster with the memorial flame and number 96 on the shirt.

Players also discussed their excitement for the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, with Sterling and Sturridge expressing their desire to win the cup for the fans. The passage also mentions that departing captain Steven Gerrard won't be around to model the new kit next season, but his dream of bowing out in the FA Cup final remains alive.

The largest high-definition map of dark matter has been produced, covering 0.4% of the sky, with the goal of mapping 12.5% over five years. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device, and the Blanco telescope in Chile. Dark matter, which makes up at least 80% of the matter in the known universe, is invisible but its effects can be seen through gravitational lensing. The map shows large filaments of matter and cosmic voids, supporting theories that galaxies form where there are large concentrations of dark matter. The survey aims to better understand dark energy, which is believed to be causing the expansion of the universe to speed up. The team at Manchester analyzed 130 million separate telescope images of galaxies to make the map, using some of the world's largest supercomputers. The survey will be completed by 2018.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old Dutch international winger. Depay has been in prolific form this season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games. He has been praised for his pace, close control, and ability to run at defenders, and has been compared to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Depay worked under Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal during the Netherlands' successful 2014 World Cup campaign. PSV technical director Marcel Brands confirmed that Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another big European club have made contact regarding Depay, with "bigger amounts of money" being discussed.

The passage describes a football match between Chelsea and Manchester City's youth teams. Chelsea took a commanding 3-1 lead in the first half, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. The Chelsea team was led by captain Charlie Colkett, who had a strong performance in midfield. Abraham was a standout player for Chelsea, scoring two volleys for his 35th and 36th strikes of the season before being substituted due to injury. Other notable players for Chelsea included Ola Aina, Jake Clarke-Salter, and Jay Dasilva. Manchester City's team included several young players, including captain Tosin Adarabioyo, who had a strong performance in defense, and Brandon Barker, who was tipped for big things at the club. However, City struggled to keep up with Chelsea's strong attack and ultimately lost the match.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, believes that people are born with a sexual preference, but he insists that state legislators should decide whether or not to allow gay marriage. He stated that he is not against gay marriage, but he believes the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Rubio does not believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right and thinks courts should not make that decision. He also mentioned that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he didn't agree with their decision. Rubio announced his presidential run last week and has reportedly received significant monetary commitments for his campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, have embarked on an open-ended cycling odyssey around the world with no specific plans or agenda. They started in London and have covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days, passing through 16 countries. Remarkably, they have been living on less than three euros each per day. They keep costs down by relying on free accommodation, such as camping and hosting websites, and their only major expense is food. They plan to continue their journey into Asia and across the Pacific, aiming to cycle the length of the American continent.

A couple from Texas, who wish to remain anonymous, are suing James Evans, the owner of Premier Photos, for allegedly printing a racial slur on the bottom of photo booth snapshots from their 2012 wedding. The couple discovered the slur months after their wedding when the bride's sister informed them. The couple's attorney, Cathy Hale, stated that the sister chose not to reveal the incident on the wedding day to avoid ruining it. The groom contacted Evans, who allegedly did not apologize and instead said, "sue me." The couple decided to press charges after Evans did not address the issue. They are suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. Evans has denied all allegations and stated that there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption. Mediation is scheduled, but if no agreement is reached, the case will go to trial in July. The couple's lawyer emphasized that they primarily want an apology from Evans.

Mike Brown, England's full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback. He is unsure when he will return to play for his club, Harlequins, after missing the Aviva Premiership clash with Saracens at Wembley. Brown is determined not to rush his return to avoid an extended break, similar to what happened to Johnny Sexton and Geoff Parling. He was knocked out cold in England's victory over Italy in February and had hoped to recover in time to face Ireland but pulled out due to symptoms. Brown credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by World Rugby online modules, for helping him realize he was not ready to play. He urges other players to prioritize their health and not risk playing through symptoms.

The passage suggests that smartphone use and internet emergence may be contributing to a decline in sexual activity among couples. According to Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, the frequency of sexual activity among heterosexual couples has decreased from five times a month in 1990 to three times a month currently. This decline is attributed to the integration of public and private lives due to constant email checking and lack of quiet time. The professor also mentions that as technology has improved, lives have become busier, leaving less time for partners. The passage also quotes Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, who says that dealing with work emails late in the evening can make it difficult to focus on one's partner at bedtime.

Tibetan Mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg and were traditionally used for herding in Tibet, have seen a dramatic decline in popularity in China. Once commanding prices of up to £1.2 million each, they are now being sent to slaughterhouses due to their unpopularity. This decline is partly attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has discouraged the practice of giving these dogs as gifts to influence officials. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several Chinese cities have further impacted the breed's popularity. The collapse of China's mastiff market was revealed after animal welfare workers rescued a group of these dogs being transported to a slaughterhouse. The dogs were found in cramped cages, with many already dead and none having been given food or water for three days. It is feared that hundreds of these dogs are meeting a similar cruel fate across China. The breed's boom began in 2005, leading to them being seen as status symbols, with one puppy selling for £1.2 million in 2020. However, the rapid pace of urbanization has made people realize that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living.

In Paris, a survey of 600 women revealed that every respondent had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half of them first encountering it before turning 18. The harassment ranged from verbal abuse to physical attacks, leading six out of ten women to fear assault on public transport, compared to three out of ten men. The report, submitted to the French Women's Rights Ministry, stated that these incidents often go unreported and limit women's freedom, forcing them to alter their daily routines. The survey's findings prompted calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on public transport. Pascale Boisard, President of the High Council for Gender Equality, expressed surprise at the widespread nature of the problem, emphasizing the importance of women's freedom to move about without fear. Ernestine Ronai, also on the council, highlighted the need for better education on what constitutes sexual assault and the consequences for perpetrators.

In response to common everyday emergencies, Leeds-based Direct Line has launched a competition called #everydayfix. They asked groups to design products to address these issues, with three prototypes making the shortlist: Snooze, Forget Me Lock, and Nipper. Snooze is an alarm clock that connects with your phone to silence notifications for a good night's sleep. Forget Me Lock is a device that attaches to your key and indicates if your door is locked or not. Nipper is a compact mobile phone charger that uses any household battery as its energy source. The public can vote for their favorite product by retweeting tweets about the prototypes, and the one with the most retweets will go into a Kickstarter campaign for development.

A police crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating over £500,000 of public money to a charity, Victims First Northumbria, of which she is a director. The charity supports crime victims in her area and its top table also includes Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. Critics, including Labour Chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, Keith Vaz, have accused Baird of a conflict of interest and inappropriate use of public funds. Baird defended her decision, stating that all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed. Sim, who gained prominence for her handling of the Raoul Moat case in 2010, is also retiring from the force in June. She was previously accused of bullying staff and faced an investigation led by Baird. The Ministry of Justice confirmed it will investigate the situation to determine if any conflict of interest rules were violated.

Three individuals, including ringleader Corry 'Corey' Campbell, have been sentenced to prison for their roles in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce. Campbell believed Valecce had harmed his cat, Pebbles. The victim was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive images in a basement that served as a torture chamber. The assault was filmed, and Valecce suffered multiple injuries. Two other individuals, David Harrison and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively. The incident occurred in late March 2014 in a rowhouse in Mayfair, North Philadelphia.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven for 21-year-old Dutch star Memphis Depay, who is a top target for manager Louis van Gaal. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, is also sought after by other European clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain. The young winger, known for his pace, close control, and ability to run at defenders, has been tipped to become as good as Dutch star Arjen Robben and even rival Cristiano Ronaldo. Depay has already made over 100 appearances for PSV and was part of the Dutch squad that finished third in the 2014 World Cup.

The passage describes a football match between Chelsea and Manchester City's youth teams. Chelsea took a commanding 3-1 lead in the first half, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a third goal late in the game. The Chelsea team was dominant throughout the match, with Abraham and Solanke leading the attack and the defense holding strong. Manchester City's young side struggled to keep up with Chelsea's pace and skill, with several players struggling to make an impact on the game. Despite a few chances, City was unable to level the score, and Chelsea emerged victorious.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, believes that people are born with a sexual preference, but he insists that state legislators should decide whether or not to allow gay marriage. He stated that he is not against gay marriage, but he believes the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Rubio does not think same-sex marriage is a constitutional right and believes courts should not make that decision. He also mentioned that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he didn't agree with their decision. Rubio announced his presidential run last week and has reportedly received significant monetary commitments for his campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, have embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world with no specific plans or agenda. They started in London and have covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days, passing through 16 countries. They live on less than three euros each per day, relying on free accommodation and food from their own budget or through the kindness of strangers. They often camp or use hosting websites such as Couchsurfing and Warmshowers. Their journey has taken them through Europe, and they plan to continue into Asia and across the Pacific to cycle the length of the American continent.

Mike Brown, England's full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion. He is unsure when he will return to play for his club, Harlequins, after missing the Aviva Premiership clash with Saracens at Wembley. Brown is determined not to rush his return to avoid an extended break, similar to the experiences of Johnny Sexton and Geoff Parling. He was knocked out in England's match against Italy in February and hoped to recover for the Ireland game but pulled out due to symptoms. Brown credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by World Rugby online modules, for helping him make informed decisions about his recovery. He urges other players not to push through concussion symptoms and is glad he took the online modules.

The passage suggests that smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among couples in Britain. According to research, the average number of times a heterosexual couple has sex has decreased from five times a month in 1990 to three times a month currently. This decline is linked to the increasing integration of public and private lives due to constant smartphone use, leading to a lack of quiet, empty time. The passage also mentions that people living alone and busier lives due to technological advancements could be contributing factors. The researcher Catherine Mercer adds that dealing with work emails late in the evening can also impact the focus on one's partner.

Tibetan Mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg and were traditionally used for herding in Tibet, have seen a dramatic decline in popularity in China. Once commanding prices of up to £1.2 million each, they are now being sent to slaughterhouses due to their unpopularity. This decline is partly attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has discouraged the practice of giving these dogs as gifts to influence officials. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several Chinese cities have further impacted the breed's popularity. The collapse of China's mastiff market was revealed after animal welfare workers rescued a group of these dogs being transported to a slaughterhouse. The dogs were found in cramped cages, with many already dead and none having been given food or water for three days. The breed's boom began in 2005, leading to them being seen as status symbols, with one puppy selling for £1.2 million in 2020. However, the rapid pace of urbanization has made people realize that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living.

In response to common everyday emergencies, Leeds-based Direct Line has launched a competition called #everydayfix. They asked groups to design products to address these issues, with three prototypes making the shortlist: Snooze, Forget Me Lock, and Nipper. Snooze is an alarm clock that connects with your phone to silence notifications for a good night's sleep. Forget Me Lock is a device that attaches to your key and indicates if your door is locked or not. Nipper is a compact mobile phone charger that uses any household battery as its energy source. The public can vote for their favorite product by retweeting tweets about the prototypes, and the one with the most retweets will go into a Kickstarter campaign for development.
